summary: Paul Merson reignited his dispute with Tottenham midfielder Andros Townsend by mocking his seven-minute cameo in Spurs’ 0-0 draw at Burnley on Twitter, despite recently admitting he was wrong after Townsend’s stunning equaliser for England against Italy. Merson had initially criticized Townsend’s England call-up in his Sky Sports column, referencing his early substitution at Manchester United, but later said he would “hold his hands up” after the Italy goal. Townsend responded to Merson on Twitter, and although tensions appeared to ease, Merson took another dig following the Burnley match.

Chelsea have made a formal summer offer for FC Tokyo’s 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, planning to loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane, who says the bid is unrelated to Chelsea’s £200m, five-year Yokohama Rubber shirt sponsorship starting in 2015–16; a two-week pre-season tour of Japan is being considered. Muto, a recent Keio University economics graduate with 11 Japan caps (1 goal), scored 13 in his debut season, was named in the J-League best XI, and has three goals in four games this season as Tokyo sit third; a £4m fee is mooted, he would be Chelsea’s first Japanese player, and while honored by the offer, he has not yet decided to join.

A large study published in Pediatrics found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life—and those with repeated prescriptions before age two—were more likely to be overweight at age two, with boys particularly affected and also slightly taller; among two-year-olds, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese. Finnish researchers analyzed records for over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds and, while the study didn’t prove causation, they suggested antibiotics might alter gut bacteria in ways that increase calorie availability or appetite. The authors, led by Dr Antti Saari, warned that early-life antibiotic exposure may contribute to the global childhood obesity epidemic and urged judicious use. The report notes high obesity rates in England (about a third of 10–11-year-olds and over a fifth of 4–5-year-olds) and cites prior links between early antibiotics and eczema and digestive problems, alongside broader concerns that over-prescription fuels antibiotic resistance, with UK authorities warning a future superbug could infect 200,000 people and kill 80,000 in a single outbreak.

During the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace last week, a young Queen’s Guard slipped on a manhole cover as he took up position in his sentry box, slid sideways, knocked his bearskin, and fell in front of hundreds of tourists; he quickly got up as colleagues marched on, blushing at the crowd’s reaction. The incident, filmed on Thursday afternoon by holidaymaker David Meadwell, 50, from Newcastle-upon-Tyne, was thought to be caused by the metal protectors on the soles of the guard’s boots. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment, saying they would not comment on “a young man falling over while doing his job.” The Changing of the Guard, which draws thousands, takes place at 11:30am daily in summer and every other day in winter; the Guard comprises two detachments for Buckingham Palace and St James’s Palace under the Captain of The Queen’s Guard, and its members are fully operational soldiers.

A&E Networks will remake Roots, the landmark 1977 miniseries that drew over 100 million viewers, for a 2016 simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History. The new adaptation will retell Kunta Kinte’s story, be “original” and “contemporary,” draw more from Alex Haley’s novel, and consult African and African-American scholars for authenticity. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co–executive produce, while executive producer Mark Wolper, son of the original producer, emphasizes the story’s lineage and the need to keep retelling it. History’s Dirk Hoogstra says the project seeks to reach both original fans and a new generation, and Burton notes many young Americans don’t know the story or its importance. The remake comes amid a cultural backdrop that includes Barack Obama’s historic presidency, 12 Years a Slave’s Best Picture win, and widespread racial unrest over police treatment of black suspects.

Police are investigating claims by former royal footman Christopher Lawler, now 64, that on his first day at Clarence House in January 1978 he was pinned to a chair and groped by palace staff who tried to force him into an orgy, leading him to quit the same day. Lawler says he was accosted after entering a bedroom, restrained while men attempted to undo his trousers, and later threatened to keep quiet; his immediate complaint allegedly drew an angry response from Clarence House. Haunted by the incident, he contacted the Palace again last year after inquiries began into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse by a VIP paedophile ring in the 1970s and 80s, but says his complaints were ignored twice before being passed to Scotland Yard months later. A retired royal aide in his 80s was reportedly interviewed and denied involvement, saying he was at Balmoral at the time. The Palace has told Lawler the Royal Household will work exhaustively and cooperatively with any police inquiry, while police say it is inappropriate to comment as investigations continue.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek of Happy Valley, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air theme, filmed as they drive and ending with a sonogram reveal. Made to inform loved ones far away, the YouTube clip has been viewed over 1.7 million times and took five takes; its lyrics mention family pressure about parenthood, conceiving in two months, and Melissa discovering a positive test. The Meeks said the viral attention was unexpected and may make another video after learning the baby’s gender. Jesse is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, and Melissa previously filmed his reaction using a tag on their dog; a Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, couple made a similar Fresh Prince-themed announcement last year.

A gray jacket-and-full-skirt ensemble worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O’Hara in several key scenes of the 1939 film Gone With the Wind—now faded from its original slate blue-gray to light gray—sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions sale in Beverly Hills, California, part of more than 150 lots from the private collection of James Tumblin, former Universal Studios hair and makeup head, who began collecting the film’s memorabilia in the 1960s and famously bought the dress for $20 after finding it on the floor at Western Costume Company; other top results included Leigh’s straw hat ($52,500), Clark Gable’s Rhett Butler suit trousers and jacket ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia de Havilland as Melanie Wilkes ($30,000). The Oscar-winning film, based on Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel, marked its 75th anniversary last year, and Hattie McDaniel, who played Mammy, became the first African-American actor to be nominated for and to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell 10–12 feet into the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo cheetah exhibit around 3 p.m. Saturday after officials said he was dangled over the railing by his parents; his parents rescued him before responders arrived. He suffered minor bumps, bruises, and a leg injury, was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center in stable condition, and was not attacked, with zoo officials noting the cheetahs did not approach. Witnesses expressed shock and multiple accounts indicated the child had been dangled. The exhibit was closed, and the zoo said it plans to press child endangering charges.

A bright yellow Gatso speed camera on Wellington Road in Handsworth, Birmingham has been mysteriously turned to point at a house’s front door, though it hasn’t worked for over two years since all fixed cameras in the West Midlands—around 300 using old technology—were switched off in March 2013. Speed enforcement in the region now relies on mobile camera units, motorway fixed cameras, and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council, aware of the repointed camera, will send an engineer to the site and may remove it, noting fixed cameras were decommissioned as obsolete and that a limited digital-technology pilot is being developed. The Wellington Road camera will not be part of the pilot, and the house’s owners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2–3, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. Bolt said he is fit, healthy, and happy to run, praised the event’s atmosphere, highlighted Jamaica’s strong relay tradition, and affirmed his commitment to making the country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed delight at his selection and predicted “sprint magic” in the Bahamas. The full Jamaican team will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves showed support for Barcelona’s basketball team by attending the EuroLeague El Clasico with Neymar’s sister Rafaella, where Barcelona beat Real Madrid 85-80, though Madrid remain top of their division on points difference. Neymar had just helped Brazil defeat Chile 1-0 at the Emirates in a feisty match that included an incident where Gary Medel appeared to stamp on him. Before the international break, Luis Enrique’s Barcelona won the football El Clasico to go four points clear in La Liga, and they return to face Celta Vigo on Sunday as they pursue a treble.

Italy is facing a surge in Mediterranean crossings, with the coast guard rescuing 8,480 migrants from Friday to Monday and responding to 20 SOS calls on Monday alone. Save the Children fears about 400 people are missing after survivors reported a ship carrying 550 capsized about 80 miles off Libya, but the Italian coast guard says it cannot confirm this and an air-sea search found no survivors, bodies, or evidence of a capsized boat. The International Organization for Migration reports more than 10,000 arrivals in Italy in the first three months of 2015, about 2,000 rescues during the first weekend of April in the Channel of Sicily, and notes most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria via Libya. At least 480 migrants have died this year, often due to bad weather and overcrowded smuggler boats, with crews sometimes abandoning vessels; last week, 978 people were rescued in a single day.

Arsene Wenger says he doesn’t know exactly why Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool but is delighted to have him ahead of Saturday’s Barclays Premier League clash. After Barcelona decided to sell, the 26-year-old was convinced post-World Cup to join Wenger, making an immediate impact with 19 goals this season following a £32m move. Wenger acknowledges Liverpool’s interest and suggests it may have been leveraged during Luis Suarez’s transfer to Barcelona, potentially involving an exchange plus money. He hails Sanchez’s efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit, calling him top-level and a game-lifter. Wenger also downplays links to Raheem Sterling, while praising Brendan Rodgers for adapting after Suarez’s sale and Daniel Sturridge’s injury, noting Liverpool’s 100-plus league goals last season.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner who turns 35 on April 28, will attempt cycling’s Hour Record on June 7 at London’s Olympic Velodrome (Lee Valley VeloPark), aiming to beat the current 52.491 km set by Australia’s Rohan Dennis in February after the UCI reformed regulations. Calling the Hour a “holy grail,” Wiggins is returning to the track after ending his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix and will race the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire with his eponymous team as part of his build-up, while also targeting a British-record eighth Olympic medal at Rio 2016 in the team pursuit. Recent Hour milestones include Jens Voigt’s 51.115 km and Matthias Brandle’s 51.852 km, with Jack Bobridge falling short; Briton Alex Dowsett will also attempt the record on May 2 in Manchester. Wiggins’ ride will be broadcast live on Sky Sports before a hoped-for 6,000 sell-out crowd, with tickets sold online only via Sky Tickets from Friday, April 19 at 10am, priced £49, £39 and £29.

Serena Williams battled past Sara Errani 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3 in a Fed Cup play-off amid tough, windy conditions, then called the match an eye-opener, admitting she isn’t yet ready for clay and needs to adjust from a hard-court mindset. Despite improving her career record over Errani to 8-0, the United States lost the tie 3-2 after Williams and Alison Riske were routed 6-0, 6-3 by Errani and Flavia Pennetta in doubles, resulting in U.S. relegation to World Group II. Williams’ doubles defeat marred an otherwise flawless Fed Cup record; she recently won her 19th major at the Australian Open but the French Open remains her least successful Slam despite titles in 2002 and 2013. U.S. captain Mary Joe Fernandez said the team must work harder, citing depth in the top 100 and aiming to win two ties next year to return to the World Group.

River Plate want to re-sign Radamel Falcao but acknowledge the deal is complicated, with vice president Matias Patanian saying they “dream of Falcao” and “the doors are open.” Falcao joined River at 15 in 2001, debuted in 2005, and scored 34 goals in 90 games before leaving for Porto in 2009. Currently on a season-long loan at Manchester United, he has struggled with just four Premier League goals, leaving his future—staying at United or returning to parent club Monaco—uncertain. Despite club form, he scored three goals in two games this week for Colombia to equal the national team’s all-time scoring record with 24.

X Factor finalist and pop star Ella Henderson, 19, has been named the face of Batiste’s 2015 “Ready For It” campaign—her first brand collaboration and endorsement. The partnership between the platinum award-winning artist and the UK’s number one dry shampoo brand was arranged by the MILES agency and launched as an international TV campaign featuring her single “Mirror Man”; Henderson says she regularly uses the product. Campaign visuals show her against a blurred city backdrop with varied hairstyles, including glossy waves and a tousled half-ponytail, paired with black and animal-print outfits and nude makeup. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, which manages Henderson, praised the natural synergy between artist and brand and anticipated an exciting 2015.

A billboard in Kenosha, Wisconsin, featuring Officer Pablo Torres and his dog with the message “Thank you for your support, Kenosha” has angered family and friends of Aaron Siler, 26, whom Torres fatally shot on March 14 after Siler “armed himself with a weapon” following a vehicle and foot pursuit; Siler was wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant. Paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, the billboard was intended to thank the community, not offend, the group said, noting the incidents’ impact on the officer, his family, and the department. Siler’s family and friends called it disrespectful and want it removed, with one family friend saying it felt like “thank you for killing Aaron.” Torres is on leave pending a state Division of Criminal Investigation probe into Siler’s death. Ten days before the Siler shooting, Torres shot 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives; Knight was wounded and charged, and District Attorney Robert Zapf ruled that shooting justified after the case was turned over on March 20. The Siler investigation continues.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed and three militants were slain in clashes Monday near the Pakistan border in Negur, Sistan-Baluchestan, with Iranian officials saying the attackers crossed from Pakistan and asking Islamabad to capture the survivors. The Sunni militant group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility; described by Pakistani media as anti-Iranian, it targets Shiites, seeks to thwart Iranian influence, has emerged in areas of Pakistan’s Balochistan, and previously claimed an October 2013 attack that killed 14 Iranian border guards near Saravan. Iranian authorities say militants often flee back into Balochistan and have criticized Pakistan for failing to curb them. Pakistan condemned the incident as terrorism, said it is investigating, requested evidence from Iran, and pledged to apprehend any perpetrators who entered its territory.

Japan’s Defense Minister Gen Nakatani told the Diet that the Air Self-Defense Force has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs, noting that while jets are scrambled to investigate unidentified objects that could violate airspace, they typically turn out to be birds or other non-aircraft. The query came from ex-wrestler–turned–Upper House lawmaker Antonio Inoki, founder of New Japan Pro Wrestling and a high-profile media figure known for unconventional diplomacy, who asked whether aircraft had been scrambled for alien threats and whether research into alien visitors exists; he says he has seen a UFO but is unsure about aliens. The exchange echoes earlier debate, including a 2007 consideration by then–Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba of how Japan’s pacifist constitution would apply to defending against an invasion from outer space.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, waiting to board a plane at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, Anhui, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his left leg and buttocks after the porcelain toilet he was standing on to avoid touching the seat collapsed and shattered. Embarrassed, he called his companions rather than shout; authorities and emergency personnel took him to a hospital where he received dozens of stitches. He told friends he had been squatting but later told police he was sitting and blamed poor construction, possibly to avoid paying compensation. Authorities said it was an accident, and a police spokesman reminded the public that toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old found a hidden bathroom camera in her home that was traced to him; prosecutors say he sexually abused her over a four-year period and secretly filmed her and others. The investigation began in March after the camera was discovered under a sink; the girl reported Rebbie had watched her while she undressed or slept and that from ages 9 to 13 he entered her bedroom and molested her. Investigators recovered 41 bathroom videos (34 showing victims showering), some with close-ups of children’s genitalia, which Rebbie uploaded to his computer; the recordings span three to four years, and he admitted filming several victims and buying the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old. He is charged with aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy; his relationship to the family is unknown, his preliminary hearing is May 1, and he is held on $500,000 bail. Limerick’s police chief called the case particularly horrific.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama, 37, created a photo series/book roughly titled Daughter and Salaryman that pairs teenage daughters with their fathers, who leap into the air in sharp business suits while the daughters wear casual clothes, posed at various Japanese landmarks. Intended to let usually serious dads reveal a playful, heroic side and to echo the “salaryman” attire, the curious images have drawn strong online interest despite little else being known; the jumps range from subtle to ambitious and older fathers sometimes look pained.

Amid the fallout from managing director Paul Downton’s dismissal, attention turns to the County Championship as Kevin Pietersen, seen both reflective and jovial at Surrey’s photocall at The Kia Oval, edges closer to a possible England return. Downton’s sacking has paved the way for the 34-year-old—controversially axed in 2014—to rejoin the international set-up after last featuring in the disastrous Ashes tour in Australia that ended in a whitewash. Pietersen has rejoined Surrey to force his way back into the Test side, with Surrey facing Oxford MCCU on Sunday and starting their Championship campaign at Glamorgan on April 19; at the photocall he sat at the end of the front row, joked with photographers and teammates, and even took pictures himself.

Relegation-threatened Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week, having first dismissed him on Wednesday for poor results before owner Angelo Massone reinstated him the next day; after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani on Saturday left the team 16th and six points from safety, he was fired again. Ze Maria, 41, a former Inter and Parma right back capped 25 times by Brazil whose international career spanned five years, had replaced Florin Marin in January as the club’s third coach of the season, and will now be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar says Radamel Falcao likely regrets his season-long loan move to Manchester United, where after a serious knee injury he has struggled and scored only four goals. With United needing to pay £46 million to make the transfer permanent, they are unlikely to do so. Dirar notes Falcao was unhappy in Monaco but believes he would have played regularly and in the Champions League there, adding that Falcao may need “more atmosphere.”

New Zealand police are seeking public help to identify a very tall man who robbed the Union St dairy in east Christchurch around 12:30 pm on Saturday, wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt and a distinctive oversized cartoon mask; he demanded cash from the owner’s 30-year-old daughter, threw the cash register to the ground, and fled with the till drawer and about $1,500. No weapon was seen, the suspect remains at large, and anyone with information is asked to contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, 24, a math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice over alleged inappropriate relationships with 15-year-old pupils. She was first arrested on March 19 after admitting in a police interview to kissing a student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April the previous year, leading to her suspension and administrative leave. Following school-sourced rumors of a second victim, police interviewed another 15-year-old who alleged he had sex with Granado in her car on consecutive nights, January 18 and 19, across from another Dallas school. Granado was booked into Irving County Jail again on Monday and released on $50,000 bail; her intended plea to the second set of charges is unknown. The district said it took immediate, appropriate action, and administrative leave prevents her from working with students or being on Irving ISD property.

A widely viewed video (over 500,000 views) shows a large crocodile in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, swimming through a public marina with a lifeless black dog in its jaws; the dog reportedly belonged to a local bike shop owner. New Zealander Tim Weston, visiting with his wife, witnessed the incident, saying the crocodile held the dog for ages without moving, and noted a crocodile sanctuary about 200 meters up the river that connects to the sea and marina. Crowds gathered to watch, and when Weston returned a couple of hours later the croc was still there, though by the next morning neither animal nor crocodile was seen. Social media users reacted with horror after the clip was posted on the Bogged Facebook page. Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta, which is built among mangroves; they are also seen on the resort’s golf course. In Mexico, American crocodiles can reach lengths of up to 6 meters and, due to urbanization, are living closer to humans than before.

After a 2-0 defeat at Southampton, Steve Bruce insisted he can keep Hull City in the Premier League despite being just two points above the drop zone, noting he initially targeted 10 wins but has only six and now hopes eight or nine will suffice. Hull, who were better in the first half before a James Ward-Prowse penalty and late Graziano Pellè goal, have six games left, including tough ties against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce blamed long-term injuries to key players—Mohamed Diame (just back after five months), James Chester (three months), Michael Dawson and Nikica Jelavic (missed half the season), and Robert Snodgrass (out all season)—but remains confident of survival. Southampton moved up to fifth as Ronald Koeman addressed a penalty-taking dispute when Sadio Mane tried to take the spot-kick designated for Ward-Prowse, vowing to clarify team rules.

Ian Guffick, 31, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, let pupils change SATs answers and altered some himself after the test session for national curriculum exams for 11-year-olds (English, maths, science), prompting a local authority investigation that found changes were made outside exam conditions and led the Department for Education to annul all the school’s 2014 results. Guffick admitted unacceptable professional conduct, though he claimed he only sought to make answers more legible; a National College for Teaching and Leadership panel ruled no changes are permitted outside test conditions, calling his conduct dishonest but short of fraud and noting his remorse. Acting for the Education Secretary, Paul Heathcote banned him from teaching for at least two years, stating his actions were deliberate and not under duress; Guffick had been forced to give up his job and has 28 days to appeal to the High Court.

Danish goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard, who joined Manchester United from Aalesunds in 2010, has struggled for minutes—making just 19 league appearances in five seasons—and is now third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes; he has been told he can leave, with a January move to FC Midtjylland falling through over price. Off the pitch, he has been with Swedish model Misse Beqiri (who has Albanian roots) since 2012; they married last year in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius and have a son. The couple are active on Instagram—he recently shared a “day off” post with her in Cheshire/Manchester, while she frequently shares modeling photos to over 17,000 followers.

At a Sotheby’s auction, the 13 glowing blue letters that once topped Yankee Stadium in the Bronx (installed in 1976 and removed in 2008) failed to sell despite a $300,000–$600,000 estimate; the only $260,000 bid came from a Sotheby’s employee. The 10-foot-tall letters are owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who bought them after the stadium’s final 2008 game and said he wanted a new generation to enjoy them, even pledging to visit any U.S. buyer. In contrast, a late-1960s New York Mets bullpen car estimated at $20,000–$30,000 sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe of their professional responsibilities after Sterling was shown inhaling nitrous oxide on Monday and photos of both with shisha pipes surfaced a day later; he spoke to them on Thursday, will not discipline either, and wants to move on. Sterling will lead the line at Wembley on Sunday with Daniel Sturridge injured, and Ibe trained with the squad on Friday. Steven Gerrard is available after a three-match suspension for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, but Rodgers would not say if he will recall him, emphasizing his focus on reaching his first FA Cup final with Liverpool and framing past near-misses in the league and Capital One Cup as part of a learning process.

Arsenal’s Mesut Ozil returned to London after the international break and shared a “Home Sweet Home” photo relaxing with his dog, having impressed in Germany’s 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifying win over Georgia; despite missing Arsenal’s last match at Newcastle through illness, he is expected to start against Liverpool at the Emirates, with Arsene Wenger dismissing reports he was seen in a Berlin nightclub during his absence. Signed for £42.5m from Real Madrid in 2013, Ozil says he now fits English football “perfectly,” embracing its demanding, game-heavy schedule, and since returning from injury in January has produced four assists and three goals.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu insisted the La Liga leaders have no plans to replace coach Luis Enrique and are “very happy” with him, noting he signed a two-year deal through 2016, has impressed since taking charge last summer, and is six games from the title. He praised Enrique’s focus after the PSG match in Paris as he prepared for Valencia and said Barcelona are among the few clubs still competing for three trophies. Barcelona then beat Valencia 2-0 at the Nou Camp, with Luis Suarez scoring in the first minute and Lionel Messi adding a second after rounding Diego Alves.

Jordan Henderson has given Liverpool a boost after their FA Cup semi-final defeat by agreeing a new long-term deal at Anfield worth around £100,000 a week until 2020. The 24-year-old vice-captain, signed by Kenny Dalglish for £16m from Sunderland in 2011, has flourished under Brendan Rodgers, delivering 13 assists and seven goals this season, and is a candidate to replace Steven Gerrard as captain when he departs for LA Galaxy this summer. Henderson becomes the third key player to extend, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho, as Rodgers seeks stability amid potential departures, while talks with Raheem Sterling—who has rejected a new deal—are set to resume at season’s end, with chief executive Ian Ayre expecting Sterling to remain at the club long term.

Filipe Luis, who joined Chelsea from Spanish champions Atletico Madrid last July on a three-year contract, says he is happy at the club and intends to stay until his deal ends despite Atletico considering re-signing him and hoping his struggles to cement the left-back spot offer leverage. After playing in Brazil’s friendly wins over France and Chile, he turns back to the Premier League run-in, with Jose Mourinho demanding full focus and a drive to win every game; Luis acknowledges nine tough matches remain but believes the team is prepared to cope.

On March 27 at Franklin’s Gardens, Wasps No 8 Nathan Hughes’s knee accidentally struck George North’s head as North scored for Northampton, leaving North unconscious—his third knockout in two months—and he was advised to take at least a month off. Hughes was shown a red card and initially banned for three matches for recklessness despite no intent, causing him to miss Wasps’ Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon. After widespread criticism from players including James Haskell, Andy Goode, Austin Healey, and Joe Marler, Wasps appealed. On Friday night the appeal panel, chaired by Jeremy Summers, heard the case afresh with new evidence, ruled no foul play occurred and that the incident was accidental, rescinding the red card and overturning the ban. Hughes is free to play but is not in the squad to face London Welsh and is unlikely to feature again until Exeter visit on April 26.

Seattle’s fiery red sunsets, photographed by local Tim Durkan and shared on CNN iReport, were caused by smoke from southeastern Siberian wildfires that began when farmers burned grass and, driven by strong winds on April 14, quickly spread and destroyed dozens of villages. Although crews extinguished the flames, atmospheric winds carried the lingering smoke across the Pacific, affecting parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The smoke filters out shorter-wavelength light (greens, blues, yellows, purples), allowing reds and oranges to pass through, a phenomenon most intense at sunrise and sunset due to the longer atmospheric path. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the sunsets’ reddish hue will fade.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis had her brand-new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway a little over a month after purchase, but police recovered it on April 1 after a tip from Mick Sexton, who recognized the car. Returned with spray-painted red rims, red side detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel, Schoenig responded humorously on Facebook—prompting some to think it was an April Fools’ joke—thanking the thieves for “pimping” her ride. Despite the playful reaction, she’s having the car professionally cleaned due to strong cigarette and marijuana odors. To honor Sexton, she’s creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, called the Sexton on Wheels (banana, pineapple, peach, coconut cream). A friend described Schoenig as vibrant and someone who loves making people laugh.

Manchester City’s players, on incentivised contracts to meet financial fairplay requirements, will each forfeit £500,000 in bonuses—about £12m squad-wide—if the club fails to reach the Champions League group stage, a risk heightened after their derby defeat at Manchester United. City are fourth; United are now four points ahead, and if Liverpool beat Newcastle on Monday, City will be only four points clear of them, with the top three qualifying automatically and fourth needing to win a play-off. Manuel Pellegrini admits the season has “been thrown into the garbage” after starting 2015 level with Chelsea, with seven defeats including early FA Cup and Champions League exits. The run-in is West Ham (H, Apr 19), Aston Villa (H, Apr 25), Tottenham (A, May 3), QPR (H, May 10), Swansea (A, May 17) and Southampton (H, May 24). The uncertainty could hinder City’s pursuit of elite signings such as Paul Pogba, while Louis van Gaal says United’s win will help attract top players.

Manchester United’s Under-18s beat Manchester City 1-0 in a lively mini-derby at Altrincham’s 6,000-capacity Moss Lane, where about 1,000 watched for free at 3pm on Saturday; coach Paul McGuinness used a three-at-the-back system to mirror the first team and give his players a senior-style stage. In a game featuring 13 English starters (10 Mancunians), England U17 midfielder Callum Gribbin made and scored the winner with a curled free-kick after drawing a foul; United’s Marcus Rashford missed two good chances, City’s Marcus Wood nearly scored with a chip, Cameron Borthwick-Jackson hit the angle and survived a penalty shout against Buckley, Aaron Nemane found the side-netting, and Javairo Dilrosun’s late free-kick landed on the roof of the net. The result leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand in the Barclays Under-18 Premier League end-of-season play-off series, while injury-hit City have lost both matches, and the performance suggested both clubs have homegrown talents worthy of future opportunities.

After England’s 1-1 draw with Italy at Juventus Stadium, Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon—who earned his 147th cap—as a “legend of the game” and an inspiration, saying he is still learning by watching the 37-year-old. Hart, 10 years younger, marked his own 50th England cap, expressed pride in his milestones, and vowed to keep improving and “rack them up” by continuing to perform for club and country.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food-delivery market by partnering with Postmates to deliver online and mobile orders in 67 cities, adding a 9% service charge in addition to Postmates’ delivery fees, which start at $5 and vary by distance and demand. After previously declining third-party delivery, the chain approved Postmates, whose independent contractors use their own cars in a model similar to Uber. Other major brands are pursuing delivery as well: Starbucks (with Postmates in parts of Seattle and New York by year’s end), Taco Bell (testing this year), McDonald’s (planning “McDelivery”), and Burger King (piloting in select markets including parts of New York City). Chipotle’s profile also drew attention with recent visits from presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio.

Bill and Denise Richard, parents of 8-year-old Martin, the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, wrote a front-page Boston Globe op-ed urging the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for the convicted bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev (whom they do not name), in favor of life without parole with all appeal rights waived to avoid years of painful appeals. They recount the toll of Martin’s death and daughter Jane’s severe injuries, their experience witnessing graphic trial evidence, and acknowledge the crimes’ brutality, saying the defendant murdered their son and maimed their daughter. Tsarnaev was found guilty on all 30 charges; the sentencing phase begins Tuesday, a day after this year’s race, and is expected to last four weeks. The April 15, 2013 blasts killed Martin and two others and wounded more than 200; Tsarnaev’s brother Tamerlan was killed in a police shootout. The Richards stress they speak only for themselves and call to “turn the page” for their family, Boston, and the country.

A mystery billionaire has converted a Boeing 747-8 jumbo jet into an ultra-luxury private aircraft, reportedly costing about £400 million and taking three years to customize by Greenpoint Technologies. Normally able to carry up to 600 passengers, this version is designed for the owner and several dozen guests, featuring multiple lounges, a hotel-like state room, a lavish master suite, an office/guest bedroom, a conference room, and an aeroloft on the top deck with eight full beds. The central section hosts an onboard restaurant-style dining room with an adjoining kitchen for a private chef. Artist’s impressions and a published layout highlight the opulent, hotel-inspired interior, described as one of the most luxurious private planes ever built.

SpaceX launched a two-stage Falcon 9 from Cape Canaveral carrying the uncrewed Dragon cargo ship to the International Space Station, with ascent successful and Dragon set to dock in a couple of days to deliver over 4,300 pounds (1,950 kg) of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker; the crew will unpack for about five weeks before loading more than 3,000 pounds of experiments and trash for Dragon’s return and Pacific splashdown off California. The company’s bid to land the rocket’s first stage on an ocean droneship failed when it touched down too hard and tipped over, following a similar failed attempt in January; SpaceX plans to keep trying to enable reusable rockets and cut costs by up to a factor of 100, as most boosters otherwise burn up or fall into the ocean. This was SpaceX’s sixth ISS mission and the second launch attempt for this flight after a weather scrub on Monday.

Priscilla Presley, 69, will serve as witness at the first wedding at the new Elvis Presley’s Graceland Wedding Chapel inside Las Vegas’s Westgate Hotel, collaborating with NBC’s Today show on a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win the “ultimate wedding.” The winners, announced next Monday, will marry on Thursday, April 23, at the venue—formerly the Las Vegas Hilton, where Elvis performed more than 830 sold-out shows—and receive a free reception, a two-night hotel suite, airfares, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Presley, involved in the chapel’s design, insisted there will be no impersonators and emphasized it is a first-class venue, part of what officials say is the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis’s artifacts outside his Memphis home. Couples must submit a video or photos and an explanation of why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his side can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a 2-0 win over Newcastle at Anfield that left them four points behind City in the Champions League race. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet made their 47th appearances of the season, equalling the most by any player in Europe’s top five leagues. Raheem Sterling scored in the ninth minute and Joe Allen added his first Anfield goal with 20 minutes remaining, though Newcastle had a strong penalty appeal when Dejan Lovren appeared to foul Ayoze Perez, which Allen thought looked a spot-kick. Henderson said Liverpool needed to respond to recent poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal and would keep pushing, while City have been faltering, including a 4-2 loss to United. Allen admitted it wasn’t his best game but said the goal was important after recent defeats.

Roma ended a four-month home winless run with a key Serie A victory over Napoli, boosting their Champions League push. Miralem Pjanic finished a swift counter in the 25th minute after link-up play from Juan Iturbe and Alessandro Florenzi, and 38-year-old goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis preserved the lead with multiple second-half saves, notably against Dries Mertens and Manolo Gabbiadini. Second-place Roma moved provisionally four points ahead of Lazio, having gone seven home matches without a win since November 30 against Inter, while Napoli’s winless streak reached five and they remained fifth. Security was tight for Napoli’s first visit since a fan’s death before last season’s Italian Cup final: Campania residents were barred from buying tickets, 1,000 police were deployed, and no problems were reported. Roma were without injured Francesco Totti and Gervinho; a possible Napoli penalty for Kostas Manolas’s shoulder-to-shoulder on Jonathan De Guzman was not given; Iturbe missed a late chance to make it 2-0, and Lorenzo Insigne returned late from a November knee injury.

Doncaster Rovers’ drab League One season, mired in mid-table mediocrity, was summed up by a goalless home draw with Fleetwood Town at the Keepmoat Stadium—a match so uneventful it tested fans’ patience and left the club’s media team posting a 27-second YouTube highlights video with just 14 seconds of action, featuring only the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle, as Fleetwood’s faded play-off hopes had them effectively “eyeing the beach.”

Roland Giroux has developed an unusually tactile bond with his blood parrot cichlid, filming himself gently cupping and massaging the fish in its tank as it relaxes, returns to his hand after swimming away, and even swims up his arm and follows his hand to the water’s surface when he withdraws it. After removing two tank mates that were bullying the cichlid, Giroux began hand-feeding it frozen blood worms, which made it more sociable; the fish now enjoys daily stroking, becomes frustrated without it, and receives at least 15 minutes of play each day. Giroux shares many videos of this interaction on his YouTube channel. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

The passage portrays Ben Stokes as a fiery, charismatic cricketer whose aggression needs careful channeling, highlighted by the Kensington Oval locker incident that broke his wrist and his clash with Marlon Samuels in the second Test. After a talk with coach Peter Moores, Stokes responded well, showing he can keep his natural exuberance while controlling it to produce runs and wickets, without trying to live up to a pigeon-holed reputation. A minor back niggle could keep him out in Barbados, but his resilience after a turbulent year and his willingness to confront challenges, as seen against Mitchell Johnson in the Ashes, make him valuable. Selection debates include a possible second spinner in Adil Rashid, which could impact Stokes or Chris Jordan, but England want both to play often, especially with limited need for two spinners this summer, to help them grow—an exciting prospect.

Wales’ Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on 12 June at Cardiff City Stadium is a 33,000 sell-out after their 3-0 win in Israel sparked huge demand. Both teams have 11 points from five games, with Belgium (ranked fourth in the world) leading Group B on goal difference, and Wales are seen as well placed to secure one of the two automatic qualifying spots—their best chance of reaching a major finals since the 1958 World Cup. The FAW said it was inundated with ticket orders, and despite speculation about moving to the 74,500-capacity Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules prevent changing venues within 120 days, so the match stays in Cardiff, a setting preferred by the Wales squad; they have not played at the Millennium Stadium since facing England in March 2011.

England Under-17 coach John Peacock has named his squad for next month’s UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, with the defending champions—who beat Holland on penalties last year and qualified with a 100 per cent record—drawn in Group D with Holland, Italy and the Republic of Ireland; they face Italy in Burgas on May 7, Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13. The squad is: goalkeepers Paul Woolston (Newcastle United), Will Huffer (Leeds United); defenders Danny Collinge (Stuttgart), Reece Oxford (West Ham United), Easah Suliman (Aston Villa), James Yates (Everton), Jay DaSilva (Chelsea), Tayo Edun (Fulham); midfielders Trent Arnold (Liverpool), Daniel Wright (Sunderland), Herbie Kane (Liverpool), Tom Davies (Everton), Marcus Edwards (Tottenham Hotspur), Nathan Holland (Everton), Chris Willock (Arsenal); forwards Layton Ndukwu (Leicester City), Stephy Mavididi (Arsenal), Ike Ugbo (Chelsea). Notable inclusions are Chelsea’s Jay DaSilva and Ike Ugbo, first-time call-ups Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, and recalled Liverpool pair Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold, who missed the Elite Round in which England beat Romania, Norway and Slovenia.

Manchester City are pursuing Anderlecht’s 14-year-old playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, a highly rated talent also attracting interest from Arsenal and Barcelona; he previously rejected Barcelona’s La Masia at 12 to continue his studies, and City have held talks with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock about a compensation deal as Manuel Pellegrini looks to build for the future.

A 23-year-old man has been arrested and bailed in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old Mexican national and transgender escort whose body was found in a Fulham, south west London flat on March 28; she was pronounced dead at the scene around 9:30 pm with head and neck injuries after being strangled and beaten. Police, led by Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves, are appealing for anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death, particularly on Friday or Saturday. Santillan, who worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami and described herself online as visiting London from Miami, is understood to have moved to London from Mexico; police have not confirmed whether her profession is central to the investigation but say they will do everything to solve the case.

On The Jeremy Kyle Show, Dawn—who has suffered seven miscarriages and buried one baby, Daniel James—accused family friend and housemate Jamie, a convicted burglar, of stealing £207 she and her partner had saved toward a £500 gravestone. After initially denying it, Jamie was found to be lying by a lie detector test; Kyle also revealed Jamie had sent Dawn a Facebook message en route to the show confessing to taking the money and professing love, while blaming his girlfriend Carol. Devastated, Dawn burst into tears, saying she felt betrayed and that the money was meant to honor Daniel James with a headstone, and she was later comforted by her partner.
MODEL FAILED TO RETURN ANY OUTPUT

Tottenham striker Harry Kane, who has broken into both Spurs’ first team and Roy Hodgson’s England side during a remarkable season, is featured in a new Copa90 animation that uses layered still photographs to showcase his best goals and celebrations, including a long-range strike against Chelsea, a header versus Arsenal, and his goal on his England debut; the season has also seen him net his 20th Premier League goal against Newcastle. Titled “Harry Kane – PFA Player of the Year?” the video was released ahead of Sunday’s awards, where Kane is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year, competing for the top prize against Chelsea’s Eden Hazard and Arsenal’s Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher backed Brendan Rodgers to remain Liverpool manager despite a third straight trophyless season and a likely finish outside the top four, noting that one game shouldn’t determine his future and that many of last summer’s signings haven’t settled. With Liverpool seven points off fourth-placed Manchester City with a game in hand and out of the FA Cup after a poor semi-final loss to Aston Villa, Carragher said Rodgers must identify improvements and make the right signings to target a trophy and a top-four return next season. Carragher also received a Beacon Award for his Merseyside community work; the 37-year-old, who played 737 games for Liverpool, supports coaching in eight deprived-area schools through his 23 Foundation and aims to inspire local youngsters, reflecting his roots in Bootle and commitment to giving back.

At East Midlands Airport, four-year-old James Hayward was frisked by security and had his £6 plastic Nerf soft-dart gun confiscated after the toy in his hand luggage was flagged by X-ray and deemed a security risk as an item resembling a prohibited item; his father, Phil, called the checks “ludicrous” and “over‑zealous,” but the family, running late for a 10-day Easter trip to Lanzarote, complied and later bought a replacement online. The airport apologized for the inconvenience, said it had offered to post the toy to the family’s home in Doncaster, and defended the decision as adherence to government-set rules from the Department of Transport that ban replica or model guns and any items that resemble prohibited items.

A 31-year-old man identifying as “Rich” from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted a Gumtree ad seeking a girlfriend or wife, listing requirements including loving pets; preferably being a non-drinker and non-smoker; being fit, reliable, honest, loyal, handy around the house, a good cook, great in bed; and enjoying the outdoors while also able to be a “princess” when needed. He offered accommodation and possible perks such as a company car, phone, laptop, a free gym membership, and “lots of benefits,” said he’s “not shy of blowin cash on my woman,” would consider all reasonable offers, and excluded former partners. He described himself as athletic, white, heavily tattooed, brown-haired and brown-eyed, 175 cm tall, well endowed, sober and drug-free, into travel and outdoor activities like sports, fishing, and camping, owning property, making great money, successful, independent, and fond of cars and bikes. Daily Mail Australia was unable to contact him.

FA chairman Greg Dyke, facing Premier League opposition, is pushing reforms to boost English talent, including raising the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and redefining “home-grown” as training in England for three years before age 18 (instead of 21). Five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson and Steve McClaren—have backed him in a letter reported by the Daily Telegraph, urging the game to support the FA’s England Commission proposals and warning that blocking them would harm England’s prospects and prolong the wait for a World Cup. Citing that only 81 of 220 Premier League starters (36.8%) were England-eligible, they argue the top-level talent pool is shrinking, accept some responsibility for past failures, and highlight encouraging young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling and Harry Kane, stressing that opportunity is the missing ingredient despite positive recent England results.

In the next episode of Poldark, Demelza (Eleanor Tomlinson)—barely showing last week—rapidly advances from announcing her pregnancy to being eight months along and then giving birth within minutes, as Ross Poldark (Aidan Turner) lovingly gazes at their new baby daughter. Though Ross married his red-headed kitchen maid out of duty, he tells her she makes him a better man, signaling his commitment despite widespread viewer infatuation with the Sunday-night heartthrob. The rushed timeline echoes Elizabeth’s earlier full-term pregnancy that unfolded between episodes, prompting fans to joke on Twitter that in Poldark times, if you’re pregnant, you’ll have the baby “in the next 10 minutes.”

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson, whose bottom‑placed side is three points from safety after back‑to‑back wins including a 3-2 victory at West Brom sealed by Jamie Vardy’s injury‑time winner, urges his players to stay calm, ignore relegation rivals, and focus solely on their own performances ahead of hosting Swansea. He says their future remains in their own hands if they maintain form through the run‑in, notes that while other teams being dragged into the battle helps, outside results only matter if Leicester do their job, and warns against growing over‑optimism as perceptions and predictions shift.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale tracked by Oregon State University scientists, completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded—nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 km)—traveling from feeding grounds off Russia’s Sakhalin Island across the Pacific and down the U.S. West Coast to Baja, Mexico, surpassing the previous 10,190-mile humpback whale record noted by Guinness. Lead researcher Bruce Mate said the journey, during which Varvara visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggests she may be from Mexico and indicates some whales classified as endangered western gray whales could actually be eastern grays, implying the true western population (believed to be about 150) might be even smaller and warrants closer study despite prior genetic differentiation findings.

On Hokkaido’s Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, about 1,000 feet of seabed rose to form new coastline overnight, reaching 30–50 feet above sea level, about 100 feet wide, and roughly 1,000–1,640 feet long. An aerial survey by researcher Yoshinori Yajima suggests a landslide—caused by melting ice and snow that dropped nearby land and pivoted the seabed upward—was responsible. Residents reported no sounds or tremors; authorities say the event differs from earthquakes, is not linked to the 7.8-magnitude Kathmandu Valley quake, and is not expected to expand further. Marine organisms like seaweed and sea urchins remain attached to the exposed mass.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied plans to leave Paris Saint-Germain, affirming his love for the club, city, and teammates, and expressing a desire to sign a new contract despite a recent dispute with coach Laurent Blanc after being dropped for the Champions League match against Chelsea; he says he’s ready whenever selected, though PSG’s reported interest in Barcelona’s Dani Alves could influence whether he stays.

Carlos Tevez, 31, wants to leave Juventus this summer to return to Boca Juniors, but Boca president Daniel Angelici says the move depends on Tevez first terminating his Juventus contract, which runs until 2016, adding that a deal is close. Juventus, where Tevez is on course for a second Serie A title and leads the league with 17 goals, are reluctant to lose him but accept his wish to depart and are seeking replacements, with Tuttosport claiming he has decided to go. Tevez began at Boca’s youth academy, scored 26 league goals in 76 games before joining Corinthians in 2005, and has long said he intends to finish his career at Boca. Argentina coach Tata Martino says a move to Boca would not affect Tevez’s national-team prospects and would not be a step down.

Bayern Munich crushed Porto 6-1 at the Allianz Arena on Tuesday, leading 5-0 at half-time, to reach the Champions League semi-finals despite Porto’s 3-1 first-leg win; the goals came from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a Robert Lewandowski brace. During the match, manager Pep Guardiola ripped the left leg of his trousers, exposing his underwear, and joked afterward that he’d have to buy new ones.
MODEL FAILED TO RETURN ANY OUTPUT

Ahead of Sunday’s 4pm top-of-the-table clash at the Emirates, second-placed Arsenal trail leaders Chelsea by 10 points with six league games left. Mesut Ozil celebrated with a new Apple Watch—acquired at an Apple store on Thursday and priced between £299 and £13,500—sharing on Instagram that it’s like Michael Knight’s watch from Knight Rider; the device goes on general sale Friday. Ozil, with four goals in 25 appearances this season, is expected to start. Arsenal have also been boosted by Jack Wilshere’s return after five months out, having made the FA Cup semi-final bench against Reading and trained last week. Club great Ray Parlour, a three-time league winner, backs Wilshere as the club’s future but warns his injury record—citing Abou Diaby as a caution—must improve for him to reach his potential.

Referee Mark Clattenburg has been appointed to officiate Sunday’s Manchester derby at Old Trafford, despite having dismissed three players connected to United and City this season—two United players in Premier League matches (Tyler Blackcett in the 5-3 loss at Leicester and Luke Shaw in the 1-1 draw at West Ham) and City captain Vincent Kompany during Belgium’s 1-0 win over Israel, which leaves Kompany suspended for Wales in June. Though he has courted controversy and faced claims of favouring Louis van Gaal’s side, Clattenburg is regarded as one of the Premier League’s leading referees alongside Michael Oliver. He will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official. The match arrives with United a point above City after the champions’ 2-1 loss to Crystal Palace, United on a five-game league winning run and City struggling since the turn of the year, making the derby potentially decisive for second place behind expected winners Chelsea.

Federal MP Bob Katter sparked controversy by accusing the Queensland Government of assuming embattled MP Billy Gordon would resign and viewing him as “a little black puppet on a string,” after Gordon quit the Labor Party over domestic-violence allegations and failing to disclose his criminal history but said he would remain in parliament as an independent, throwing the razor-thin-majority government into chaos. Citing recent federal cases where resignations weren’t expected, Katter argued Gordon was treated differently, defended his phrasing as deliberate and informed by his own experiences of racism, and drew social media criticism over his terminology. He also pointed to Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott as independents who became government puppets and vowed Gordon would not do the same.

Illinois teen Dayna Dobias of Downers Grove, born with cerebral palsy, is using energetic dance videos to challenge stereotypes, counter bullying and stares, and encourage people to think before judging; she stresses that while she may do some things differently, she’s fundamentally like everyone else and hopes to improve how disabilities are represented in television, film, and fashion. She has created multiple videos, including one set to Taylor Swift’s “Shake It Off,” and despite early medical warnings that she might never walk, she now dances, drives, attends college, and has begun motivational speaking at Chicago-area schools to inspire others and turn negativity into something positive.

Orlando City, coached by former Everton and Manchester City striker Adrian Heath, have inquired about signing Manchester United’s Javier Hernandez, seeing the 26-year-old—currently frustrated on loan at Real Madrid—as a major commercial draw for their large Latin-American fanbase; captain Kaka already fronts the MLS side. However, Hernandez also has strong interest from eight European clubs: Premier League sides Southampton, Stoke, West Ham and Everton, and Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio and Inter Milan, with United willing to sell for about £8m and the player having one year left on his contract. Separately, United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira after he rejected their opening terms, with Paris Saint-Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven and Feyenoord contacting his father, and Pereira was on the bench against Aston Villa on Saturday.

Around 12:15 a.m. Saturday at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles, at least three suspects argued with a driver, then doused his white Dodge Charger with gasoline and set it on fire while two passengers were inside; the driver’s grandmother said the incident followed a carjacking attempt in which a gun was shown and the driver fled. No one was injured, but the car’s front end was destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the case as arson, using surveillance video, and the suspects remain at large.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni in southern Iowa, surrendered his state license after the Iowa Board of Chiropractic reported he bartered sex for services with some patients and performed exorcisms; he signed an agreement admitting wrongdoing, pledging not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years, and requiring him to prove the circumstances leading to revocation no longer exist before he can practice again. The report also says he recommended that patients stop taking medication he prescribed to them. A woman answering a call to his home declined comment, his former practice said he hadn’t worked there for some time, and his practice’s Yelp-listed Lamoni address appears to be a residence. Despite this, three patient surveys on HealthGrades.com gave him a perfect five-star satisfaction rating.

The U.S. lodged a complaint to Moscow after a Russian SU-27 intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland, with the U.S. crew calling the Russian pilot’s close, high-speed maneuvers unsafe and unprofessional. Russia’s Defense Ministry, via Sputnik, claimed the U.S. plane was heading toward its border with its transponder off and said the SU-27 circled to identify it, a claim a U.S. European Command official denied. The Pentagon and State Department plan to pursue the issue through diplomatic channels. This follows a similar incident a year earlier when a Russian jet flew within 100 feet of an RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk, described by U.S. officials as one of the most dangerous close passes in decades. Such aircraft encounters are common in Northern Europe and between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent’s sniper rifle was stolen overnight on March 27 from his car in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City, about a week before President Obama’s visit. The rifle was in a hard case padlocked and chained to a truck safe and, despite being secured properly, a thief broke the rear right passenger window, likely tied a rope to the case handle or a cable lock, and used another vehicle’s momentum to rip it free, pulling the window frame out; officers found two skid marks, pieces of rope, and the broken case handle. The agent’s gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also taken, with some bags and clothing later found at a Residence Inn across the street, but the rifle has not been recovered. The hotel had no surveillance cameras; the rifle’s serial number was entered into the National Crime Information Computer; the Secret Service was notified; and police do not know if the agent’s car was specifically targeted. The hotel is next to the city’s airport and near the state’s FBI office.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbour, Terrence Freebody, by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times in the dining room of a home on Mugga Way in Red Hill, Canberra, in July 2012. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen, who examined Costa after the attack, testified that Costa’s mental state was declining before and during the incident, citing triple 0 calls made almost certainly during the event that showed moment-to-moment mood swings and a trail of faeces from the scene to the toilet where police found Costa as signs of confusion. He said Costa’s brain was compromised by dementia and alcohol, leaving him unable to understand what he was doing or the long-term consequences. Prosecutor Shane Drumgold suggested Costa feigned memory loss, which the psychiatrist denied, stating it was “more likely than possible” that Costa had a demented illness in the weeks, months, and possibly years leading up to the event. Costa’s state of mind is central to the case, and the jury can return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time is proven.

Everton beat Burnley 1-0 at Goodison Park despite a 10th-minute penalty miss by Ross Barkley, who took the kick—awarded for David Jones’ foul on Aaron Lennon—despite specialist Leighton Baines being on the pitch (15/16 Premier League penalties). Barkley’s well-struck effort wasn’t in the corner and was saved by goalkeeper Tom Heaton. Though recalling January’s controversy when Kevin Mirallas took and missed a penalty ahead of Baines, there was no dispute this time. Manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley, saying Romelu Lukaku would have taken it if on the field and that several players are trusted based on how they feel, praising Barkley’s responsibility and noting Baines was content. Kevin Mirallas later scored in the 29th minute to secure the win.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on Holland America Line’s ms Ryndam at 11:30 a.m. Thursday in San Juan, Puerto Rico, in what the cruise line said appears to be a murder-suicide. The cabin was secured and authorities, including the FBI, were notified; investigators were on scene, and the cruise line said authorities will make the official determination. The ship departed Tampa on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and is currently in San Juan. According to a Puerto Rico Port Authority spokesman, cleaning staff discovered the bodies after knocking on the cabin door.

Former Holland forward and assistant coach Patrick Kluivert led Curacao into the second CONCACAF qualifying round for the 2018 World Cup, advancing 4-3 on aggregate after a 2-2 draw at Montserrat followed a 2-1 win in Willemstad. The tie was headed to extra time until substitute Charlton Vicento scored in the 87th minute, five minutes after coming on. Curacao will face Cuba on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, previously worked with Louis van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup and was a World Cup losing semi-finalist in 1998 as a player and last year as Van Gaal’s assistant.

Esteban Cambiasso says keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would feel like winning a trophy, despite the club being seven points adrift at the bottom with eight games left and winless since January; he remains confident, telling BBC East Midlands Today that survival is their objective and that his teammates can achieve it, with Nigel Pearson’s side next facing West Ham. The veteran, who joined on a one-year deal last summer after a decade in Italy, has become a key player and is happy in the East Midlands, open to staying beyond this season. His career honors include titles with River Plate (Argentine Primera División), Real Madrid (La Liga, a Super Cup, Supercopa de España), and Inter Milan (Champions League, five Serie A, four Coppa Italia, four Supercoppa, FIFA Club World Cup).

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two children under five by different fathers, handed both babies to her 52-year-old mother Debbie when they were four months old after social services threatened to remove them. Debbie, who has raised the children since, says Gemma’s ongoing drinking, partying, and use of the legal high MKat, along with suspected theft, make her unfit, and she plans to ban Gemma from her home and from seeing the children, who call Debbie “mum.” Debbie accuses Gemma, who is unemployed, of selling a child’s iPad to fund her lifestyle; Gemma denies taking the device but admits stealing money and other items from her mother, and a lie detector on The Jeremy Kyle Show indicated she did steal. Debbie says Gemma has been troubled since age 13 and prioritizes partying over motherhood, insisting she needs to stop drinking, drugs, and partying.

Eden Hazard scored to give Chelsea a 1-0 lead over Manchester United at Stamford Bridge after a move sparked by John Terry’s strong challenge from behind on Radamel Falcao near halfway, which released a loose ball that Cesc Fabregas and Oscar combined to set up Hazard. During Sky Sports’ half-time analysis, pundits Graeme Souness, Thierry Henry, and Jamie Redknapp agreed the challenge was a foul and play should have been stopped: Souness said Terry used a forearm/elbow on Falcao, Henry said he would want that foul as a striker, and Redknapp noted Falcao might have stayed stronger but insisted it was still a foul.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott’s tour bus caught fire Thursday morning on Interstate 30 northeast of Dallas; bystander Michael Barnett filmed smoke and flames from the rear and later uploaded the video to CNN iReport, saying he stopped recording out of concern and didn’t realize it was the band’s bus. Scott posted on Instagram that she, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver were safely evacuated, expressing gratitude, and noted the fire destroyed everything in the back lounge except her Bible. The tour manager told KTVT the bus had stopped after a rear tire blew out and it burst into flames after everyone got off. Bandmates Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not on the bus, and Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday in Arlington, Texas.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University proposes using satellites covered in mirrors to harvest sunlight, convert it via semiconductors into laser light, and beam it to Earth to boost solar panels and potentially power homes—making solar viable even in Scotland and restoring power quickly after disasters; initial trials in Scotland were successful, with plans to move trials to Portugal. He stresses the beams would be far weaker than sci‑fi depictions—not even strong enough to blind a pigeon—though he notes concerns about who controls the satellites. A separate Tokyo Riken proposal would mount a laser on the ISS to use its telescope to locate debris up to 100 km away and gently push sub‑centimetre pieces into the atmosphere, and this system also would not be weaponizable.

Stephen Munden, 54, a convicted paedophile described as having a fanatical obsession with young girls, went missing at 6.15pm on Tuesday after leaving a psychiatric hospital in Winchfield near Hook, Hampshire, prompting a police manhunt. He is about 5ft 8ins, heavy build, with dark hair, and may have shaved his beard; police released images of him bearded and clean-shaven. Formerly of Marchwood near Southampton, he was detained under the Mental Health Act and made subject to a hospital order after his conviction last August for sexually touching a girl under 13, having sat near a three-year-old on a bus and stroked her hand, which he denied was deliberate. Prosecutors said he admitted ten unrelated offences of possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children, was arrested after trying to download images on a public computer at Hythe library, and had children’s clothes, books and dolls at home. A consultant psychiatrist said he is autistic with mild learning difficulties and struggles to control sexual interest in small children, and police urged anyone with information to come forward urgently.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay $2,630,000 in gifts to Rochelle “Shelly” Sterling after Shelly sued, alleging Stiviano targeted wealthy older men and that Donald Sterling used marital funds to give her luxury items—including a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover—and help her obtain a $1.8 million duplex; Stiviano argued the gifts were legitimate and she didn’t exploit him. Shelly’s lawyer called it a victory that sets a precedent for injured spouses to recover such gifts. The list of gifts also included smaller items like a $391 Easter bunny costume, a $299 blender, and a $12 lace thong. The case follows Donald Sterling’s downfall after audio surfaced of him berating Stiviano for posting photos with African-Americans, including Magic Johnson, which led NBA Commissioner Adam Silver to ban him, fine him $2.5 million, and move to terminate his ownership rights.

Thierry Henry, speaking as a Sky Sports pundit after Arsenal’s goalless draw with Chelsea, criticised Arsenal’s transfer dealings and urged the club to sign four top players—a goalkeeper, centre back, holding midfielder and a top-quality striker—to form a title-winning spine. He questioned whether Arsenal can win the league with Olivier Giroud as first-choice striker despite his 14 Premier League goals, saying he “does a job” but is not enough to win the title. Citing Chelsea’s signings of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas and Diego Costa as the model, Henry said Arsene Wenger “has to do it” to create competition within the squad. Arsenal are third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City with a game in hand.

A young woman told Sydney’s District Court how years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn severely affected her life, saying she fears future relationships and feels he stole her first sexual experience. Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child, and sat calmly in the dock without looking at her. The woman, who cannot be named, said she didn’t know the abuse was wrong at the time, kept it secret until learning he had been caught, and has since experienced depression from age 14, hospitalization for self-harm, and an attempted suicide; she also fears people finding out and worries about how the abuse will affect her relationships with men. Van Ryn is in custody and the hearing continues.

Arsenal’s 19-year-old midfielder Serge Gnabry, a Germany Under-21 international who impressed last season but was sidelined by a serious knee injury, has not featured for the first team since the Champions League last-16 second leg against Bayern Munich in March 2014; he is now nearing a return after playing 90 minutes for the Under-21s in a 1-0 loss to Reading on Monday—his second full match in a week—and says he feels “better and better,” is over his injury worries, and is looking forward to the next game.

Jacob Phillips, 23, a University of Birmingham accountancy graduate working for Liam Gallagher’s Pretty Green, died after falling about 70ft from a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, when he ran from a taxi at night to avoid paying a fare after drinking in Cardiff. He and friends Padraig Crowley and Rory Robinson exited the cab claiming to use an ATM before fleeing; driver Dave Sidaway briefly chased but stopped in the dark. Disoriented in pitch black, Phillips leapt over a fence near the disused Northern Promenade (The Dardanelles) and fell to the rocky beach, where a dog walker found his body the next morning. Cardiff Coroner’s Court recorded accidental death, noting he likely didn’t know the danger; the cabbie said he wouldn’t have left him had he known the area. Phillips, of Reading and raised in Barry, had returned to Wales for Christmas, was staying with his mother in Cowbridge, and had planned to stay at a friend’s house but lacked money for the taxi.

Amid last summer’s UK passport backlog, when HM Passport Office struggled with 3.6 million applications and more than 500,000 were stuck by mid-June, ministers refused blanket refunds despite many families paying an extra £30 per passport for fast-track and some still missing trips. Only 2,191 compensation claims were approved between April last year and January this year (little changed from 2,077 the previous year), totaling £203,066—an average of £92.68, with payments ranging from £1 to £5,463—and the number of rejected claims is unknown due to a customer complaint database failure. While urgent cases received a free upgrade, ministers rejected the Home Affairs Select Committee’s call to compensate all out-of-pocket applicants, saying it would set a precedent. Keith Vaz, the committee chair, condemned the outcome, noting that HM Passport Office posted a £42.3 million surplus during the chaos and managers received £1.8 million in bonuses in 2013–14 (average £499, highest £3,500). Of more than a dozen affected holidaymakers contacted by the newspaper, only one received compensation; one couple lost nearly £1,500 despite applying 10 weeks early and paying for upgrades.

A three-bedroom semi-detached “timewarp” home in Horfield, Bristol, untouched since the 1930s, is being auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000; inside it retains original features including a mint-and-black 1930s bathroom with tiles, wooden floor, yellow wallpaper and green sink, the original kitchen with cupboards and a glass-panelled door, a wood-panelled hall, a brick open-face fire, oil-fired central heating, and stained-glass windows depicting ships and coats of arms, plus hallway tins of Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk, Tate & Lyle sugar and Colman’s Mustard; while the house has been double glazed, auctioneer David Beddoe warns renovation costs may deter developers, though it could suit a family or collectors with a passion for antiques.

Colin Kaepernick started his NFL career as Alex Smith’s backup, became the San Francisco 49ers’ starting quarterback mid-2012 after Smith’s concussion, stayed in the role, and led the team to its first Super Bowl since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth “Babyface” Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent much of her early life there, then moved to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45 mi freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone and around Colchester, attended the Stanway School, where he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur, whose debut album Leisure (1991) received mixed reviews; drawing on alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop, the band released a self-titled debut album in 2001 to worldwide success. His solo debut, Everyday Robots, co-produced by XL Recordings CEO Richard Russell, was released on 28 April 2014 and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as samples of Lord Buckley’s rants.
Mogadishu, locally known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, and as the national capital it hosts many important national institutions.
“Happiness in Slavery” is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, released on their debut EP, Broken (1992).
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The passage outlines two works titled Shooter: the 2007 film about Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger (played by Mark Wahlberg) who is framed for murder by a rogue secret private military company unit, and the TV series starring Ryan Phillippe as Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is drawn back into action after learning of a plot to kill the president.
