House, also known as House, M.D., is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

In 1971, Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people—Abigail Ann Folger, Wojciech Frykowski, Steven Earl Parent, Sharon Tate Polanski, Jay Sebring, and Leno and Rosemary La Bianca—carried out by members of the group at his instruction; he also received first-degree murder convictions for Gary Hinman and Donald “Shorty” Shea, and after he was charged, recordings of songs written and performed by him were released commercially.

Sean Justin Penn (born August 17, 1960) is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who began acting with a brief TV appearance in Little House on the Prairie (episode 112, December 4, 1974), directed by his father Leo Penn. After his film debut in Taps (1981) and roles including Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982), he earned critical attention with At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito’s Way (1993). He became a leading actor with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and the Berlin Film Festival Best Actor Award, followed by Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), and Academy Awards for Best Actor for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman, AC (27 August 1908–25 February 2001), known as “The Don,” was an Australian cricketer widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time, who remained pre-eminent in the game for three decades after retiring by serving as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid has held top executive roles in the music industry, serving as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a division of Sony Music Entertainment), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07). He began his career with Greta in 1990, helped co-found Rage with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991, and as of 2016 plays in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Separately, Rage is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter “Peavy” Wagner.

The Millers is a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, totaling 34 episodes over two seasons; CBS announced its cancellation on November 14, 2014, four episodes into the second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (September 1, 1933–September 13, 2006) was an American Democrat who served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995; previously the state treasurer, she gained national prominence after delivering the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, was the second female governor of Texas, noted for outspoken feminism and one-liners, and lost her 1994 re-election to George W. Bush. A different Ann Richards (October 1, 1935–April 1, 1982) was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
In 2011, Drake Bell independently released an EP titled A Reminder.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh (born Jeanette Helen Morrison; July 6, 1927–October 3, 2004) was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios (24 July 1783–17 December 1830), known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a leading role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states independent of Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, or Devil’s Triangle, is a loosely defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships are said to have disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup to Alex Smith and became the San Francisco 49ers’ starting quarterback in 2012 after Smith’s concussion, leading the team to its first Super Bowl since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens; in 2013, his first full season as starter, he guided the 49ers to the NFC Championship Game, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is an audio or visual marketing communication that uses an openly sponsored, nonpersonal message to promote or sell products, services, or ideas. Unlike personal selling, it is not directed to a particular individual. It is delivered through mass media, including old media (newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, direct mail) and new media (search results, blogs, websites, text messages).
Private Lives is a 1930 three-act comedy of manners by Noël Coward and a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (10 February 1894–29 December 1986), was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist from Stagira in Chalkidice on the northern edge of Classical Greece. He joined Plato’s Academy in Athens at age 17 or 18 and remained there until about age 37 (c. 347 BC). After Plato’s death, he left Athens and, at the request of Philip II of Macedon, began tutoring Alexander the Great in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz ([pækhaʊs]; born February 16, 1982) is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur who invented the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and is currently the CEO of music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons; after winning championships in high school and college, he was the first overall pick in the 1979 NBA draft, won a championship and NBA Finals MVP as a rookie, and added four more championships in the 1980s. After protests from fellow players, he retired again for four years, returned in 1996 at age 36 to play 32 games for the Lakers, then retired for the third and final time. He has numerous business interests, was named by Ebony magazine in 2009 as one of America’s most influential black businessmen, and was a part-owner of the Lakers for several years.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, consisting of lead vocalist/guitarist Jack Black and lead guitarist/vocalist Kyle Gass. They have released three albums: Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012). The band first gained popularity in 1997 by starring in their eponymous television series and supporting large rock acts.

James VI and I (James Stuart) (19 June 1566–27 March 1625) ruled Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603 until his death, governing Scotland and England as separate sovereign states under a personal union. A strong proponent of a single parliament for both kingdoms, he achieved most of his aims in Scotland but encountered major difficulties in England, including the 1605 Gunpowder Plot and repeated conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017 (Big Brother 18) is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality show, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Marcus Morgan Bentley (born 4 October 1967) is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist best known for narrating the UK version of Big Brother since 2000; he also did continuity announcements for Channel 4 until leaving in July 2011 to continue narrating the revived series on Channel 5, with his Geordie accent making him one of Britain’s most recognized voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked German federal state bordering Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland (Lower Silesian and Lubusz Voivodeships), and the Czech Republic (Karlovy Vary, Liberec, and Ústí nad Labem Regions). It is Germany’s 10th largest state (18,413 km²) and 6th most populous (about 4 million), with a history spanning more than a millennium in the middle of a formerly all German‑speaking part of Europe. Saxony also contains the Sachsen quality wine region, which, together with Saale‑Unstrut, is among Europe’s northernmost wine regions and is one of only two of Germany’s 13 wine regions located in the former East Germany.
East End Park was a former major league baseball park in the East End neighborhood of Cincinnati, United States, and “In the End” is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B . Brown began her solo career by releasing the single “I Want You Back” with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra (Pawn) is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah, with Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar in support. Released on 1 July 1994, it became the second highest-grossing Indian film of the year and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Divya Bharti was originally cast for the female lead and had shot many scenes before her death, after which Raveena Tandon replaced her, and the film is also remembered for its chartbuster songs.
The passage states that “Hourglass” is both a song by British electronic duo Disclosure and the title of singer-songwriter James Taylor’s fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black (born December 16, 1961) is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor best known for writing the 1987 hit action film Lethal Weapon and making his directorial debut with Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond spy film and the seventh and final one to star Roger Moore as the fictional MI6 agent James Bond.
Papua is Indonesia’s largest and easternmost province, covering most of western New Guinea; formerly called Irian Jaya (earlier West Irian or Irian Barat), it comprised all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, though unconfirmed rumors suggested his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez entered music in 1999 with her debut album On the 6, led by the number-one single “If You Had My Love”; in 2001, releasing her second album J.Lo alongside the film The Wedding Planner made her the first woman to have a number one album and film in the same week. After her second divorce, her high-profile relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her third album, This Is Me... Then (2002), while Gigli (2003) was a critical and commercial failure. She later married Marc Anthony and rebounded with the box office successes Shall We Dance ?, gave birth to twins in 2008, and, after a relatively unsuccessful period, returned to prominence in 2011 with her role as an American Idol judge and her most commercially successful single to date, “On the Floor,” one of the best-selling singles of all time.

A working animal is a usually domesticated animal trained by humans to perform tasks, including assistance roles like guide dogs, providing tractive force such as draft horses or logging elephants, and jobs like milking or herding that require human training for cooperation; while wild animals can sometimes be tamed and trained, this is rare and typically for novelty or entertainment because they often lack the trustworthiness and mild temperament of true domesticated working animals.

The passage mentions Billboard Dad, a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, and describes two Billboard magazine record charts: Top Latin Albums, regarded as the most important U.S. chart for Spanish-language full-length albums, and Regional Mexican Albums, a weekly genre-specific chart in the United States.

Vedam (English: Chant) is a 2010 Telugu-language Indian drama film written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, featuring an ensemble cast including Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

Men in Black II (stylized as MIIB) is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character in Don Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra’s 1605 novel Don Quixote, serving as Don Quixote’s squire and delivering “sanchismos,” comments that mix broad humor, ironic Spanish proverbs, and earthy wit.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role and directed by Ron Underwood.
Hedda Gabler premiered on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich, with Henrik Ibsen in attendance.
Brazzers (pronounced [ˈbræzərz]) is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A., commonly known as Juve, is a professional Italian football club based in Turin, Piedmont, founded in 1897 by young Torinese students including first president Eugenio Canfari and his brother Enrico. The club’s name derives from the Latin “iuventūs” (“youth”). It is the second-oldest active club in Italy after Genoa’s football section (1893), has worn a black-and-white striped home kit since 1903, and currently plays home matches at the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium after having used several venues over its history.

In the late 1990s and early 2000s, Viola Davis appeared in supporting and minor roles in films and television, including the films Kate & Leopold (2001) and Far from Heaven (2002), and the TV series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress, widely regarded as the world’s most famous adult entertainment performer and “The Queen of Porn.” She began acting in erotic videos in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamour model.
The passage identifies the New Orleans Pelicans as a National Basketball Association team that competes in the league’s Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, initially broadcast via closed-circuit television and later via pay-per-view, produced by the National Wrestling Alliance and later World Championship Wrestling. Jim Crockett Promotions traditionally held major holiday shows on Thanksgiving and Christmas from the 1960s to the 1980s, mostly at Greensboro Coliseum. In this series, Starrcade (1985) was the third annual event under JCP/NWA, Starrcade (1987) was the fifth, and Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual pay-per-view.

Jack Ryan Falahee (born February 20, 1989) is an American actor best known for portraying Connor Walsh on ABC’s legal drama How to Get Away with Murder and Benjamin Stringfellow on PBS’s historical drama Mercy Street.

Don’t Say No is the debut mini album (extended play) by South Korean singer and actress Seohyun (Seo Ju-hyun, born June 28, 1991). She debuted in August 2007 as a member of Girls’ Generation and later its subgroup TTS, a group that became one of the best-selling artists in South Korea and one of South Korea’s most popular girl groups worldwide. Beyond group activities, she established herself as an actress through stage musicals including Moon Embracing the Sun, Gone with the Wind, and Mamma Mia. She made her solo debut with Don’t Say No on January 17, 2017, becoming the third Girls’ Generation member to debut as a solo artist.

The Apple II is an 8-bit home computer, among the first highly successful mass-produced microcomputers, designed primarily by Steve Wozniak, with Steve Jobs overseeing its foam-molded plastic case and Rod Holt developing its switching power supply. The Apple II series—trademarked as “Apple ][” and later rendered “Apple //”—is a family of home computers, also among the first highly successful mass-produced text command microcomputer products, manufactured by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.) and introduced in 1977 with the original Apple II. Stephen (or Stephan) Gary Wozniak, born August 11, 1950 and nicknamed “Woz,” is an American inventor, electronics engineer, programmer, philanthropist, and technology entrepreneur who co-founded Apple Inc.

A&E, formerly Arts & Entertainment Network, is an American cable and satellite television channel that serves as the flagship of A&E Networks, a joint venture between the Hearst Corporation and Disney–ABC Television Group (a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company), with each owning 50%.

L.A. Reid is a music executive who has held top leadership roles, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a division of Sony Music Entertainment), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group; he also founded and led Hitco Music Publishing and co-founded LaFace Records.
Veeram (Valour) refers to two films: a 2014 Indian Tamil action movie directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and a 2016 Indian epic historical drama written and directed by Jayaraj.

The passage describes two films titled Home for the Holidays: a 1972 American made-for-television horror film directed by John Llewellyn Moxey, produced by Aaron Spelling, starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan, which premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972; and a 1995 film starring Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Hourie Killam, born April 1, 1982, is an American actor, comedian, and writer.
The Sex Factor is an online reality TV series produced by xHamster in which eight men and eight women compete to become porn stars.
John Hovig Dolmayan, born July 15, 1973, is a Lebanese-born Armenian-American songwriter and drummer.
Island Records is a British-American record label that functions as a division of Universal Music Group (UMG).
Sikkim is a northeastern state of India, pronounced [ˈsɪkᵻm].
In 1983, Christa McAuliffe took a position as a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire.
Ronald Bilius "Ron" Weasley is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
Reign Over Me is a 2007 American drama film written and directed by Mike Binder, produced by his brother Jack Binder, distributed by Columbia Pictures, and released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Rand Kaepernick, born November 3, 1987, is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent.

In 2016, Sheryl Lee appeared in Café Society and completed the Showtime revival of Twin Peaks (2017), reprising her role as Laura Palmer, while Sheryl Lee Ralph played Madame Morrible in Wicked on Broadway.
Matteo Renzi, born on 11 January 1975, is an Italian politician who served as the Prime Minister of Italy from February 2014 to December 2016.
The Road to El Dorado is a film starring Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell, and Rosie Perez.

“Same Old Love” is a song by American singer Selena Gomez from her second studio album, Revival (2015), which debuted at number one on the Billboard 200; the album’s first three singles—“Good for You,” “Same Old Love,” and “Hands to Myself”—all topped the Mainstream Top 40 chart in the United States.
Weekly Idol is a show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal is a rock music genre that developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s, primarily in the United Kingdom and the United States; in the late 1970s, bands from the new wave of British heavy metal, such as Iron Maiden and Saxon, followed in a similar vein.
Ashton Kutcher later appeared in several romantic comedies, including Guess Who (2005), A Lot Like Love (2005), What Happens in Vegas (2008), and No Strings Attached (2011).

Topman is a UK high-street men’s clothing chain owned by the Arcadia Group, which also owns Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins, with stores on nearly every UK High Street and main street outlets in six cities and towns in Ireland.

During the early Industrial Revolution, Wales shifted from an agricultural society to an industrial nation due to the growth of mining and metallurgical industries, with exploitation of the South Wales Coalfield driving rapid population expansion.
Tool is a band that has won three Grammy Awards, toured worldwide, and released albums that topped charts in several countries.
YouTube is an American video-sharing website headquartered in San Bruno, California, and is ranked as the second most popular site in the world by Alexa Internet, a web traffic analysis company.
Sidse Babett Knudsen, born 22 November 1968, is a Danish actress who works in theatre, television, and film.
Conrad Dunn began his screen career as Francis “Psycho” Soyer in the 1981 film Stripes, which also provided the first significant film roles for John Larroquette, John Diehl, and Judge Reinhold.
Raees is a film starring Shah Rukh Khan, Mahira Khan, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui.
Asylum Records is an American record label founded in 1971 by David Geffen and partner Elliot Roberts.
Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

The Armenian Genocide (Hayots tseghaspanutyun), also known as the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government’s systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, mostly Ottoman citizens, within the Ottoman Empire and its successor state, the Republic of Turkey. Other indigenous and Christian ethnic groups, such as the Assyrians and Ottoman Greeks, were similarly targeted for extermination in the Assyrian and Greek genocides, which some historians view as part of the same genocidal policy.
Marcus Morgan Bentley, born on 4 October 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist.

William Jefferson Clinton, born August 19, 1946, is an American politician who served as the 42nd U.S. President from 1993 to 2001; his first inauguration took place on January 20, 1993, on the West Front of the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle (born 20 October 1956) is an English director, producer, screenwriter, and theatre director known for films including Shallow Grave, Trainspotting, The Beach, 28 Days Later, Sunshine, Slumdog Millionaire, 127 Hours, and Steve Jobs. The Beach is a 2000 adventure drama he directed, based on Alex Garland’s 1996 novel, with the film adaptation by John Hodge.
In the first week after the dress image surfaced, it generated over 10 million tweets, with hashtags including #thedress, #whiteandgold, and #blackandblue.
Major Bruce Middleton Hope Shand, MC and bar (22 January 1917–11 June 2006), was an officer in the British Army.
Advertising is an openly sponsored, nonpersonal audio or visual marketing communication used to promote or sell a product, service, or idea.

The Others (2001) won eight Goya Awards, including Best Film and Best Director, becoming the first English-language film without any Spanish dialogue to win the Goyas’ (Spain’s national film awards) Best Film. It received six Saturn Award nominations—including Best Director and Best Writing for Amenábar and Best Performance by a Younger Actor for Alakina Mann—and won three: Best Horror Film, Best Actress for Kidman, and Best Supporting Actress for Fionnula Flanagan.
Ralph Fults (January 23, 1911–March 16, 1993) was a Depression-era outlaw and escape artist associated with Raymond Hamilton, Bonnie Parker, and Clyde Barrow of the Barrow Gang.

The 14th Dalai Lama, religious name Tenzin Gyatso and born Lhamo Thondup on 6 July 1935, is the current Dalai Lama. He was born in Taktser village, Amdo, Tibet (then administratively in Qinghai province, Republic of China), selected as the tulku of the 13th Dalai Lama in 1937, and formally recognized as the 14th Dalai Lama at a public declaration near Bumchen in 1939. During the 1959 Tibetan uprising, he fled to India, where he now lives as a refugee.

Miracle at St. Anna is a World War II story set mainly in German-occupied Italy, following four Buffalo Soldiers of the 92nd Infantry Division who seek refuge in a small Tuscan village and form bonds with its residents; the narrative is told as a flashback framed by one survivor’s reflections in 1980s New York.
Caroline Bouvier Kennedy, born November 27, 1957, is an American author, attorney, and diplomat who served as the U.S. Ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017.

The Armenian Genocide, also known as the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government’s systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians—mostly Ottoman citizens—carried out within the Ottoman Empire and its successor state, the Republic of Turkey; Turkey, as the Ottoman Empire’s successor, denies that “genocide” accurately characterizes the mass killings, which began under Ottoman rule in 1915.

Muslims believe the Quran is God’s verbal revelation to Muhammad through the angel Gabriel (Jibril), delivered gradually over about 23 years—from December 22, 609 CE, when Muhammad was 40, until 632 CE, the year of his death.

The human brain, together with the spinal cord, forms the central nervous system and comprises the cerebrum, brainstem, and cerebellum, with the cerebrum being the largest part. Beneath the cerebral cortex lie key structures: the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, subthalamus; limbic structures including the amygdala and hippocampus; the claustrum; various nuclei of the basal ganglia; basal forebrain structures; and the three circumventricular organs.

AMGTV is an American family-oriented television network offering a wide range of programming, including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how-to content, hunting and fishing, children’s shows, and other features.

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman AC (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001) was an Australian cricketer widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time; even after becoming reclusive in later years, his opinion remained highly sought and his status as a national icon endured—so much so that in 2001, more than 50 years after his Test retirement, Australian Prime Minister John Howard called him the “greatest living Australian.”

Margaret Hilda Thatcher, Baroness Thatcher (13 October 1925–8 April 2013), was a British stateswoman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990 and as Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990. In 1975, Thatcher defeated Heath in the Conservative Party leadership election to become Leader of the Opposition, becoming the first woman to lead a major political party in the United Kingdom.

EA Black Box, formerly Black Box Games, was a video game developer based in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada, founded in 1998 by former Radical Entertainment employees and later acquired by Electronic Arts (EA).

It adds that the area near Naples contains many culturally and historically significant sites, including the Palace of Caserta and the Roman ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum, and observes that famous ruins exist worldwide, from China, the Indus valley, and Judea to Zimbabwe in Africa, ancient Greek, Egyptian, and Roman sites in the Mediterranean, and Incan and Mayan sites in the Americas.

Call in the TV mini-series Lonesome Dove, Agent K in the Men in Black film series, the villain Two-Face in Batman Forever, terrorist William Strannix in Under Siege, a Texas Ranger in Man of the House, rancher Pete Perkins in The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (which he directed), Colonel Chester Phillips in Captain America: The First Avenger, CIA Director Robert Dewey in Jason Bourne, and Warden Dwight McClusky in Natural Born Killers.

Palo Alto is a charter city in the northwest corner of Santa Clara County, California, within the San Francisco Bay Area of the United States; its name comes from Spanish, with palo meaning “stick” or colloquially “tree” and alto meaning “tall,” together meaning “tall tree.”

Morse code is a simple, versatile method of transmitting text as on-off tones, lights, or clicks that skilled listeners or observers can understand without special equipment. To speed communication, character lengths are designed roughly inversely to their frequency in English. It is more robust than voice under poor signal conditions while remaining human-comprehensible without a decoder. Many amateur radio repeaters identify using Morse even when carrying voice, and in emergencies it can be improvised with any easily keyed on–off method.
Alexandra Anna Daddario, born March 16, 1986, is an American actress.

On December 12, 2005 at 21:47 UTC, a magnitude 6.5 earthquake struck northeastern Afghanistan. The Hindu Kush is an 800 km mountain range near the Afghan–Pakistan border, stretching from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan; known in Ancient Greek as the Caucasus Indicus or Paropamisadae, it has numerous high snow-capped peaks, with its highest point being Tirich Mir (Terichmir) at 7708 m in the Chitral District of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan.
As of 2015, Ripon College in Wisconsin had about 840 students, with most living on campus.

Fox Sports is a global brand for sports channels, broadcast divisions, programming, and other media that are controlled or partially owned by Rupert Murdoch’s family. Tatum O'Neal married professional tennis player John McEnroe in 1986, and they had three children together.

Sean Penn is an actor who debuted in Taps (1981), gained attention with Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982), and earned critical acclaim in At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito’s Way (1993). Volcanic outgassing likely produced Earth’s primordial atmosphere and then the ocean, but this early atmosphere had almost no oxygen and would be toxic to most modern life. As Earth cooled, a solid crust formed, allowing liquid water to exist at the surface. Ongoing plate tectonics continues to shape the oceans and continents and the species they harbor. Changes in the biosphere—now dominated by human activity—significantly affect the atmosphere and other surface systems, including the integrity of the ozone layer, greenhouse gas levels, and the conditions of productive soils and clean air and water. Water covers 71% of Earth’s surface.
Nuuk (pronounced [nuːk], also known as Godthåb) is the capital and largest city of Greenland and the municipality of Sermersooq.

Miller, and Kristen Wiig—along with new additions Cate Blanchett, Djimon Hounsou, and Kit Harington; Blanchett voices Valka and Hounsou voices Drago.

Martin Van Buren (1782–1862), also Maarten van Buren, was a Democratic American politician who served as the eighth President of the United States (1837–41), after serving under Andrew Jackson as the tenth Secretary of State (1829–31) and the eighth Vice President (1833–37). A major organizer for Jackson’s 1828 campaign, he ran for and briefly served as Governor of New York to boost Jackson’s prospects, resigned after two months to become Secretary of State, and in 1831, after resigning that post—which aided Jackson in resolving the Petticoat affair—received a recess appointment as American minister to Britain.

Michigan is a U.S. state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions, the 10th most populous and 11th largest by total area (the largest east of the Mississippi River). In the 1930s, Penguin Books revolutionized publishing by selling inexpensive sixpence paperbacks through Woolworths and other high street stores, making high-quality fiction and non-fiction widely accessible to the mass market.

Human trafficking is the trade of people for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization estimates that as of 2014, forced labor alone generates about $150 billion in annual profits, with roughly 20.9 million victims: 14.2 million (68%) exploited for labor, 4.5 million (22%) sexually exploited, and 2.2 million (10%) subjected to state-imposed forced labor.

The passage distinguishes two figures named Francis I: Franz Stefan (François Étienne, 1708–1765), Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, whose wife effectively wielded the real power; and François Ier (1494–1547), the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois, reigning from 1515 until his death. The French king, known as “Francis of the Large Nose,” the Grand Colas, and the “Knight-King,” personally fought wars against his rival Charles V, King of Spain and Holy Roman Emperor; when unsuccessful, he formed a controversial Franco-Ottoman alliance with Suleiman the Magnificent. The Italian War of 1536–1538 was a conflict between Francis I of France and Charles V.

Peking University (PKU; colloquially Beida, 北京大学, pinyin: Beijing Daxue) is a major Chinese research university in Beijing and a member of the C9 League. Founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking to replace the Taixue/Guozijian (Imperial Academy), it was China’s first modern national university and initially served as the country’s highest education administration (ministry of education). It is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for his appearance—especially his friendly mutton chops—along with his distinctive gravelly voice and unique bass playing style.

Kentucky, nicknamed the “Bluegrass State” due to bluegrass pastures nurtured by fertile soil, includes the central Bluegrass Region that contains Louisville and Lexington, and is known for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the NWA and later WCW, originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and, from 1987, via pay-per-view, making it the first NWA event on PPV. A floppy disk—also called a floppy, diskette, or disk—is a disk storage medium consisting of a thin, flexible magnetic disk sealed in a rectangular plastic enclosure (carrier) lined with fabric that removes dust particles.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife in the mid to late 19th century, and from 1960 to 1996 it underwent a bloody civil war between a US-backed government and leftist rebels, during which the military carried out genocidal massacres of the Maya population.

Matthew David McConaughey (born November 4, 1969) is an American actor who since 2011 has preferred dramatic roles, appearing in The Lincoln Lawyer (2011), Bernie (2011), Killer Joe (2011), The Paperboy (2012), Mud (2012), Magic Mike (2012), The Wolf of Wall Street (2013), Dallas Buyers Club (2013), Interstellar (2014), The Sea of Trees (2016), and Free State of Jones (2016); Mud stars McConaughey, Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer is a writer best known for his book Deep Blues, his music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone, his production work on blues recordings and the soundtrack for the film Deep Blues, and his clarinet playing in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (April 9, 1912–January 27, 1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, Gutzon Borglum—who designed the monument and directed its construction from 1927 to March 1941 with Lincoln’s help—died, at which point Lincoln took over as leader of the project.

The Concert for Bangladesh, despite later financial problems due to its pioneering nature, is recognized as a highly successful and influential humanitarian aid project that generated significant awareness and funds, and offered valuable lessons and inspiration for subsequent efforts, notably Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is cited by the media as one of India’s influential filmmakers, widely credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and altering the profile of Indian cinema.

Stephen A. Douglas articulated the Freeport Doctrine at the second Lincoln–Douglas debate on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. The Lincoln–Douglas Debates, also known as the Great Debates of 1858, were seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic candidate. The debates in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton drew especially large crowds from neighboring states, reflecting the nationwide importance of the slavery issue.

Easy A (stylized as easy A) is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice (born Howard Allen Frances O’Brien, October 4, 1941) is an American author of gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She launched her career with Interview with the Vampire in 1976 while living in California and began writing sequels in the 1980s; though initial reactions were mixed, she gained wider critical and popular acclaim during that decade. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years, from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002 at age 60.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a 2010 U.S. Census population of 77,344, ranking as the 12th most populous municipality in the state; at the start of the 20th century its population was mostly European immigrants, and a city is a large, permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for The Canyons, a 2013 American erotic thriller-drama that is an original work, directed by Paul Schrader; the film was critically derided.

The Lincoln–Douglas Debates, also called The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates in Illinois between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for U.S. Senate, and Stephen Douglas, the incumbent Democratic senator, held across seven towns in the state.

The passage states that Homer is the name ancient Greeks gave to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two epic poems central to ancient Greek literature, and that The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel by American author Joe R. Lansdale.

Christopher Scott Kyle (April 8, 1974 – February 2, 2013) was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas, on February 2, 2013.

Audioslave was a four-piece band featuring Soundgarden’s Chris Cornell (lead singer/rhythm guitar) alongside Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass/backing vocals), and Brad Wilk (drums). Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07); he began with Greta in 1990, co-founded Rage with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991, and as of 2016 played in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine formed in 1991 with Zack de la Rocha (rapper/vocalist), Tim Commerford (bass/backing vocals), Tom Morello (guitar), and Brad Wilk (drums).

Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to her own imprint Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records; in 2010, she released her critically acclaimed first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid—a concept album sequel to her first EP—through Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a 1983 novel by Mark Helprin.

Lake Providence is a town and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. At the University of Mississippi, about 55% of undergraduates and 60% of students overall are from Mississippi; 23% are minorities, and international students come from 90 nations.
The series Flaked was renewed in July 2016 for a six-episode second season, scheduled to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served twice in the New York State Assembly (1784–1785, 1798–1799), was New York State Attorney General (1789–1791), served as a U.S. senator from New York (1791–1797), and reached the apex of his career as vice president.

The Soyuz rocket was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft for the Soviet human spaceflight program, starting with eight unmanned test flights followed by the first 19 manned launches. “Soyuz” (“Union,” as in “Soviet Union”) refers to a series of spacecraft designed in the 1960s by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia), which succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft, was originally built for the Soviet manned lunar programs, and remains in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine faced growing tensions that led de la Rocha to quit and the band to break up; de la Rocha began a low-key solo career while the other members formed the rock supergroup Audioslave with Chris Cornell, then-former frontman of Soundgarden, which released three albums before disbanding in 2007. The same year, Rage Against the Machine announced a reunion and performed together for the first time in seven years at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in April 2007. Renegades is the band’s fourth studio album, released on December 5, 2000, by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX (also called the BSE 30 or SENSEX) is a free-float market-weighted index of 30 well-established, financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange, the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange, and is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia, with about 92.7 million people, making it the world’s 14th most populous and the ninth-most populous in Asia. It borders China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, Vietnam’s economic growth rate has been among the highest globally, and in 2011 it had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. It remains one of the world’s four one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins, marking his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh, executed at age 23 on 23 March 1931, was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary whose two acts of dramatic violence against the British in India and subsequent execution made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement, and he became a popular folk hero after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in Aamir Khan’s Dangal, a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama about wrestling directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I (James Stuart, 19 June 1566–27 March 1625) ruled Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and England and Ireland as James I from the union of the crowns on 24 March 1603 until his death. Although he governed both realms in a personal union, Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws. He strongly advocated creating a single parliament for England and Scotland but faced many difficulties with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand stage and screen actress known as an original core cast member of Shortland Street and for roles including Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, and Shota in Legend of the Seeker. Her other works include the film Separation City (2009), the Australian series Rake, and portraying Sydney underworld figure Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor. Her most notable recent role was Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, which she led for four years before leaving in 2016.
Born October 11, 1979, Rob Sheridan is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred or co-starred in films including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2; Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop received mixed reviews but achieved commercial success, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week sales, becoming Gaga’s second consecutive US number-one record, selling 757,000 copies, and ranking as the ninth best-selling album of 2013 with 2.3 million copies worldwide.
In 2006, Stadium Arcadium was released as John Frusciante’s fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers; it was the group’s last to feature him, and he confirmed his departure in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism; though always controversial, she is hailed as one of the greatest and most influential politicians in British history, even as debates over Thatcherism persist.

Michael Andrew “Duff” McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author who has also built a career as a writer, contributing weekly columns on diverse topics to SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, beyond his acting roles, has also worked as a narrator for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of the Valencian Community (also known as the Valencian Country), an autonomous community of Spain. It is the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with about 800,000 inhabitants in the administrative center, and its metropolitan area—also Spain’s third largest—has a population between 1.7 and 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers is a character portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film adaptation and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
Make It or Break It concluded with its third and final season, with the end of the series announced on April 26, 2012, and the series finale airing on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methods and technologies to recognize and translate spoken language into text, drawing on linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice user interfaces (voice dialing, call routing), domotic appliance control, search for spoken content, simple data entry, preparation of structured documents, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft Direct Voice Input. Advances are evidenced by increased academic publications and widespread industry adoption of deep learning, with companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC publicly citing deep learning as core to their systems.

Richard Alf (January 26, 1952–January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman beginning in 1970; the convention was founded in 1970 as the Golden State Comic Book Convention by Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and was later called the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee in the lead role.

France’s Dubuisson shot 67 to tie overnight leader Van Zyl of South Africa at 16 under, while Rory McIlroy recorded a third straight five-under 67 to reach 15 under alongside Thailand’s Kiradech Aphibarnrat; Englishmen Chris Wood (-13) and Richard Bland (-12), tied second overnight, slipped to fifth and seventh. McIlroy, the world number three, mixed rare three-putt bogeys at the third and 10th—after the latter he threw his putter at his bag—with a birdie at 11 and an eagle, and says a lower round is possible as he seeks his first win since May. After rupturing a left ankle ligament in July, he returned for the US PGA, played three FedEx Cup play-off events, and began the new PGA Tour season with a tie for 26th at the Frys.com Open; he is targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years and leads Danny Willett by 271,214 points with three events remaining after the Turkish Open.

Al-Wefaq leader Sheikh Ali Salman said meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain requires the government to offer concrete solutions and include someone speaking for the royal family, citing reformist Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa amid a court split with hardliners around the unelected prime minister, Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, who oppose the newly agreed talks with six opposition societies and fear concessions will spur more demands from distrusted leaders. He welcomed dialogue as necessary but noted many young protesters have lost faith, rejecting permits for demonstrations and doubting a constitutional monarchy under a family they say is still killing people. Urging engagement with reformists within the Sunni royal family, including the US- and UK-educated crown prince seen as favoring accommodation with the Shia majority, he recalled that just hours before GCC troops entered on 14 March 2011, the crown prince and opposition had agreed a seven-point plan toward a constitutional monarchy, after which the intervention severed talks. On the appointment of John Kerry as US Secretary of State, he expressed hope for clearer, more direct US pressure for human rights and democracy than under Hillary Clinton, and he criticized the UK for relying on private urging rather than public pressure. Despite a ban on public gatherings, al-Wefaq will continue calling for peaceful demonstrations as the only way to pressure the government. He also demanded the release of 13 opposition leaders and activists, convicted of plotting to overthrow the government on evidence widely accepted as obtained under torture, warning that excluding them would cause the dialogue to fail.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after a months-long illness; his funeral will be private with a memorial service to follow. A leading figure in the early-music movement, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973 and directed it across six continents for about 30 years, overseeing more than 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments; his 1980 Handel’s Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson was later named by BBC Music Magazine among the top 20 recordings of all time. He studied keyboard at Cambridge with Rafael Puyana and Mary Potts and later with Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt, began as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields under Sir Neville Marriner, and was a founding member of the Early Music Consort of London. He served as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society and held academic posts at Harvard, the University of Cambridge, and Cornell. Tributes from Christopher Purvis, Richard Egarr, Dame Emma Kirkby, and David Thomas praised his generosity, scholarship, influence on historically informed performance, and enduring legacy.

In Scotland, 57 homicide victims were recorded in the year to the end of March 2016, five fewer than the previous year, marking the lowest 12-month total since 1976 and half the figure of nine years ago; only one case from 2015–16 remained unresolved as of 31 March 2016. Sharp instruments were the most common method, accounting for 51% (29 cases), with 26 involving knives. Although most accused had unknown alcohol/drug status, 31% (20 people) were identified as under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the decline but stressed ongoing education, enforcement, cross-service support for at-risk communities, tackling alcohol misuse and “casual” violence, investing in projects for young people, and ensuring police and courts have adequate powers and resources. Scottish Labour’s Claire Baker urged caution, noting that 2014–15 homicides were revised from 59 to 62 after three reclassifications, and highlighting sexual crime at a 45-year high and a 27% rise in attempted murder and serious assault.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 at Sunderland, becoming the first Premier League side beaten by the Black Cats this season; Dan Gosling put the Cherries ahead with their first goal in three games, but Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty turned it around, and Bournemouth couldn’t equalise even after Steven Pienaar’s red card. Manager Eddie Howe told BBC Radio Solent the issue isn’t confidence—citing six goals against Hull recently—and lamented that despite creating enough chances to “win three games,” they failed to score, stressing the need to accept it and move on.

Mr Abbott defended Australia’s policy of detaining any migrants arriving by boat and sending them to offshore processing camps for eventual resettlement elsewhere, arguing the only way to prevent drownings is to “stop the boats.” A New York Times editorial condemned the “ruthlessly effective” policy as “brutal,” inhumane, of dubious legality, and at odds with the country’s tradition of welcoming people fleeing persecution and war, calling it unconscionable for Europe to adopt similar measures as Abbott had suggested; Australia had not responded to the editorial, though Abbott called the image of Syrian three-year-old Alan Kurdi “very sad” and reiterated his stance. He also angered Australian Jewish groups by saying Islamic State was worse than the Nazis, a comparison Robert Goot of the Executive Council of Australian Jewry called injudicious, citing state-implemented genocide and purpose-built death camps. Abbott later said he stood by his comments but was not “in the business of ranking evil.”

The United States suspended bilateral channels with Russia intended to sustain Syria’s ceasefire, accusing Moscow and the Assad government of intensifying attacks on civilians in Aleppo, targeting hospitals, and blocking aid—including the 19 September strike on a humanitarian convoy—after a week-long truce lapsed. Washington had warned it would halt talks unless Russia stopped bombing Aleppo, where heavy bombardment resumed, hundreds have been killed, the main trauma hospital in rebel-held east was hit for the third time in a week, and about 250,000 people are trapped. Russia denied its or Syria’s planes hit the convoy, blaming ground fire, and said the US failed to fulfill humanitarian obligations, separate jihadists from moderate rebels, and was shifting blame for the truce’s collapse. Planned coordination of strikes against jihadist groups in Geneva was called off, US personnel for a proposed Joint Implementation Center were withdrawn, though both sides will continue counter-terrorism deconfliction talks to avoid clashes.

Downing Street backed Policy Exchange’s “Ending Expensive Social Tenancies” report, which proposes councils sell vacant high-value social homes (worth more than the regional average) to fund new building, claiming net receipts of about £4.5bn a year—enough for 80,000–170,000 homes—and potentially cutting the 1.8 million social housing waiting list by around 500,000. The think tank says 21.8% of UK social stock (816,000 of 3.78 million homes) is “expensive,” worth up to £159bn overall (over £70bn in London), with about 3.5% (28,500 homes) becoming vacant annually; it argues this would create the largest social housebuilding program since the 1970s and is popular (73% oppose council homes above local average values). No 10 says councils can already do this and should use stock efficiently, while critics—including Labour, the National Housing Federation, and MP Karen Buck—warn it would break up mixed communities and push low-income families from expensive areas; Labour instead proposes a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes, and ministers cite £19.5bn in public/private funding to deliver up to 170,000 homes plus reforms like fixed-term tenancies.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, was found dead at his Swansea flat the morning after visiting an out-of-hours GP on 17 April with a widespread rash; he had recently been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital. Swansea is at the centre of a measles outbreak with 942 cases since November and 83 hospital admissions. Laboratory tests confirmed he had measles, but an initial examination could not determine whether it was the main cause of death; an inquest will be opened and adjourned to allow further tests. His mother, Angela Colfer, said the family does not know how he contracted measles, and no close relatives have it, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter.

Cumbria Police say Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence on a boy under the age of 16, reported to have taken place in 2001, and is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates’ Court later.

Gateshead and Guiseley drew 1-1 in the National League, extending Neil Aspin’s promotion-chasing hosts’ unbeaten run to nine and Adam Lockwood’s side’s to five. Guiseley struck first on 15 minutes when a throw-in found James Hurst, who squared for Jake Lawlor to finish into an empty net; before the break, Gateshead’s Liam Hogan blocked Jordan Preston and Guiseley keeper Jonny Maxted saved from Wes York. The hosts started the second half strongly and leveled on 62 minutes after half-time substitute Derek Asamoah slipped, allowing Wes York to curl into the top-right corner from the edge of the box. Bookings: Simon Walton (Guiseley), Gus Mafuta (Gateshead). Subs included Asamoah for Kevan Hurst at half-time, Adam Boyes for Jake Cassidy, Michael Rankine for Jordan Preston, and Luke Hannant for Mafuta.

Bristol Sport Ltd, which owns the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity as an alternative to a new Ashton Vale stadium that is delayed by a town green application. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed at a Tuesday shareholder meeting that, following Bristol City Council’s November approval, the club will sign the section 106 agreement shortly, then wait six weeks for any judicial review; if none arises by March, redevelopment will start in May.

Cuadrilla suspended fracking after a 1.5-magnitude tremor—the second in two months—saying it will review British Geological Survey (BGS) data and consult authorities before deciding whether to resume, a process expected to take weeks. The BGS, which is monitoring the site, said the latest quake’s epicentre was within 2 km of the Preese Hall site at a depth of about 2 km, with waveforms very similar to a magnitude 2.3 event on 1 April near Poulton-le-Fylde, indicating a similar location and mechanism; it also noted that injecting pressurised fluids during shale gas operations can fracture rock and potentially trigger earthquakes. While fracking has been contentious in the US amid allegations of water contamination that can ignite tap water, the Commons energy select committee recently urged UK ministers to support it under tight regulation and good industry practice.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool busker from Woolton who has played in the city centre for over 30 years, denied three fraud charges but was found guilty of one for performing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign (HJC) banner on his bagpipes in April 2015; a jury at Liverpool Crown Court cleared him of the other two counts. Sgt Chris Gaynor said Carpenter gave the impression he was collecting for the HJC, while Carpenter argued he was simply busking and the banner was a tribute. HJC chairman Kenneth Derbyshire said he had permitted Carpenter to design and display a banner featuring the eternal flame and the word “justice,” but not to use it for fundraising. Carpenter said he was a familiar face at Anfield and known to the HJC as a busker. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town beat Queens Park Rangers 3-0 in the Championship: Grant Ward put them ahead, Luke Varney rolled in a second after keeper Alex Smithies miscued a clearance, and Tom Lawrence added a third after Cole Skuse’s long-range effort broke to him. QPR offered little, though Sandro headed a corner against the post, while Smithies made saves to prevent a heavier defeat as Ipswich, who had failed to score in seven of their previous ten league games, created numerous chances (including a Berra header wide and a Skuse volley saved). The result, in Ian Holloway’s second game in charge, continued Rangers’ poor away run, lifting Mick McCarthy’s side up four places to 14th and above QPR, who slipped to 15th; McCarthy praised Varney and Jonathan Douglas and noted Smithies’ costly error, while Holloway called the second goal a calamity, declined to blame his keeper alone, and demanded more mental toughness and solidity.

Wells, 23, impressed in last season’s T20 Blast with 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66, and he praised the club’s positive direction and the coaches’ elite-performance environment that motivates players to be involved.

Fifth-placed Reds beat third-placed Chinnor 29-12 for a second straight win, with Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey and Craig Williams praised for leading from the front and the front row/five making over 70 tackles. Churcher told BBC Cornwall the display was emotionally dogged rather than complete and said there’s still room for improvement, urging the team to build on the result. The Reds’ next eight games include seven against lower-ranked teams and a meeting with leaders Old Elthamians.

Police in India arrested 28-year-old Nazrul (Nazu), allegedly a Bangladeshi citizen, at a Kolkata railway station, accusing him of raping a 74-year-old nun during a 14 March attack in Ranaghat where money was stolen and the convent school ransacked. Identified from CCTV and said to have fled to Bangladesh, he was caught after a tip-off about his return by train. This is the sixth arrest in a case with eight identified suspects, two still untraced; the five previously arrested have named Nazrul as the rapist. In May, police also arrested Milon Sarkar, described as the gang’s leader, though his exact role remains unclear. The incident sparked nationwide outrage and street protests.

An interactive video (best viewed full screen and possibly incompatible with older browsers) features Robert Opie, founder of London’s Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, explaining why consumer purchases change, highlighting the impact of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports on what UK shoppers buy and what’s offered for sale. The video’s interactive elements also examine shifts in ownership and rankings of major UK brands. A non-interactive version and related resources are provided, including information on what China owns, tips on freezing food, an annual survey of the top 20 UK consumer brands, and details about the Museum of Brands.

Two phone scams a week apart targeted women in Sandyhills and Stranraer, with a 71-year-old and another victim losing money after callers posed as BT/BT technical support, cited internet problems, and gained remote access to their computers; the first incident occurred on 15 September and the second seven days later. PC Siobhan Pellett warned that scammers can easily access victims’ computers and take substantial sums, urging people to be extremely cautious with cold calls seeking remote access and to never share banking or account details by phone, noting that legitimate institutions do not ask for such information.

Duffy, 37, has left Swinton Lions to join third-placed Championship club Featherstone on a one-year deal and will lead them in Saturday’s final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers; chairman Mark Campbell praised his work at Swinton, where Duffy’s former assistant Stuart Littler takes over, and Duffy, also Scotland’s assistant coach, previously played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford during a 16-year career.

At 12:50 GMT on Sunday, a Porthcawl RNLI crew with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter responded to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve, where, according to crewman Chris Page, a rider was found unconscious on wet sand with head injuries and very cold; she was treated and flown to Cardiff’s University Hospital of Wales.

At the UN’s World Radiocommunication Conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries agreed to allocate radio spectrum for satellites to receive aircraft ADS-B transmissions—signals previously sent only to other aircraft and ground stations—enabling real-time global flight tracking and addressing a radar-based system that leaves about 70% of airspace uncovered. The move, prompted by the 2014 disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 with 239 people aboard, follows Malaysia’s call for real-time data solutions; debris later confirmed from MH370 was found on Reunion Island. The ITU hailed the rapid decision, and the ICAO set a November 2016 deadline for new tracking guidelines requiring aircraft to report positions at least every 15 minutes, with more frequent updates in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five in August 2002, has been found at 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland, Ohio. After the teen had problems applying for college, the FBI received a tip on 30 October and, working with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, confirmed his identity; his mother has been notified, AL.com reports. Bobby Hernandez, 53, long suspected at the time of the disappearance, was arrested and is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail on $250,000 bail, and is also charged with tampering with records in 2012 to obtain a driver’s licence. A missing persons database notes he said he was taking his son to pre-school in August 2002 but then fled.

A 2 March fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s Duncan Street site kept firefighters on scene for several days, reduced train services, and caused travel delays; the cause is undetermined. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste after the blaze and, following joint visits sparked by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) concerns raised in February about risks to residents, transport, and the environment, decided to revoke its environmental permit. Subject to any appeal, the revocation takes effect on 7 August, after which the company cannot operate from the site and must remove all waste; the firm has until 7 August to appeal. GMFRS had visited the premises nine times in the past year and said the site operators, Asset and Land Group, were broadly compliant with fire safety law; the company could not be contacted for comment.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed two bills tied to the Ukraine crisis, especially in Crimea where pro-Russian sentiment is strong and many residents—especially in Sevastopol, home of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet—hold Russian passports. One bill would let Russia accept a territory into the federation based on a local referendum or leaders’ plea, bypassing the current requirement for a treaty with the neighboring state, with backers arguing this is needed when a state is disintegrating; the context notes Russia’s post-2008 control over Abkhazia and South Ossetia after aiding separatists. The second bill would fast-track Russian citizenship for Ukrainians by waiving taxes, prior residence, proof of funds, and renunciation of Ukrainian citizenship, allowing applications at Russian missions before 1 August and granting citizenship in two months; its preamble says it supports the “fraternal” Russian-speaking Ukrainians facing a “brown threat.” The passport plan was announced in Sevastopol by party leader Sergei Mironov, and several Russian MPs, including prominent celebrities, traveled to Crimea.

McLaren, once an F1 powerhouse with 182 wins, 12 drivers’ titles and eight constructors’ crowns, now targets fourth-row starts and points despite fielding two world champions, including Fernando Alonso. Their decline began in 2013 when chassis design faltered; although they believe the current car is strong, Honda’s power unit is the weak link—far from the late-1980s McLaren-Honda era that won 15 of 16 races in 1988 with Senna and Prost and dominated for four years. After renewed success with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes in 1998–99 (their last constructors’ title was 1998), the team suffered major scandals: exclusion and a $100m fine in 2007 over Ferrari data despite scoring most points, and 2009’s “lie-gate,” which brought a Hamilton apology and Dave Ryan’s dismissal. Wins continued through 2012 (seven by Hamilton and Jenson Button), but only Hamilton’s 2008 drivers’ title interrupted a broader title drought, and victories have since dried up. McLaren’s history is cyclical—early titles with Emerson Fittipaldi (1974) and James Hunt (1976), a slump that led Marlboro to install Ron Dennis, who engineered mid-’80s domination, then stepped back in 2009 before returning after 2013 without the desired turnaround. Dennis insists McLaren will be the next to break Mercedes’ hegemony; Alonso rejoined in 2015 betting on the renewed Honda partnership, and team leaders say the car is among the best and Honda will soon deliver on the engine—but for now, their hopes rest on belief, with both the team’s reputation and Alonso’s late-career ambitions at stake.

Thomas “Tommy” Baker, 44, from Everton, was found with gunshot wounds to the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Old Swan, Liverpool, on 27 January and later died in hospital. Police said he had just left Phoenix Gym and was shot while getting into his car, with suspects believed to have waited outside for about an hour. Three Liverpool men—two aged 29 and one 32—have been arrested and remain in custody. Detectives are searching for a silver VW Polo that left the scene at speed via Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road and Queens Road, and are urging individuals seen on CCTV near the market to come forward.

The passage suggests five digital ways to keep Christmas spiritual: 1) Everyday Church Online, a UK-launched virtual church streaming recorded sermons with live chat to a global audience from 61 countries, featuring a Star Wars-themed Christmas series, “The Hope Awakens,” running all day; 2) Guardians of Ancora, a free fantasy game for 8–11-year-olds on Android, iPhone, and Kindle from Scripture Union, with 45,000 players in four months and Christmas quests about finding the birth of Jesus; 3) popular nativity videos, including Viral.de’s 2010 “The Digital Story of Nativity” (about six million views) told through social media, and the Churches Advertising Network’s “Christmas Starts with a Baby’s Giggle” (about 250,000 views), which a cinema seller rejected as “too religious”; 4) Next Manga’s app/e-book releases such as Manga Messiah (after distributing over three million books and nearly five million booklets), available in 33 languages with 25,000 Arabic copies sent to Syrian and Libyan refugees; and 5) churches’ use of Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to prompt brief spiritual reflection, with media voices noting that rather than condensing the Gospel, the goal is to spark higher-minded thoughts—and that Jesus, a great communicator, would likely be on Twitter.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is reviewing a proposal to take over 250 hectares of common land for a circuit, with backers including Blaenau Gwent council offering about 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts presented conflicting views on environmental impacts: Natural Resources Wales said it was difficult to conclude the replacement land was of equal value but did not oppose the development, while the developers’ ecology report claimed a net biodiversity gain through habitat enhancements, a claim disputed by Gwent Wildlife Trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend an outcome after the inquiry, with Welsh government ministers making the final decision.

Novaya Gazeta reported on 1 April that more than 100 people in Chechnya had been detained on suspicion of being homosexual and at least three killed, with detainees—including influential Muslim clerics close to Ramzan Kadyrov and two well-known TV presenters—tortured with electric shocks and beatings at a prison near Argun, 20km from Grozny; the Russian LGBT Network, in touch with victims, said the report was true, is helping people flee, accuses Russian authorities of ignoring the abuses, and plans to seek an International Criminal Court case if Russia fails to prosecute. Chechnya’s authoritarian leader Ramzan Kadyrov, loyal to President Vladimir Putin, denied the allegations as “lies,” and his spokesman claimed there are no gay people in Chechnya, where homophobia is rife. On 3 April Chechen Muslim clerics condemned the report as an insult to their faith and the dignity of Chechen men and adopted a resolution warning of “retribution,” which the mufti confirmed; Novaya Gazeta called it a call for reprisals against journalists and urged Russian authorities to protect them. The paper’s editor Dmitry Muratov vowed to keep investigating human rights abuses and sought dialogue with the mufti. The passage notes Chechens have been linked to the contract killings of Novaya Gazeta reporters Anna Politkovskaya and Natalia Estemirova, and that much remains unclear about those murders and the 2015 shooting of opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, who exposed corruption and organized crime in Chechnya.

Investing Solutions, a south London lettings agency operating across seven boroughs, and the charity Fresh Start Housing—both founded by Samir Patel and based in the same building—legally profit by placing single homeless men, mainly over 35, in shared houses and claiming housing benefit per tenant while paying landlords a lower rent; for over-35s, benefit rules allow private-room rates of up to £260 a week in those areas. On one property they claimed £2,114 a month for two tenants while the landlord received £1,150, an annual gross margin of about £11,568, and Wandsworth Council alone paid the agency over £2.1m in two years, making it one of the UK’s largest housing benefit recipients. Fresh Start says it refers clients to both private landlords and Investing Solutions and has housed 788 people (222 in the past year), while Patel insists the charity is independent and that most rent is passed to landlords. A tenant reported poor conditions (no heating or hot water, rats, damp), and Crisis called the charity–agent link “a new low”; councils say they have teams to ensure the private rented sector is safe, secure and affordable, and the government says local authorities must rigorously safeguard taxpayers’ money with investigations and inspections, while neither organization is alleged to have acted illegally.

Great Britain lost a well-contested final warm-up to the Netherlands after leading most of the first three quarters, despite 14 points from Andrew Lawrence and 13 from NBA guard Ben Gordon. GB led 35-24 before the Dutch edged ahead early in the third; Gordon then hit three straight threes to restore the lead, but a 10-0 Netherlands run to start the fourth made it 71-60, and they held on despite a late GB rally. Worthy De Jong led the Dutch with 18 points. Coach Joe Prunty, who used his strongest lineup before cutting the roster for a six-game EuroBasket qualifying campaign starting midweek in Hungary, said the team must compete on every play and admitted they “lost a little of our fire,” while praising Gordon—who joined the squad despite missing London 2012—for finding rhythm with a strong third-quarter stretch.

Conor McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use 8oz gloves for his 154 lb boxing match with Floyd Mayweather, prompting a public NAC debate on 16 August; NAC rules normally require 10oz gloves at 154 lbs, with 8oz only permitted between 135–147 lbs via waivers, and officials stressed fighter safety in any deviation. Mayweather had posted he would wear 8oz gloves but had not filed the waiver at that time. Despite criticism from figures like Oscar De La Hoya and Gennady Golovkin, the NAC sanctioned the bout after executive director Bob Bennett reviewed extensive information, citing McGregor flooring Nate Diaz three times, Diaz’s boxing credibility, McGregor’s “granite-like chin,” his being 12 years younger as well as taller and longer than Mayweather, and Mayweather’s lack of a clean knockout in 10 years. Bennett reviewed three videos of McGregor’s progress and said he is “good to go,” advising the hiring of Hall of Fame referee Joe Cortez, who later described a McGregor–Paulie Malignaggi spar as “out of control”; Malignaggi left camp after images showed him on the canvas. Lighter gloves offer less hand cushioning but can make punches more punishing, and the NAC will announce its glove-size decision after the hearing.
MODEL FAILED TO RETURN ANY OUTPUT

Rowling said supportive messages reminded her how many decent people there are after facing abusive Twitter attacks over her politics, stating her personal line had been crossed and that she would stand up to bullies; following her £1m donation to the Scottish independence No campaign (and a £1m Labour donation in 2008), she was called a traitor, blocked some users she believed were SNP supporters, but also engaged positively with courteous SNP backers, even joking she’d bring marshmallows when someone suggested burning her books; she added she felt no responsibility to hide such abuse to protect any party’s image, while the SNP won 56 of Scotland’s 59 seats and became the UK’s third-largest party.

A University of Edinburgh study tracking 4,300 youths since 1998, funded by the ESRC, Nuffield Foundation and Scottish government and published in Scottish Justice Matters, found that poverty strongly drives youth justice outcomes and violence: children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely as better-off peers to face police action for the same offense; poorer youths were about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision; a prior police record was the strongest predictor of being NEET at 18; and household poverty increased offending, with those in extreme poverty much more likely to be both victims and perpetrators, even after other risks were controlled. Gender was a powerful predictor, with boys three times more likely than girls to engage in violence, and poorer girls twice as likely as more affluent girls to be involved in violent crime. Report author Lesley McAra warned that poverty heightens violence risk and contact with the juvenile justice system can exacerbate it, reproducing conditions for violence.
