A related AQMeN study showed crime reductions have not benefitted the most deprived areas, where crime remains concentrated: half of the highest‑crime communities are also in the top 20% for chronic health problems and a third in the top 20% for unemployment, raising questions about whether inequality is being tackled. The Scottish government said Scotland is becoming safer, citing recorded crime at a 41‑year low, homicide at a 39‑year low, 1,000 extra officers, and a £296m investment to mitigate welfare cuts and address poverty and inequalities.

Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway in the Marian Estate, Kilkee, in the early hours of Sunday and pronounced dead at 06:00 after being taken to Limerick University Hospital. Robbie Walsh, of Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh and remanded in custody until 14 August. Two other men arrested were released without charge, with files sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions. In Ennis District Court, Det Sgt Padraig Frawley said it will be alleged Walsh was one of three who entered the estate shortly after 01:00 seeking Mr Haugh; a fight involving weapons ensued after they encountered him and another man, with additional individuals joining. Gardaí recovered knives and golf clubs at the scene, including a bloodstained blade and a knife handle, and a judge noted evidence of local tension following the killing.

After Sinn Féin MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted in May 2014 implying Tom Elliott had harassed and shot people while serving in the UDR, the High Court heard Elliott—now MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, who served in the UDR from 1982 to 1992—has a clear MoD record. Elliott was alerted to the tweet by victims campaigner Ann Travers and DUP MLA Arlene Foster (set to become Northern Ireland’s first minister), and Flanagan deleted it within an hour. An apology, to be posted on Twitter by Friday, will state the allegation was untrue and wholly without foundation, while Mr Justice Stevens reserved judgment on compensation. The insurer that indemnifies Stormont MLAs has refused to cover Flanagan’s costs and compensation, a decision he is challenging separately. Elliott said he was vindicated, noting Flanagan admitted the comments were totally untrue and expressing frustration at the delay.

Hawick Knitwear, founded in 1874 and employing over 230 staff, has increased weekly sweater production from about 7,500 last year to 9,500 to meet surging demand, driven by better-than-expected sales of its Hawick Knitwear-branded range launched in January and growth in its private-label business. The company was bought by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year and sells across Europe (Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, Spain) and in the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop said rising orders at home and abroad prompted the production boost, credited dedicated staff, and expressed confidence in the firm’s future despite challenges.

At Luton Crown Court, Brian Wright, 55, admitted hitting 72-year-old lollipop lady Sylvia Blackburn with his VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun and cannot recall the traffic light color. Prosecutors say his car failed to stop at a red light as Mrs Blackburn, appropriately dressed and on duty, stepped out to escort a woman and her six-year-old daughter, with traffic in the opposite direction already stopped; she suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. The judge paused proceedings as Wright became emotional and apologized, saying he had turned her world upside down. The sun was about 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into his eyes; the trial continues.

NATO’s Dynamic Mongoose exercise, spurred by increased Russian submarine patrols, trains a 10-ship force led from USS Vicksburg (including HMS Portland) to find the German U-boat U33, which is trying to “sink” the command ship and an oil tanker while staying hidden. The drill highlights the difficulty of anti-submarine warfare—often reduced to fleeting periscope sightings and sonar analysis—and the seriousness with which crews treat the mission. As European states cut defense capabilities, Russia has invested in a roughly 60-strong, technologically advanced, ultranquiet submarine fleet that RUSI says leads the world, can remain undetected for months, and “fingerprint” other navies. Alongside helicopters, NATO for the first time employs underwater drones that offer cheaper, persistent, safer surveillance but struggle with seabed clutter. Long-range maritime patrol aircraft remain vital; a French Atlantique provides cover because Britain has none, a key UK vulnerability that forces reliance on allies and demands attention in the forthcoming defense and security review.

UN officials warn South Sudan’s crisis may be sliding toward genocide and ethnic cleansing as violence that flared in Juba in July spread to the southern Equatoria states, driving about 340,000 people into Uganda—more than any other country this year, compared with 200,000 Syrians in 2016—and averaging 2,500 new refugees daily. Refugees describe killings, rape, and ethnically targeted attacks linked to the rivalry between Dinka President Salva Kiir and Nuer former vice-president Riek Machar, with Equatorians increasingly targeted since July; accounts include boys being killed, women and girls raped, and families murdered. Uganda has responded rapidly—within 36 hours families receive small plots and tarpaulins to start planting—but the burden is immense: Bidi Bidi has grown into one of the world’s largest refugee settlements (over a quarter-million people across 250 sq km), the country now hosts nearly a million refugees, and essential services like water must be trucked in. The UNHCR urges international pressure on South Sudan’s leaders to stop the massacre of civilians on both sides, noting that roughly half the refugees are children and many are deeply traumatized.

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight championship. The ex-Norwich and Peterborough man became a professional boxer in 2013 after quitting football two years earlier, has an eight-win, one-draw record from nine fights, is the son of former British and European champion Clinton, and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

Bridgwater Community Hospital is set to be rebuilt as part of the coalition’s £330m investment in new NHS facilities, with a total project cost of £33m and the remaining balance funded by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. Planned for Bowers Lane subject to planning permission and aiming for completion by autumn 2014, the new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities and space for mobile scanners. It will replace the cramped, outdated 1813 building, which staff say suffers from extreme temperatures and heavy maintenance, and is expected to improve patient recovery and well-being. This project aligns with wider upgrades in Somerset—three of 13 community hospitals have been replaced in the past five years and work is under way on Musgrove Park Hospital’s Jubilee Building—with clinicians praising the move toward integrated, one-stop care.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, near the city centre, around 13:35 GMT, with witnesses saying he was in or near a black Mercedes he had been driving. Police found him with a gunshot wound to the chest, armed officers sealed off the area, and he died later at Northern General hospital. Local residents said he was from a nearby family gathering for a celebration, with relatives rushing out to help after hearing the shot. The incident comes amid recent shootings in Sheffield, previously in the north of the city: a 25-year-old seriously injured in Shiregreen on Monday, shots fired into an elderly couple’s living room in Southey Green believed to be mistaken identity, and two separate house shootings on the same High Green street in January.

The passage surveys rival hacktivist groups in the Ukraine conflict—Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International—all presenting themselves as independent activists and capable of exposing documents, blocking websites, and hijacking CCTV, billboards, and printers. Led by Yevhen Dokukin, Ukrainian Cyber Troops claim hacks on Russian interior ministry servers and a Rostov police email, with volunteers finding apparent official reports indicating wounded Russian servicemen evacuated from Ukraine; they use DDoS “artillery” to disable rebel sites, target separatists’ electronic payment accounts, monitor rebel areas via hacked CCTV, and have hijacked printers to broadcast pro‑Ukrainian and anti‑Putin messages, while officials deny using hackers’ data to direct artillery. Cyber Berkut, staunchly anti‑Western, aims to thwart Kyiv’s military plans; during Joe Biden’s Kyiv visit it defaced government sites, claimed to extract documents on U.S. military aid, hacked billboards to show graphic anti‑Kyiv content, said it disrupted parliamentary vote‑counting, leaked defense data on losses and desertions, and blocked the president’s site; it also touted a purportedly hacked Facebook chat alleging Ukraine downed MH17, a claim unverified and largely ignored. Anonymous International (b0ltai/Shaltay Boltay) publishes leaked Kremlin material—unclear if hacked or insider-provided—mostly on Russian domestic affairs but including a fighter’s letter suggesting locals didn’t support separatists and alleged emails tied to Igor Girkin; its site is blocked in Russia.

Ahead of the 5 May election, presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional as departing MSPs gave valedictory speeches, including former first minister Alex Salmond and Labour veteran Duncan McNeil. Salmond reaffirmed his view that Scotland is “diverse, not divided,” said there is broad support for Holyrood to take greater responsibility, welcomed new powers under the Scotland Bill but argued it falls short of referendum pledges, mixed in humor, and signed off with “goodbye… for now.” Marwick praised his service as MSP and first minister. McNeil urged Holyrood to strengthen accountability, scrutiny, and committee work, saying it must now learn from Westminster. Former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also bowed out, joking about Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “faux indignation.”

Older People’s Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is inviting older people and their families to share experiences of residential care to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies, as part of a review into the quality of life and care in Welsh care homes. The review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, and will also gather input from providers, social care staff, and public bodies. Rochira aims to highlight good practice and the impact of poor care, citing increasing concerns and unacceptable variations across Wales, and to ensure decision-makers understand daily realities and act to improve quality of life. Care Forum Wales chair Mario Kreft supports the review’s aims but criticizes the absence of a provider expert or individuals with direct care home experience on the main advisory panel, calling it a missed opportunity for partnership working.

Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group reported a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m for the year to June 2016 despite turnover falling by £1m to just over £100m, with international sales growing in Europe and new markets. The Turriff-based company manufactures and supplies animal feeds for the beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry sectors and runs 19 Country Store shops across Scotland serving rural communities with products including fireside supplies, country clothing and footwear. In Companies House filings, it noted that agriculture’s outlook is hard to predict after 12–18 months of challenges; while Brexit’s impact is not yet clear, the board is confident the group will be well positioned for any resulting business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead Saturday afternoon at a house on Nettleden Road in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, and a man in his 80s was taken to hospital; police say the investigation is in its early stages but are treating the death as murder. Detectives urgently want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, and warn the public not to approach him. He is described as white, about 6ft (1.8m) tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair, of average build, possibly wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Officers have increased patrols and urge anyone with information to contact police or Crimestoppers.

David Lipton, the IMF’s second-in-command, warned in a Washington speech that the Fund’s latest reading shows a weakening global baseline and that the world is at a “delicate juncture,” following data that Chinese exports plunged by a quarter year-on-year; the IMF has indicated it is likely to downgrade its current 3.4% global growth forecast in its April outlook, a bleak scenario with ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that had bet on China’s growth.

At a council scrutiny meeting on the troubled new Cowes chain ferry, leader Dave Stewart made crossings free until 2 July to acknowledge problems and gather feedback, and ordered an auditor review after calling the launch “frustrating and disappointing.” Since its late 14 May debut, the ferry has broken down, run aground, been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training issues, and caused car damage during loading and unloading. Shopkeeper Angie Booth said local businesses have borne almost six months of lost trade and asked about compensation; transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation is under discussion, described the ferry as a prototype with expected teething issues, said electrical problems have been rectified, ramp extensions authorized to prevent vehicle scraping, and groundings attributed to seamanship now resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, in which a 32-year-old man died at the scene. Police arrested a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention, and the road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigations.

Matching Models, a London agency billing itself as “an international temp agency for beautiful and talented people,” posted ads specifying women’s physical attributes—such as a PA with “brown long hair” and “b‑c cup” and a “sexy female driver” to drive a Porsche Cayenne two days a week for £40,000–£50,000—prompting the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) to condemn them as appalling, unlawful and demeaning and to write to the firm demanding immediate clarification of its hiring practices; women’s groups called the ads 1970s‑style and likely unlawful. Employment lawyer James Lynas said the adverts are clearly unlawful, that phrases like “beautiful and attractive” could be code for “young” and discriminatory against older women, that anyone can complain to the EHRC (which can intervene), and that a rejected male applicant could sue for sex discrimination with unlimited compensation. Founder Nathalie Jansen defended prioritizing looks, citing client demands (e.g., an older gentleman seeking a “Jackie O” look with a smaller cup size to fit a Dior outfit and a businessman hiring blonde, blue‑eyed Greek women), and the company’s website argues first impressions matter; EHRC’s Rebecca Hilsenrath countered that hair color isn’t what counts and urged the firm to consign such sexism to history. Under the Equality Act 2010, it is illegal to state or imply discriminatory intent, employers cannot ask about age, sexual orientation, marital status, number of children or plans to have children, disability, race or religion, and clothing size requirements must be essential to the job; Matching Models says it has hired 5,000 people worldwide and lists clients including MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca‑Cola and Harrods.

A shooting took place at the hostel of the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where Mahesh, an office assistant, allegedly barged into 18-year-old Gautami’s room on Tuesday evening and shot her in the head, then shot another student, Sirisha, who was severely injured but is believed to be out of danger; he was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and remanded until 12 April. The motive is unclear. Incidents of gun crime at Indian schools and colleges are very rare despite strict gun control laws, though firearms are often used in feuds, and a 2007 case near Delhi involved a 14-year-old schoolboy shot dead by two fellow students.

GLAAD’s Where We Are on TV study of scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series airing or with confirmed casting between June 2016 and May 2017 counted 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender roles rising from seven to 16. The report also highlighted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast TV, driven by shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder, but criticized the deaths of more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters, including Poussey Washington (Orange is the New Black) and Bea Smith (Wentworth). GLAAD president Sarah Kate Ellis said the progress is heartening, while noting that numbers are only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he would not seek re-election ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy faced likely opposition, following criticism over a borough council loan to Northampton Town FC made during his leadership; about £10.25m is missing, the stadium stand remains half built, and police are investigating alleged financial irregularities. He denies wrongdoing and said it was time for his constituents to have a new representative.

In April in Balch Springs, Texas, former police officer Roy Oliver, 37, fired a rifle into a car of teenagers driving away from a house party, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards; he was fired days later for policy violations. Police had responded to reports of underage drinking and, after officers inside the home heard what they believed were gunshots, Oliver opened fire; initial claims that the car reversed aggressively toward him were disproved by footage showing it driving forward away. Oliver faces a murder charge carrying a possible 5–99 years in prison and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official for the other four teens in the car, including two of Edwards’ brothers. He is free on bail, his lawyer has not commented, and no trial date has been set; the Dallas County district attorney said justice is proceeding effectively and thoroughly. If convicted, he would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973, and the family’s lawyer urged caution, noting it has been more than 40 years since a cop was convicted in Texas; Edwards’ coach described him as exemplary as a player, son, teammate, and friend.

Melania Trump and son Barron will delay moving to Washington until he finishes the school year, with no date set; spokesman Jason Miller said the family is energized about serving and cited avoiding a midyear school change, prompting both criticism and support online. While only Martha Washington (before the White House existed) and Anna Harrison (whose husband died early) declined to live there, historian William Seale notes family accommodations have varied, citing Frances Folsom Cleveland spending much time at a separate home, John Tyler’s children not relocating immediately, and Dolley Madison sending her son to school; recent school-age residents Chelsea Clinton and Malia and Sasha Obama moved in from inauguration, the Obamas having relocated early to ease schooling. The First Lady’s role is ceremonial but often public-facing, with figures like Lou Henry Hoover and Eleanor Roosevelt active and Nancy Reagan initially reluctant; Melania has prioritized Barron and signaled interest in tackling cyber-bullying, raising the possibility others, such as Ivanka Trump, might share duties, as seen historically and when Chelsea Clinton assisted her mother. Past first families have balanced public duties with family routines, with privacy largely respected and structured time fostering normalcy.

A 72-year-old man who died on 27 October at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness prompted an investigation by the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), led by Kate Frame, into the initial police response to his call. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) instructed Pirc to carry out the inquiry, Police Scotland said it is fully engaging and awaits the findings, and Pirc will submit a report to COPFS in due course.

Forecasters issued a yellow wind warning, noting locally possible gusts up to 75 mph (120 km/h), particularly west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly direction likely to intensify impacts and cause travel disruption on roads and at sea. The affected counties are Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys. Overnight winds felled a tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing a main route into the town, and Telford Road is expected to remain closed for most of Monday for clean-up.

The Giants and Panthers traded goals, with player-coach Derrick Walser scoring a short-handed opener for the Giants before Jeff Dimmen equalised; in the second period Mike Forney’s powerplay breakaway made it 2-1, Andy Bohmback levelled, then Mike Radja and James Desmarais put the Giants 4-2 up before Nottingham’s David Ling pulled one back. The teams meet again on Saturday night in the second match of their double-header. In the league, Nottingham lead with 28 points, Sheffield Steelers have 27, and Belfast 25.
MODEL FAILED TO RETURN ANY OUTPUT

Thomas Hitzlsperger used an interview with Die Zeit to come out as gay in order to spark discussion of a topic he says is ignored in German football, becoming the most prominent footballer to do so and drawing widespread support. Former teammates Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, Bayern Munich, and leading administrators Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball praised his courage, while public figures such as Gary Lineker, Joey Barton, and John Amaechi also voiced backing. The announcement is viewed as a watershed in a sport still struggling with homophobia; government spokesman Steffen Seibert and politician Volker Beck urged acceptance and greater openness, and Zwanziger expressed optimism that sexual orientation will soon be a non-issue. This contrasts with earlier caution, including Philipp Lahm’s 2011 advice against coming out and second-tier player Marcus Urban’s claim that some Bundesliga players hide their sexuality.

Steve Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances to help Brighton earn promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years and, with his contract expiring, he hopes to sign a new deal, saying he believes they can stay up. Brighton’s win over Wigan confirmed promotion and, four points clear of Newcastle with two games remaining, they aim to wrap up the title. Sidwell made 19 appearances on loan from Stoke in 2015–16 before signing a one-year deal in June 2016, and, with prior Premier League spells at Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke, he feels his stronger-than-expected impact this season merits another top-flight opportunity.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1: Jamille Matt put Blackpool ahead after 12 minutes from Nathan Delfouneso’s chipped cross, but after Sam Slocombe’s superb save from Matthew Briggs, Kurtis Guthrie equalised from the resulting corner. Slocombe later denied George Elokobi and Guthrie hit the bar before half-time. Tom Aldred missed a late unmarked header that could have won it for Blackpool, and Colchester finished with 10 men when substitute Sean Murray was sent off for violent conduct in stoppage time.

Reid, 29, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One, has previously played for Charlton, Bradford and Preston, and could make his debut for Colchester United (the U’s) in Wednesday’s EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa; Colchester began the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

PC Keith Palmer’s murder outside Parliament in March intensified calls for a permanent police memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire. The UK Police Memorial Trust is appealing for £1.5m toward the £4m project, to be completed by 2019, which will commemorate officers and staff who have lost their lives over the past 250 years by bearing more than 1,400 names and featuring a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out and given to families as personal memorials. Sir Hugh Orde said the site will provide a place for national and personal remembrance of policing’s courage and sacrifice, and the government has committed £1m to the memorial.

Manchester United moved 15 points clear at the top with eight games remaining after a 1-0 win at Sunderland, a run highlighted by 25 wins in their first 30 matches and 50 points from the last 54; they have eight matches to surpass Chelsea’s 95-point 2005 record. Sir Alex Ferguson stressed focusing only on the next game—the upcoming league derby against Manchester City, where United hold a 15-point head start—and said he will make changes for Monday’s FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea after injuries to Rafael and Anderson and a knock to David De Gea following a collision with Nemanja Vidic. Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley did not start at Sunderland, Rooney will be assessed after returning tired from England duty, Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez are available, and Rio Ferdinand was among those not taken to Sunderland. Ferguson praised a strong first half, acknowledged a battling second half, credited Sunderland’s effort, and said United’s win owed much to determined defending and courage.

Google chairman Eric Schmidt told the BBC the company pays all taxes legally required, noting Google paid £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, and said it is up to the UK government to change tax laws—Google will comply and pay more or less accordingly. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, proposed a new committee to oversee major firms’ tax arrangements, able to take secret evidence to bypass confidentiality. Google, which routes most UK sales through Ireland, has been criticized for minimizing UK tax, while EU leaders agreed to combat avoidance via automatic information exchange among tax authorities. Schmidt argued corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity and risk occur, called for international tax reform, and urged politicians to set and defend clear, simple rules that law-abiding companies can follow.

NHS Improvement says the NHS is behind schedule in cutting its £3.6bn annual agency staff bill, targeting a £1bn reduction by year-end; an October cap limiting rates to no more than 55% above normal shift pay for all but senior managers has saved £600m so far. The cap aims to reduce both costs and reliance on agency workers, who are pricier due to fees and employer costs, but trusts remain about 10% off target, and it’s unclear if other pay spending has risen. Figures exclude NHS bank staff and overtime. The regulator will publish league tables of trusts’ agency spending and collect data on each trust’s 20 highest-earning agency workers amid concerns over excessive rates, citing quotes like £130/hour for a surgeon (cap £76) and £70/hour for a junior doctor (cap £35). Chief executive Jim Mackey said the NHS cannot keep paying for expensive agency staff and more action is needed.

Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a “cathedral of commerce,” now symbolizes Ireland’s post–Celtic Tiger crash, yet locals see tentative recovery: shopkeeper Matt O’Brien reports being 30% down from the boom with a layoff but notes improvement after diversifying into childrenswear and dress hire. Fianna Fáil criticizes the Fine Gael–Labour government’s midlands policy, arguing that the half‑billion euro spent on water meters not yet operational should go to broadband, and TD Robert Troy says the IDA hasn’t brought a single potential client to Longford in over four years. The government cites Center Parcs’ proposed €200m, 340‑acre development in Ballymahon, aiming for about 1,000 jobs on opening in 2019, though it still needs planning permission; Fine Gael TD James Bannon highlights the region’s scenic waterways and infrastructure. Traders like O’Brien still want practical boosts such as free street parking, and the overall message is that while recovery is beginning in the midlands, more needs to be done, with the Center Parcs news likely to help the government in the expected election.

An eight-team tournament runs with each team playing the others twice, the top four qualifying for the play-offs, and the competition concluding on 29 May in the same stadium; scores, fixtures and results are on BBC Sport. Current leaders: runs – Warner 294, Kohli 267, De Villiers 249; most sixes – Warner 12, De Villiers 12, Kohli 8; highest individual scores – De Kock 108, Warner 90*, Gambhir 90*; wickets – McClenaghan 9, Kumar 8, Rahman 7. Four current or former England players feature: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). Fixtures span 25 April to 22 May (mostly 15:30 BST, some 10:30 BST) across teams including Kings XI Punjab, Mumbai Indians, Sunrisers Hyderabad, Rising Pune Supergiants, Delhi Daredevils, Gujurat Lions, Kolkata Knight Riders and Royal Challengers Bangalore, followed by Qualifier 1 on 24 May, the Eliminator on 25 May, Qualifier 2 on 27 May, and the Final on 29 May.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported that plastic carrier bag use had risen by 200 million since 2013, worsening environmental harm as many non-recyclable bags are discarded in dumps and rivers. To address this, from October people in England will have to pay 5p for plastic bags to encourage reuse; Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland already charge and have seen decreases in bag use. Campaigners hope the English charge will reduce the number of bags thrown away and help the environment.

High winds across Wales on a busy pre-Christmas Friday prompted a yellow “be aware” warning and caused widespread disruption, with part of a school roof ripped off at Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon and power cuts affecting hundreds of homes. Transport was hit by train delays and speed restrictions (including Llandudno Junction–Holyhead), restrictions on the A55 Britannia and M48 Severn bridges that were later lifted, and Irish Ferries canceling six fast Holyhead–Dublin sailings while transferring passengers to cruise services; the highest gusts were recorded at Mona on Anglesey. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham, and although winds eased by evening, a blustery Christmas weekend forecast led to Rhyl’s Boxing Day Dip being postponed to Tuesday, 27 December.

Jordan said he is “super excited” for Black Panther and wants “to put a different spin on it,” but did not reveal his role; the film will reunite him with his Creed director Ryan Coogler. He added he is eager to work with Lupita Nyong’o—who won a best supporting actress Oscar for 12 Years a Slave in 2014 and played the CGI character Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens—and Chadwick Boseman, currently on screen as Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in last year’s Fantastic Four flop reboot, and Black Panther is slated for a February 2018 release.

Alexandra Palace’s 1875 theatre, long unused but retaining original décor and stage machinery, is part of an east wing restoration to create a new cultural destination, including repairing and refurbishing the BBC studios and turning the glazed east court into public and exhibition space; if fundraising succeeds, the theatre—originally a venue for opera, musicals, plays and early cinema—aims to reopen in 2018 for theatrical performances, cinema, comedy and live music, funded by £18.8m from the Heritage Lottery Fund and £6.8m from Haringey Council toward the £26.6m project, with the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust committed to raising the final £1m by summer 2017.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, earned 61 England caps after his 2009 debut, was in squads for two World Cups and two European Championships—playing only three minutes at Euro 2016—and said the decision reached was about common sense while wishing Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters success; he is also England’s most-capped Under-21 player with 46 appearances since 2004 and scored his only international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova in the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

In Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, Marcy Smith’s house was destroyed by a fast-moving fire that started from rubbish she burned in the wood stove, and the fire alarm did not go off. Her son David, awake while on FaceTime with his father, spotted the flames, woke the family, and helped his mother and sister escape as the kitchen was quickly engulfed, though their dog and cats died. The family fled in only their pyjamas, and the community has rallied with donations of clothes, shoes, and a bike. Smith told the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation she credits David with saving their lives and will keep reminding him of his heroic act.

Reports say an energy drinks giant considered a £200m bid for West Ham; Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in 2010 when the club was valued at £105m and now own over 85%. Since moving to London Stadium in August, the club has been linked with Qatari and Chinese takeover interest. Sullivan said last year a minority stake might be sold to clear debts, but he and Gold plan to pass ownership to their children.

At a fan-voted Los Angeles awards show that “is definitely not the Oscars,” playful categories like best kiss and best shirtless performance (won again by Efron) mixed with heavy promotion for upcoming blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner, taking best movie, while Shailene Woodley earned best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss with Ansel Elgort, dedicating an emotional speech to author John Green. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, dedicating it to the late Chris Kyle; Channing Tatum took best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street; Meryl Streep won best villain for Into the Woods; and Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne were also winners. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award with his children, saying he does it all for them. Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award from his Avengers co-stars—who knelt onstage—calling it “the recognition I so desire.” The show also previewed the Pitch Perfect sequel, Judd Apatow’s Trainwreck, and Marvel’s new film Ultron.

St Mirren have brought in 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 cap Cammy Smith, with manager Jack Ross calling it a “brilliant acquisition” that adds another attacking option; Smith was loaned by Aberdeen (the Dons) to Dundee United in July and has five goals this season, having debuted for Aberdeen in 2012 and scored four times in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie club. Bottom-of-the-Championship St Mirren host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council said warmer weather now allows its Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes, with a goal of filling 145 per day over the next four months, and extra staff will repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016 on EnQuest’s Thistle platform, 125 miles northeast of Shetland, six Wood Group contractors removing pipework during a planned shutdown were exposed to radiation; rigging supervisor Steve Innes says they learned of a problem two-thirds through the trip, had been working without proper PPE, were told the levels may not cause long-term harm, but now fear cancer with blood tests ongoing, and he accuses EnQuest of failing in its duty of care while noting he has struggled to find work since raising concerns. EnQuest says the exposure involved low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM), less than 1% of the threshold for reporting to the Health and Safety Executive, though it notified HSE and, after investigation, took additional precautionary steps. Wood Group says safety is its top priority, it downmanned employees for medical assessments, supported a joint investigation, and is reinforcing procedures. The Unite union condemned the workers’ treatment and called for transparency, while HSE said the incident was not reportable under RIDDOR, no staff raised it separately, and no investigation was carried out.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) bought a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007, but after allegations surfaced in a 2012 court case and the dealer’s manager, Aaron Freedman, confessed to dealing in looted Indian antiquities and possessing 150 stolen objects, ACM decided to return the piece. Although there is no conclusive proof the sculpture was stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, the decision followed discussions between Singapore’s National Heritage Board and India’s Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which officially requested its return in May. The bronze was one of 30 objects ACM bought from the dealer; none of the others are thought to be listed as stolen, though ASI was allowed to view them. The museum plans legal action to seek compensation for apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck at 15:48 (14:48 GMT) at a depth of 15.5 km with its epicentre in Garfagnana, 35 km north of Lucca, and was felt in Milan, Florence, Bologna and Modena; there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, though phone and power lines were cut in Garfagnana, several aftershocks followed, schools were evacuated as a precaution, Milan’s top floors shook, and people in Lucca poured into the streets. INGV’s Alessandro Amato called it a classic quake for the area—medium-strong, fairly shallow, and unexpected. The region has recent seismic history: two quakes last May in the same area killed more than 20 people (the strongest magnitude 6, causing significant damage), and nationwide Italy recalls the 2009 L’Aquila disaster that killed nearly 300; in 2012 six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of multiple manslaughter for providing falsely reassuring, incomplete, and contradictory information before that quake.

On 8 September 2016 (15:33 BST), Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield who had doubted South Yorkshire’s climate, finally saw results; the fruit remains attached to the plant and is not yet ripe to eat, and he said he was “literally jumping for joy.”

Rockstar has delayed Grand Theft Auto V’s PC release from 27 January to 24 March to allow extra testing and polish, saying the move is in the best interests of the game and fans. Online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC launch. New PC screenshots were released, with promises of greater detail, 1080p at 60fps, support for up to 4K resolution and triple-monitor setups, and the minimum PC specifications were published. GTA V, originally released on 17 September 2013, became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, earning $1bn in three days.

At Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery, 76-year-old Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for Squint (19), after being shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times, saying finally winning was “very nice indeed.” Judge Ansel Krut called the work “quite extraordinary” yet “difficult to look at,” likening it to a subtle, minimal “tone poem” that builds sympathy. The painting depicts a medieval “leper squint”—holes in church walls so undesirables could watch services—and, at about 7ft (2.1m), is a relatively small piece from a larger series; Simpson entered it for its size and because he was working on it. He plans to spend the prize on stretches, canvas and good quality paints. Established in 1957, the biennial John Moores Painting Prize is one of Britain’s oldest; past winners include David Hockney and Peter Doig, and patron Sir Peter Blake won the junior title in 1961.

The offices of pro-government newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked almost simultaneously early Thursday, with four masked assailants targeting the Yeni Safak building; no casualties were reported. Gunfire shattered windows at both sites, numerous spent bullet casings were found, a blaze at Yeni Safak was quickly extinguished, and police cordoned off the area around that building and are hunting the attackers. The papers back President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s AK Party, their offices are 20 km apart, no group has claimed responsibility, and the incidents follow last September’s attack on Hurriyet by pro-government protesters over an alleged misquote of Erdogan.

A 24-year-old, previously under contract with the Stags, will join Marcus Bignot’s Mariners on a free transfer on 1 January, becoming Bignot’s first signing; he spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances, and is an ex-Burton player.

Arsene Wenger, whose Arsenal contract runs to the summer and who has been linked with the England job, voiced support for Gareth Southgate, praising his experience and stressing competency over big names; Southgate, 46, follows a win over Malta and a draw with Slovenia and has a World Cup qualifier against Scotland on 11 November and a friendly with Spain four days later to push for the permanent role. Wenger said he remains focused on his current job, confirmed Arsenal will offer 21-year-old Hector Bellerin a new contract despite reported interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, and said Bellerin’s long-term future is at the club. He also noted Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games after a hamstring injury suffered on 14 August.

Officers believe a local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday, and Lincolnshire Police, conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, said the company is cooperating fully.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to end the dispute over seafarers’ pay, after the RMT claimed some crew on the freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay were paid under £4 an hour. The change will see contracted-out services return to Serco Northlink from next month, subject to final financial and regulatory details. Seatruck, which currently operates the vessels under contract to Serco Northlink, had argued the national minimum wage did not apply to many non-UK crew, while Serco Northlink said it had offered to bridge and backdate the pay gap but Seatruck refused. Yousaf said the new charter basis will resolve the wage issue and ensure all crew receive at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink, awarded a six-year £243m Northern Isles contract in 2012, operates three ferries and two cargo boats on a route heavily subsidised by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. On 7 May, after drinking at the park bar, Jamie Mitchell, 35, intervened in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother, Samantha, leading to a confrontation that bystanders broke up; he later told police he tried to push them apart, calling it a “tragic accident.” At Winchester Crown Court, where he reacted emotionally to a jury’s verdict, Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault, and he and his mother admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially claiming Mr Dickie pushed Samantha and she pushed him back; both are due to be sentenced on 6 February.

British songwriter Rod Temperton died in London last week aged 66 after a brief, aggressive battle with cancer; nicknamed “The Invisible Man,” he had a private funeral. Born in Cleethorpes, he moved from a Grimsby frozen‑food job to disco group Heatwave via a Melody Maker ad, writing 1970s hits like Boogie Nights, Always & Forever and Groove Line. Spotted by producer Quincy Jones, he wrote Off The Wall, Rock With You and Burn This Disco Out for Michael Jackson’s Off The Wall, and Thriller, Baby Be Mine and The Lady in My Life for Thriller, helping make it the best‑selling U.S. album with 32 million sold; his songs were also recorded by Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin and The Brothers Johnson. He won a 1990 Grammy for Birdland from Quincy Jones’s Back on the Block and earned two 1986 Oscar nominations for work on The Color Purple soundtrack. Tributes poured in from Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan and BBC radio presenter Gilles Peterson, while Warner/Chappell’s Jon Platt said the family is devastated and requested privacy.

A team including Swansea University’s Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, with researchers from Exeter, Reading, and Brazil’s São Paulo and Belém, identified more than 450 large geometric earthworks (geoglyphs) in Acre, western Brazilian Amazon, revealed by modern deforestation but likely up to 2,000 years old. These ditched enclosures are unlikely to be villages or defensive sites; they were probably used sporadically for ritual gatherings, though Loader’s analyses of phytoliths, charcoal, and carbon isotopes indicate they were built among tall vegetation and not visible above the forest canopy, complicating their interpretation. The findings challenge the view that pre-16th-century Amazon forests were pristine, showing that over 6,000 years people assembled diverse plant species and practiced low-burn management, concentrating on economically valuable trees like palms. The team likens this agroforestry to a “prehistoric supermarket,” with evidence that its legacy still shapes the biodiversity of some Acre forests today.

Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian ranked a career-high 12th, beat world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round, days after winning the Japan Open and edging toward the top 10. He said he was subdued because he felt tired and “a bit bored,” citing travel, poor sleep after arriving late, and the hour-long ride to the Qi Zhong Stadium near Shanghai. The tournament also recalls his $1,500 fine last year for a foul-mouthed outburst in which he called it a “circus.”

Scientists and charities say the HPV vaccine can protect against head and neck cancers, and while girls aged 12–13 already receive it to prevent cervical cancer, groups including Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University’s HPV research team are urging the Welsh government to vaccinate boys, citing rising head and neck cancer cases. Consultant oncologist Dr Mererid Evans reports a shift toward younger, mostly non-smoking patients, with three-quarters men and an average age of 55, and Tenovus notes HPV causes 5% of the global cancer burden. A school vaccination program began in 2008 with 85% of girls in Wales vaccinated, and the Welsh government says it will await Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation advice before considering changes.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School pupil with the rare blood cancer gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, died after inspiring widespread support by chronicling his illness on the “Jak’s Journey” Facebook page, which gained more than 28,000 Likes. He briefly attended a prom in his honour on Saturday, where former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson greeted him, and his family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. A devoted Rangers fan, he met club players, and during hospital stays in Edinburgh and Glasgow he was visited by athletes from Celtic, Hibs, Hearts and Edinburgh Rugby and the cast of Wicked. After doctors said on 23 January that the cancer had spread and no further treatment would be pursued, he thanked medical staff and resolved to fight the pain. His family urged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, with further fundraising planned via a charity football match at Livingston’s Energy Assets Arena.

Egypt beat Uganda 1-0 in a drab Group D match on a deteriorating Port-Gentil pitch, decided in the 89th minute when Mohamed Salah set up Abdallah El Said to finish past Denis Onyango; Uganda had a Joseph Ochaya effort correctly disallowed for offside and, despite second-half pressure, failed to register a shot on target. The result means Egypt face Ghana on Wednesday with top spot still at stake, while Uganda are out of their first tournament since 1978. Earlier, Ghana secured a quarter-final place by beating Mali 1-0; in the final round Uganda meet Mali, who must win and need Ghana to defeat Egypt by two or more goals to qualify.

Lancashire County Council has earmarked land at the former Glenburn Sports College (council-owned, closed in August) and the unused Skelmersdale College Westbank campus (owned by Newcastle College) for a new Skelmersdale railway station, following a Network Rail comparison that also considered a site near the Concourse shopping centre. Working with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, the plans could deliver two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. Councillor John Fillis called it an exciting step, saying the preferred location is large enough for future expansion with good highway access and connectivity, and the authority will now begin acquiring the relevant land. Skelmersdale’s original station closed to passengers in 1956; designated a new town on 9 October 1961, it remains one of the largest towns in the north west of England without a railway station.
Police searching a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning found plants in an “elaborate grow house” and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

In Hamelin, Lower Saxony, a 28-year-old woman was found late Sunday with severe injuries after being dragged by the neck through several streets; she underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner from nearby Bad Muender later surrendered to authorities. Both are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive remains unclear, according to Hannover prosecutor Thomas Klinge. Police have secured the area and appealed for witnesses.

A study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin of 4,600 workers, using 2013–14 Australian workplace relations survey data, found women ask for pay rises as often as men but are less likely to get them; when comparing like-for-like full-time and part-time workers and controlling for employer size, industry, parenthood and qualifications, men were 25% more likely to receive a raise when they asked. The research found no evidence for the “reticent female” theory or that women avoid asking to placate bosses or conform to stereotypes. Using Australia’s uniquely detailed data on raise requests, Warwick’s Andrew Oswald said the results imply some element of discrimination against women, though he noted the country could be atypical. The study also found parity under 40 in both asking for and receiving raises, which co-author Amanda Goodall viewed as a hopeful sign that younger women are negotiating more successfully.

Oxford City Council has spent funds mainly on ground investigations for new burial sites but found none suitable; only Wolvercote and Botley cemeteries have remaining space, expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. Despite ongoing efforts, the council says it has run out of suitable land in Oxford, with potential council-owned sites ruled out due to size, poor ground conditions, high water tables, or restrictive covenants. Once the two cemeteries are full, only reopening family plots, using a few reserved plots, and interring ashes will be possible. The last expansion of burial space in the city was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis (19–22 July) is introducing an augmented reality app that lets visitors trigger online content from items like signs and posters, providing videos and band interviews on phones and tablets. Acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. Director Caroline Maclennan says the feature enhances the festival and enables global engagement, with messages updated before and during the event so people can access information and interviews, buy tickets, and get a taste of the festival’s atmosphere from anywhere.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred gelding owned by Trevor Hemmings and ridden by Leighton Aspell, collapsed and died after narrowly beating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day; veterinary staff treated him on course but he was pronounced dead, with the British Horseracing Authority confirming a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Tony Welsh of the BHA said such episodes are rare, can occur without underlying issues across sport horses, and the sport aims to better understand and prevent them. Though Many Clouds had previously shown post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling) and was closely monitored—most notably after his Grand National success—he had never collapsed and showed no ataxia symptoms on Saturday. A previous winner of the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup, he was described by trainer Oliver Sherwood as the “horse of a lifetime,” while BBC correspondent Cornelius Lysaght stressed there were no significant underlying health issues and that the report concludes a rare haemorrhage caused his death.

At Portsmouth Crown Court, a 34-year-old defendant now called Davina, formerly known as David Ayrton, denied raping a girl she had met when the girl was 15 at a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004, but was remanded in custody and will be sentenced on 4 March; Judge Ian Pearson called it an unusual case, said she posed risks to herself and of failing to attend, and ordered her held in a male prison in Winchester with detention protocols in place. The court heard the rape occurred in the garage while two others slept, that the victim shouted at Ayrton to stop, had only drunk a can and a half of Foster’s, and clearly remembered events. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, discussed her sexuality during the trial, said she had made no physical changes or taken medication, and changed her name in 2012. In 2014 she told a worker at the Fordingbridge, Hampshire care home where she lived about the attack.

In Rio, the Serbian doubles team lost 6-4, 6-4 to Brazil’s Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares, a day after world number one Novak Djokovic was eliminated from the singles by Juan Martin del Potro; Djokovic had earlier suffered a surprise third-round Wimbledon defeat to Sam Querrey in July but rebounded to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

More than 20 competitors will take part in a Saturday event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, where carvers from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US use only chainsaws to carve logs into animals and people; last year’s winner, Pete Bowsher of Moffat, will return to defend the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, 27, has not played since a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm-up against Italy in September but says he is running again and in a pre-season phase, aiming to return around early February—and possibly a couple of weeks sooner with physios’ approval—to be fit for Wales’s Six Nations opener away to Ireland on 7 February. Capped 16 times, he has renewed his national dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to remain with his home region, where he debuted in 2007, to bolster his chances of playing for his country.

On Tuesday morning, U.S. border agents five miles east of Sumas, Washington, interrupted an alleged attempt to smuggle 58 lb (26 kg) of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco after encountering two men with backpacks; one dropped his pack, fired at agents, and fled while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested. A joint U.S.-Canadian search led to the arrest of fugitive Canadian citizen Nathan Hall in Abbotsford, British Columbia. The backpacks contained ecstasy, and one also held a California driver’s licence bearing the name William Nickerson but showing Hall’s photo. Investigators later arrested Bellingham resident Kali Henifin, who planned to pick up the men, and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, who said he was to be paid $11,000 to drive the drugs to San Francisco; Henifin said they had monitored police radio and left after hearing of the shooting. The three defendants in U.S. custody face conspiracy and drug possession and distribution charges, and authorities noted the wooded area is a known smuggling route with such prosecutions common in the district.

NSPCC’s Childline counseled more than 4,500 children about online bullying in the past year, up from about 2,400 in 2011–12, with the true number believed to be much higher; even children as young as seven reported being tormented, abused, and afraid to go to school as online trolls inflicted misery and humiliation. Childline president Dame Esther Rantzen called the figures a wake-up call, warning that cyberbullying follows children home, worsens without intervention, and requires decisive action from parents, teachers, and schools, while urging children to seek help. The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, which is working with parents, schools, and other organizations to address the problem. One young person described being told online to kill themselves, feeling deeply upset, and not being fully understood by their parents.

Israel’s Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote to authorize 492 new homes in the Ramat Shlomo and Ramot settlements at Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s request to avoid straining relations with Washington ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry. The delay follows the US decision to abstain on a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction, which passed and declared settlements illegal under international law and a major obstacle to a two-state solution; over 500,000 Jews live in about 140 settlements built since Israel’s 1967 occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem. Netanyahu, angered by the abstention, accused the White House of helping draft and push the resolution—an allegation the US State Department denied while hoping it would serve as a wake-up call. Israel rejected the resolution, especially its condemnation of building in East Jerusalem, and responded by summoning US and other ambassadors, recalling envoys to New Zealand and Senegal, cutting aid to Senegal, and cancelling a visit by Ukraine’s prime minister. Kerry is expected to outline his vision for ending the conflict and address “misleading critiques,” while Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas said the resolution paves the way for a 15 January French peace conference and hopes for a mechanism and timetable to end the occupation.

On the eve of the Queen’s 90th birthday, Prince William told the BBC she has been a “guiding example” of a good monarch and said he takes duty seriously despite “work-shy” criticism, with support from his father and grandmother as he eases into fuller royal responsibilities. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh visited Windsor’s Royal Mail delivery office to mark the postal service’s 500th anniversary, then opened a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens where schoolchildren sang Happy Birthday. A new set of 10 stamps was released, including a sheet featuring four generations—the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William and Prince George—photographed at Buckingham Palace, plus six stamps highlighting her family life and official role. Political leaders, including David Cameron and Jeremy Corbyn, praised the Queen’s service, with Cameron calling the day an “important landmark.” Birthday events include a Windsor walkabout and unveiling The Queen’s Walkway (a 6.3km trail marking her record reign), and lighting a beacon to start a chain of more than 900 across the UK and beyond, followed by a lunch with President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama on Friday. The Queen observes two birthdays each year: 21 April and an official one in June. The group Republic criticized the BBC’s coverage as celebratory rather than balanced.

West Ham United beat League Two Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup, seizing control before half-time with quick goals into the same bottom corner from Diafra Sakho—his first since November from Sam Byram’s pass—and Andre Ayew. The Premier League side, who made seven changes after league defeats at Manchester United and Southampton, could have added more, with James Collins and Byram going close, Kyle Storer clearing an Angelo Ogbonna header off the line, and keeper Jonathan Flatt denying Sakho from Ayew’s cross. Cheltenham, unchanged from a 3-0 league loss to Carlisle, had respectable moments—Harry Pell’s low volley across goal just evaded sliding substitute Dan Holman, while Pell and Jordon Forster went close—but they did not sufficiently test goalkeeper Adrian. The result follows the clubs’ only previous meeting at the same stage four years earlier, a narrow 2-1 Hammers win, and Cheltenham’s exit ended League Two’s representation before Thursday’s third-round draw.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died after a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday when Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, turned his VW Transporter right and failed to see the motorcyclist. Werner, a father of four who was staying with his family near Bala, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates’ Court, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years; the prosecutor said the victim’s family saw no value in a jail term, accepting it was a momentary lapse, and the defense said Werner was remorseful and had no explanation.

Imran Khawaja, 27, from Southall, west London, a masked and highly public British fighter in Syria who called himself Abu Daigham al-Britani, is deemed by police one of the most dangerous UK jihadists to return, facing a possible life sentence after admitting four offences. Having left the UK via Kurdish territory, he joined Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated to Islamic State that produced slick propaganda aimed at young British Muslims, posting videos, donation appeals, and gruesome images—including one of Khawaja holding a bag containing a severed head. Watched by MI5, he decided to return last June for unknown reasons, enlisted his cousin Tahir Bhatti (who has admitted assisting an offender), faked his own death online, and tried to slip back into Britain, but was arrested at Dover and later held in Belmarsh’s high-risk unit. Police say he chose terrorism and engaged in a terrorist training camp; why he came back and what he planned remain unclear. An additional charge of soliciting to murder will lie on file.

Barnsley have made 22-year-old Kayden Jackson their third signing for next season ahead of Sunday’s League One play-off final at Wembley; Jackson scored four goals in 36 appearances last season as Wrexham finished eighth, turned down a new contract there, and caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom said his pace and direct play will fit Barnsley’s style.

Detergent bottles, believed to be from a container lost overboard during stormy weather, have been washing up since Sunday at Poldhu Cove on the Lizard, with National Trust volunteers clearing them due to risks to wildlife; the bottles are sealed but some have leaked. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirmed the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of Vanish bottles, but says there’s no evidence linking these to the Cornish wash-ups, though the loss is thought to have occurred near Land’s End in May. Nearby coves including Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion are also affected. Cornwall Wildlife Trust is highly concerned about impacts on sensitive marine life, and the National Trust says the main worry is detergent entering the marine environment, though most bottles are full. Cornwall Council and partners are monitoring beaches; the National Trust is overseeing clean-up, and the public is advised to keep children and dogs away and not to recover the bottles. The BBC has contacted Vanish, which has not yet commented.

An incident occurred at about 14:00 on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness, resulting in several people sustaining minor injuries; the road was closed with diversions set up via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich route, and Police Scotland said inquiries are ongoing.

Bolton Wanderers’ French centre-back Dorian Dervite, 28, has signed a new contract after making 14 appearances last season to help the club finish second in League One and earn promotion to the Championship; having joined from Charlton in 2014, he has 83 appearances in all competitions, and manager Phil Parkinson praised his strong late-season contribution. He follows David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan in agreeing new deals post-promotion.

After initially teaming up in the Lords to defeat the government on amendments about EU citizens’ rights and requiring parliamentary approval of a Brexit deal, Labour and the Liberal Democrats split when MPs rejected those changes: the Lib Dems sought to insist on them while Labour chose to defer to the Commons. Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being ready to concede everything, while Labour’s Baroness Smith and a party source called the Lib Dem stance grandstanding that gave people false hope; Lib Dem Baroness Ludford countered that Labour was waving through government plans and aligning with Conservatives on a hard Brexit. Despite a history of cooperating to defeat the government on other issues, Ludford said cross-party work would continue where possible, but a Labour source predicted residual tensions and only business-like relations.

Defence barely cracks voters’ top concerns—well behind the economy, the NHS and immigration—so parties have been defensive and light on detail even as threats grow (failed states, Islamist extremism, a more belligerent Russia) and UK capabilities shrink: the Army is falling from 102,000 to 82,000, the Royal Navy has 19 warships, the RAF has eight (soon seven) front-line fast-jet squadrons, and the UK has no maritime patrol aircraft. Spending has slipped from 4th to 6th globally and is likely to drop below NATO’s 2% of GDP—only UKIP and the DUP would maintain it—with projections of 1.7% (or 1.5% with further cuts); about £25bn over five years would be needed to stay above 2%, and Washington would see a shortfall as damaging to UK credibility. With defence unprotected amid deficit reduction, the £34bn MoD budget could lose £2–3bn a year, though Conservative pledges to renew Trident, raise the equipment budget by 1% annually and avoid further Army cuts constrain savings; Labour avoids such commitments, yet military leaders still expect reductions. Trident is the most divisive issue: Conservatives/UKIP back a like-for-like four-submarine renewal costing at least £20bn (around a quarter of next decade’s equipment spend), Labour would keep continuous patrols with possibly three boats, Lib Dems would end continuous at-sea deterrence, and the SNP/Greens would scrap it—setting up another review or delay and US unease if nuclear costs squeeze conventional forces. Two new aircraft carriers will enter service by decade’s end, but crew and F-35 shortfalls (space for 36 jets but plans for 12) risk a hollow force, challenging claims that Britain still punches above its weight.

Barcelona insists it committed no offence in Neymar’s transfer and that its original tax payment was correct, but to address differing interpretations of the contracts it has filed a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56. The club had stated it paid €57m (£48.6m) for the 22-year-old Santos striker, with £34m going to his parents, yet allegations—and a judge’s ruling to continue investigations—suggest the true cost is higher; including the initial fee, signing-on fee, five-year wages, agents’ fees, and this tax payment, Neymar will cost £106.8m. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid misappropriation accusations and is under investigation, which he denies, and it is not yet confirmed whether the case will be dropped after the payment. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, a Nottingham delivery driver and father of a baby girl, died as a passenger when his van was struck by a car driving the wrong way on the motorway near Kegworth, Leicestershire, at 02:00 GMT on 12 October; the wrong-way driver, Albert Kenneth Newman, also died, and Luciw’s colleague Andy Harrington was seriously injured. Luciw’s family and Harrington urged stricter checks on older motorists—regular in-car driving tests and medical examinations for retired drivers—arguing reaction times slow with age and noting alternatives like free bus passes. UK rules currently require drivers over 70 to renew their licences every three years via self-assessment without a medical or driving test. The DVLA says it has no plans for age-based restrictions because evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents; over-70s must declare medical conditions and can lose their entitlement if they fail medical standards. Age UK said older people should be supported to keep driving safely for as long as possible because driving underpins their independence.

Following complaints of debilitating side effects from mesh implants used to treat incontinence, Scotland’s independent review of transvaginal mesh became contentious: two patient members, Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, and a consultant quit, alleging a watered‑down final report and removed content. Health secretary Ms Robison told Holyrood’s public petitions committee that Prof Alison Britton of Glasgow Caledonian University will examine how the review reached its conclusions and identify lessons. The report advised against routinely offering mesh procedures for pelvic organ prolapse, urged offering a range of treatments with information to enable informed choices, and called for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Ms Robison said the recommendations will continue to be implemented, noting the Scottish government cannot impose a ban, which is a matter for the UK Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. Review chair Tracey Gillies, who took over late in the process, apologized for failing to secure consensus amid strong disagreements. Over 20 years, more than 20,000 women in Scotland have received mesh or tape implants, with over 400 currently taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, 23, ran 14:49.12 at Glasgow’s Emirates Arena to break Liz McColgan’s 25-year-old record by 14 seconds. McColgan had questioned whether the attempt met UK Athletics’ criteria—saying it should be a genuine race since Muir was effectively the only 5K competitor in a mixed 3K race and raising drug-testing concerns—but British Athletics said the time is expected to be ratified and noted rules do not require athlete drug tests if no event doping control was in place. Praising Muir as world class with the ability to win medals, McColgan said a 3:55 1500m runner like her could run about 14:30 and has more to come. She likened Muir’s solo, lapping run to her own record effort, when she lapped a young Paula Radcliffe two or three times, and welcomed having her record beaten by a fellow Scot. Muir also recently broke her own British 1500m record in Paris and reached the 1500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Jung won aboard Sam, a late replacement after Fischertakinou contracted an infection in July; France’s Astier Nicolas took silver, American Phillip Dutton won bronze, and GB’s William Fox-Pitt finished 12th. Fox-Pitt, 47, competing just 10 months after being placed in an induced coma following a fall, produced a faultless final show-jumping round on Chilli Morning, but after leading the dressage he incurred several cross-country time penalties that dropped him to 21st; Ireland’s Jonty Evans was ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Andy Murray, 30, beat 29th seed Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in two hours 39 minutes, clinching match point at 20:57 BST to reach the last 16 for the 11th time, and will face Benoit Paire on Monday. In an up-and-down contest, Fognini recovered after a poor first set, was later hampered by an ankle issue, received a point penalty for a visible obscenity, and benefited from Murray’s double fault to lead 5-2 in the fourth, but Murray saved five set points and won five straight games to close it out as fading light threatened the need for the roof. Murray said he was pleased to finish in four and will work on his movement before Monday. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta reached the second week for the first time by defeating Maria Sakkari 6-4 6-1.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014; police arriving soon after found people still inside and till receipts showing alcohol served until 04:49, prompting a judge to order the bar’s closure for three months. License holder Colleen O’Neill, 43, of Kevin Lynch Park, was charged with two counts of allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours and fined £3,000, while James Thomas, 44, of the same address, faced one count and was fined £1,000. A defence solicitor admitted licensing laws were not strictly followed and the bar ran into the morning; the judge condemned O’Neill’s “appalling record,” called it as bad a case as he had seen, and noted he lacked power to impose a custodial sentence.

At the Ulster Unionist Party manifesto launch, Mike Nesbitt said “Domination doesn’t work, partnership does,” framing the election as a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal and its £85,000‑a‑day cost, and condemning 10 years of DUP–Sinn Féin rule as marked by “incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption.” Amid controversy over his remarks about transferring to the SDLP and his preference for partnering with the SDLP rather than Sinn Féin at Stormont, he denied any regrets, urged voters to back UUP first then any candidate who will “do the right thing,” and reported little criticism on unionist doorsteps. He responded lightly to colleague Danny Kennedy’s public distancing and said he was relaxed about differing candidate positions on transfers. The “Real Partnership” manifesto pledges action on waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritising the York Street interchange, standing up for the LGBT community, guaranteeing no group is worse off because of Brexit, and includes a “Cleaning Up Stormont” section, with Nesbitt hoping this message eclipses the row over his SDLP transfer comments.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has secured executive agreement to bring a legislative consent motion before the Northern Ireland Assembly to pardon convictions for now-abolished sexual offences, aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales’ “Turing’s Law.” The proposals would provide posthumous pardons and allow living men—specifically gay and bisexual men—to apply for pardons, with arrangements to be introduced as soon as possible to ensure equal treatment. Sugden said this approach seeks to right past wrongs and offers a quicker resolution than an assembly bill, and the motion will now go forward for assembly consideration.

Laura Muir, 23, from Kinross, ran 4:19.12 to finish second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon, breaking Yvonne Murray’s 1994 Scottish mile record of 4:22.60 and moving to second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd’s 4:17.57. The fifth-place finisher at last year’s World Championships, Muir now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records and said she was pleased with her first race of the season over the distance; Murray sent congratulations via Facebook. She aims to secure a Rio Olympic place at the British trials in Birmingham from 24 to 26 June, having opened her season with an 800m win in Montbeliard and with a 1500m race in Stockholm next week. Muir balances training with her veterinary studies and has completed her fourth year of vet school.
Presents some of your photos from the 26 Scottish beaches that have been ranked as “most excellent” for water quality.

At a UK inquiry into Alexander Litvinenko’s 2006 death, Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argued that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive and that the Russian state likely sponsored the killing, citing the use of polonium-210—administered in tea during their meeting—which left a “trail of polonium” and indicates state involvement, though not necessarily on President Putin’s orders. He outlined possible motives including Litvinenko’s 2000 defection after accusing the FSB of murder and corruption and his personal attacks on Putin, said Litvinenko was poisoned twice and died nearly three weeks later, and warned the public health impact of polonium exposure in London may never be known. Despite UK officials’ belief the suspects carried out the poisoning, they deny wrongdoing, remain in Russia after failed extradition attempts, and are unlikely to face trial; Kovtun was criticized by inquiry chair Sir Robert Owen for not giving evidence. The inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed Australia’s Test captain after Michael Clarke, 34, confirmed his retirement following a heavy Ashes defeat at Trent Bridge that put England 3-1 up. Already leading the one-day side, Smith will also captain the Twenty20 team in injured Aaron Finch’s absence, with David Warner, 28, named vice-captain. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith’s talent and leadership and said Warner has matured despite past disciplinary issues. Smith previously captained three Tests against India during Clarke’s injury layoff and has 2,952 runs at 54.66 from 32 Tests. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test at The Oval starting 20 August.
