After winning the leadership over Norman Lamb, Mr Farron repeatedly declined to say whether homosexual sex is a sin, saying instead that “we are all sinners.” He insisted he is “passionate about LGBT-plus rights,” putting defense of equal marriage and its extension at the top of his agenda, including addressing transgender people’s unequal access to marriage due to the “spousal veto.” Questioned about his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill, which would have made it harder for businesses to discriminate against gay people, he said the Lib Dems had proposed an amendment over “protection of individual liberties” and, when that was defeated, he voted against the bill; he did not specify those concerns but maintained support for equal legal access for all regardless of sexuality.

After Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015 with the loss of 450 jobs, Accord Healthcare will take over the plant for pharmaceutical production, aiming to rehire many former Sanofi staff. The company expects the investment to have an extremely positive local impact, and Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes called it fantastic news that strengthens the region’s science and healthcare reputation while bringing skilled jobs and long-term investment. Accord Healthcare is a global firm that develops, manufactures and distributes more than 130 pharmaceutical products to about 60 countries.

Three senior council officials are leaving: Richard Ellis departs Friday at the end of his contract; Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Ellis has been the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive; Monaghan is head of the chief executive’s office; Sutherland is head of human resources and customer services. Opposition SNP leader Stephen Flynn said the exits show the council’s inability to retain senior staff and predicted more departures, while council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the trio for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants stormed Kabul’s 400-bed Sardar Daud hospital after blowing open its gate, shooting staff and patients; Afghan special forces landed on the roof and, after more than six hours, killed all four attackers. Islamic State claimed responsibility while the Taliban denied involvement; more than 50 people were wounded, and President Ashraf Ghani and Abdullah Abdullah condemned the attack. Beginning at 09:00 local time, the assault marked IS’s first direct engagement with security forces in the capital and used Taliban-style tactics, suggesting increased resources and training and raising fears of more such operations. Since declaring its Khorasan Province in 2015, IS has struggled to expand beyond eastern strongholds near Pakistan and has pursued headline-grabbing attacks in Kabul—previously targeting Shia gatherings and the Supreme Court—while the Taliban has continued its own deadly campaign.

After crashing at this year’s TT and struggling with a problematic Honda Fireblade, Martin told MCN he was quitting road racing, then clarified he hasn’t given up racing but has no plans to do more road racing on Hondas this year. He skipped the North West 200 after team-mate John McGuinness’s practice crash and will not race at next month’s Ulster Grand Prix. Calling the TT a “bloody disaster” that turned him into a test rider, he said post-Cadwell testing showed the bike wouldn’t be competitive; the team withdrew him from the Ulster GP. He feels no unfinished business and wants to race classics and oddball stuff.

Nigeria’s All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 declared governorships, cementing the Peoples Democratic Party’s (PDP) biggest setback since 1999 and following its first presidential loss; APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who defeated President Goodluck Jonathan, is due to be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP lost key northern states including Katsina, Kaduna (home of outgoing Vice-President Namadi Sambo), and Adamawa, but retained Rivers, and won eight governorships mostly in the south-east; Taraba’s result was pending and Imo’s poll was inconclusive due to spoiled ballots, while seven states did not vote. Analysts say the APC made historic gains—dominating most northern states and retaining Lagos—while the PDP’s strength was largely confined to the south-east and Niger Delta; however, the APC failed to win any of the five oil-producing states, raising concerns that militants could disrupt oil output and federal revenue, with PDP governors there unlikely to assist Buhari. The Independent National Electoral Commission recorded 66 violent incidents, mainly in southern states such as Rivers, prompting extended voting in some areas, though the overall process was more peaceful than in previous years. With Nigeria’s 36 governors wielding significant power and large budgets, these outcomes are highly consequential; APC control of Lagos means the president’s party will govern the commercial capital for the first time since 1999, while the PDP faces rebuilding after defections, corruption allegations, and criticism over its handling of the Islamist insurgency.

A US environmental group, Mighty, alleges that Singapore-based Olam and majority owner Temasek enable unsustainable palm oil trading by creating a secretive market that sources largely from unknown suppliers, potentially contributing to the annual haze caused by slash-and-burn in Indonesia; both firms deny this. Olam says it buys 99% of its palm oil from third parties, represents under 1% of the global market, and enforces a no-burn, no-peat, no-deforestation policy; after earlier resistance it disclosed 14 suppliers, says they meet its standards, admits full verification will take years, and pledges to drop violators. Temasek dismisses the claims, backs no-burn policies, and says it does not direct portfolio companies, though Mighty argues its stake means Singaporeans have unwittingly financed an opaque channel for unsustainably produced palm oil and could link the state fund to haze if proven. The report sets this in an industry projected at $88bn by 2022 that faces allegations of labor abuses and environmental damage; NGOs call for tougher penalties while executives say policing third-party suppliers is impractical and governments hesitate to act because firms bring jobs and investment. Mighty also accuses Olam of clearing rainforest in Gabon for monoculture plantations; Olam replies that its public–private projects responsibly and transparently convert only a tiny share of less valuable forest, with plans published.

On 27 August 2016 (12:34 BST), a restaurant began serving “puppy platters” after a new law allowed dogs to eat at restaurants as long as they were outdoors, and the piece invites viewers to check out a related clip.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is a doubt with a knee issue after only featuring from the bench in the last two games, Derby County striker David Nugent could return from a groin problem after missing Monday’s draw with Huddersfield, and midfielder Jacob Butterfield is seeking a recall after coming off the bench to score a late leveller against the Terriers.

Pakistan’s telecom regulator said the YouTube ban was no longer necessary after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version and directed all ISPs to restore access, a move many young Pakistanis welcomed while activists demanded details of the deal with Google and greater transparency of agreed terms; PTCL posted “Welcome Back YouTube.” The IT ministry said Google provided a web process for the PTA to request blocking of offending material for users in Pakistan, but YouTube denied that authorities can filter content or that government requests are automatic, saying removals follow community guidelines or, where content is illegal locally, access may be restricted after review, with requests logged in its Transparency Report. The ban had been imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 after the film Innocence of Muslims sparked protests that killed more than a dozen people; blasphemy is a crime in Pakistan and can carry the death penalty, though none has been carried out. Google also recently launched local YouTube versions for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Liberian FA boss Musa Bility is demanding that FIFA Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee head Domenico Scala, who shares Swiss-Italian nationality with candidate Gianni Infantino, withdraw from overseeing the 26 February presidential election, citing conflict-of-interest rules and threatening to go to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not step down by Thursday. Bility notes that ahead of the May 2015 vote between Sepp Blatter and Prince Ali, Scala and fellow Swiss committee member Claudio Sulser recused themselves to avoid the appearance of a nationality-based conflict. Scala’s spokesman Andreas Bantel counters that FIFA’s regulations do not deem shared nationality a conflict, and that Scala withdrew previously only because the Swiss candidate was the incumbent President; with five non-incumbent candidates now, there is no conflict. Bility, barred from running after failing eligibility checks, has endorsed Prince Ali. The five candidates are Prince Ali, Infantino, Jerome Champagne, Bahrain’s Sheikh Salman, and South Africa’s Tokyo Sexwale, with 209 member associations voting in Zurich.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, died shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working at Harford Attachments in Spar Road, believed to be in a paint-spraying area; their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search was conducted at the company, which manufactures digger buckets, and Det Ch Insp Paul Durham reported “significant progress” with forensic inquiries and witness statements. Evidence indicates a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition, creating a fireball, and the Health and Safety Executive, along with electrical safety experts, is gathering evidence.

Morocco and Tunisia secured their places in 2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualifying after resolving disputes with Caf: Morocco’s ban for refusing to host the 2015 finals over Ebola concerns was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, which also reduced its FA’s fine from $1m to $50,000, while Tunisia avoided expulsion by apologising for complaints following a 2015 quarter-final where a highly contentious 90th-minute penalty helped hosts Equatorial Guinea overturn Tunisia’s lead and win 2-1 in extra time; Tunisia said they never alleged corruption, only poor referee selection, and a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou repaired relations. Equatorial Guinea hosted the 2015 tournament with 64 days’ preparation. In the 2017 qualifying draw, Tunisia face Togo, Liberia and Djibouti (Group A) and Morocco meet Cape Verde, Libya and Sao Tome (Group F); if Tunisia reach the finals in Gabon, it would be their record 13th consecutive Nations Cup.

After a mass fracas in the 95th minute of Chelsea’s 3-1 win at Etihad Stadium, both clubs were charged and must respond by 18:00 GMT on 8 December. Manchester City had Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho sent off, while Chelsea’s Cesc Fabregas will face no further action; City manager Pep Guardiola apologised for his team’s part. Aguero, 28, received a four-match ban for his second dismissal for violent conduct this season following a high, late challenge on David Luiz, and Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban for clashing with Fabregas in the ensuing scuffle.

Wales, which has some of the poorest cancer survival rates in the developed world, is launching a six‑month pilot in Cwm Cynon and Neath for patients whom GPs suspect may have cancer but who lack urgent symptoms, to cut delays caused when such cases don’t fit standard pathways and are bounced between multiple tests over weeks. Inspired by Danish diagnostic centers observed a year ago—credited with improving Denmark’s outcomes—Cwm Taf will allow 40 GPs to refer patients within seven days to a diagnostic hub at Royal Glamorgan Hospital, Llantrisant, expecting about six patients a week to receive multiple tests, ideally on the same day. Currently only 35% of patients with “concerning” symptoms receive a diagnosis in Cwm Taf. A parallel clinic will open at Neath Port Talbot Hospital. Leaders say the scheme will reassure patients and speed diagnosis; if successful, other health boards will adopt it.

England crushed Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare to level the four-match series, securing their second-biggest win over Pakistan by runs after declaring at 589-8 and 173-1. Joe Root, promoted to No. 3, was man of the match for 254 and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls, plus four catches and a wicket; Alastair Cook added 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan were bowled out for 198 and 234, batting only 63 and 70 overs on a pitch offering little help to bowlers. Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott hailed England’s dominant, disciplined display (though Vaughan expects a tight series), while coach Trevor Bayliss praised Root’s response to earlier errors. Misbah-ul-Haq called Pakistan’s showing a disappointment, citing poor shot selection and low confidence, noting only he and Asad Shafiq have passed 50 so far, and looked to regroup before a two-day game against Worcestershire ahead of the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August.

With Warren Gatland leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand and naming interim coach Rob Howley in his backroom team, Wales forwards coach Robin McBryde will assume Wales’ head coach role for the summer tour—his third stint after leading tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde called it an honor and an exciting opportunity he has enjoyed before. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches to support him and expects to confirm the full management team soon, said chief executive Martyn Phillips. WRU chairman Gareth Davies, also on the Lions selection panel, said Welsh coaches’ involvement in the Lions is a major development opportunity that will benefit Welsh rugby, with the New Zealand tour providing a stimulating, ultimate test.

Hull City came from behind to beat Southampton 2-1 at the KCOM Stadium, ending a six-game league losing streak for their first league win since 20 August, though they remain in the bottom three before the international break. Charlie Austin’s sixth-minute penalty, awarded after Curtis Davies fouled Maya Yoshida, put Saints ahead, and Hull then lost strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries. Substitute Robert Snodgrass transformed the game, equalising on 61 minutes from Sam Clucas’ cross and, two minutes later, delivering the free-kick that Michael Dawson headed past Fraser Forster. Southampton pressed—Virgil van Dijk hit the bar, David Marshall saved repeatedly from Austin and Yoshida, Dawson made a key block, and Clucas produced a stoppage-time goalline clearance—to preserve the win. In front of a sparse 17,768 crowd amid unrest over the Allam family, Hull boss Mike Phelan lauded his players, praised Marshall and Snodgrass (who recovered from a swollen ankle), and welcomed the break after more injuries, while Claude Puel cited a loss of concentration and the demands of playing after Europe. After the break, Hull visit Sunderland on 19 November and Southampton host leaders Liverpool.

A crash at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton near Woodhall Spa left a locally resident motorcyclist dead, while the tractor driver was uninjured; Lincolnshire Police have released no further details, are appealing for witnesses, and closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into alleged abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, saying he wanted to “put an end to the agony” ahead of early June elections, a move condemned by opposition leader Zoran Zaev and EU officials. Ivanov said he acted to defend national interests; Zaev called the decision illegal and urged protests, leading hundreds to gather outside the prosecutor’s office. EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn said the action conflicted with the rule of law and jeopardized Macedonia’s EU prospects. The crisis stems from recordings released since February 2015 that appear to show ministers plotting vote-rigging and a murder cover-up; Zaev has alleged mass wiretapping of 20,000 people and widespread corruption, while the government denies the claims and accuses him of trying to destabilize the country, which he rejects.

After Bob Bradley’s sacking, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead Swansea against Bournemouth while the club seeks a swift appointment, with ex-Derby boss Paul Clement their preferred choice. Curtis says Swansea need someone to steer them out of trouble and warns relegation would make an immediate return difficult given a stronger Championship, noting Newcastle’s advantage in retaining players—something Swansea might not match. He recalls Swansea’s 2011 Premier League promotion after a near-bankruptcy and 2003 survival, lauds past eras under Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers and Michael Laudrup, and argues the club has lost its “Swansea Way” through managerial churn and inadequate replacements for departed players. Despite this, he believes the current squad can stay up and ensures new signings understand the club’s journey—often via the “Jack to a King” documentary—and the importance of survival to the club and area.

Leyton Orient relegated Dagenham & Redbridge with a late winner from Armand Gnanduillet after Jay Simpson put Orient 2-0 up and Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona briefly gave the Daggers hope; the result keeps Orient two points off the play-offs just four days after player‑manager Kevin Nolan was removed, with interim boss Andy Hessenthaler emphasizing professionalism and responsibility to fans. Dagenham, who entered the Football League in 2007 and reached League One in 2010 under John Still, return to the National League having posted League Two’s worst goal difference, conceded 20 more goals than at this stage last season, and struggled in attack (40‑year‑old Cureton has nine goals versus 20 in 2014‑15). Still, back for a third spell since December, committed to leading a promotion bid and criticized his side’s lack of organization and discipline.

Former Reds captain Gerrard, 36, will return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February in his first job since retiring in November after a 19-year career. Klopp said he had a good long chat with him, called the appointment “wonderful news,” noted Gerrard wants to be a manager and is ready to learn, and predicted a bright future. Gerrard debuted for Liverpool in 1998, left at the end of the 2014-15 season for LA Galaxy, and won the Champions League, Uefa Cup, FA Cup and, on three occasions, the League Cup. He had been linked with the MK Dons manager’s job but felt it came too soon, and he is working toward his Uefa A coaching licence, required to manage in the Premier League.

Morton beat Alloa 4-1 at home: McManus opened the scoring on the quarter-hour and Ross Forbes’ deflected strike quickly made it 2-0; Kyle McAusland pulled one back before half-time, but another McManus finish and a late goal from Denny Johnstone sealed a comfortable win for the hosts.

Ofsted found children being taught in squalid conditions at three unregistered sites in Birmingham, which have been closed with local council help, and has visited a total of 18 unregulated schools in recent months, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands. Owners of the three Birmingham sites are under investigation for running illegal schools, an offense that can carry up to 51 weeks in jail. While any setting teaching children more than 20 hours a week must register as a school, ministers are consulting on tighter regulation for places teaching more than 6–8 hours a week amid concerns that some part-time or “flexi” education centers are exploiting home-education rules. Chief Inspector Sir Michael Wilshaw warned these cases are likely the “tip of the iceberg,” citing risks of abuse or radicalization, and criticized officials for slow, confusing responses that suggested proprietors could apply to register. The government has funded a six-inspector team to investigate illegal schools and emphasized enforcement will apply to all religious groups, not only Muslim settings. The education secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare prosecution cases against unregistered schools, for which her consent is required, and the consultation on further regulation runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, launches amid proposals for the region’s first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes says there’s exciting potential to make the Scottish Borders a “region of distilling excellence,” noting their tiny scale—one of the smallest production stills in the UK housed in a cowshed—and an aim to capture the Teviot valley’s wild foods and Borders “terroir.” John Henderson of Born in the Borders says the gin distillery complements the on-site Scottish Borders Brewery, represents hosting the first new distillery in the Borders in nearly 200 years, and aligns with an ethos of local sourcing through Borders botanicals. The gin is named after Lilliard, the heroine of the nearby 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor, reflecting the landscape and the strong female production team.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam died at Swithens Farm in Rothwell, near Leeds, when Gary Green, 51, of Bradburn Road, Wakefield, reversed a tractor into him at about 09:15; Leeds Crown Court heard Green was more than twice the legal alcohol limit and must have consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 02:00. Because the incident occurred on private land, Green was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law; he admitted failing to ensure the safety of others and was jailed for 16 months and two weeks. A Health and Safety Executive investigation found the victim had been walking toward a worker in a closed-off area when Green reversed, behavior an inspector called reckless. Harry’s mother, Pam Whitlam, who worked at the farm’s cafe, said the close-knit family had been changed forever, condemned drunk driving on any land, and hoped they could now remember the good times they shared with Harry.

Uruguay striker Luis Suárez, 27, who joined Barcelona for £75m, had his FIFA punishment for biting Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini “generally confirmed” by CAS, but the court ruled an all‑activity ban excessive, allowing him to train, play in friendlies, attend matches and do promotional work while remaining barred from “organised” competitive games. Barcelona said he will train with the first team on Friday and be presented Monday at the Camp Nou, with his involvement against Club León undecided; his competitive Barça debut is likely at Real Madrid on 26 October. He must still serve the remaining eight matches of his nine‑game international ban but is available for Uruguay friendlies against Japan, South Korea and Saudi Arabia. FIFPro criticized the unchanged lengths and lack of mandated treatment, while Suárez’s lawyers called the outcome a success; he later apologized and has prior bans for biting and for racially abusing Patrice Evra.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a carrying race, beating Lithuania’s Vytautas Kirkliauskas, who was carrying his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene; Blake-Smith said a week of training paid off and that they were pushed hard by the Lithuanians. Competitors tackled a 380-metre course with haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols, and entrants did not need to be married, with pairings including men carrying women or men, and one woman carrying a woman. Rich and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Transport minister Stephen Hammond told Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that when paper car tax discs are scrapped and replaced by an electronic system in October 2014—allowing monthly direct debit payments—DVLA job roles will change, with fewer refunds and new processes requiring training, but any reduction in work will be handled through redeployment to growth areas rather than redundancies. Hedges, who had sought clarification after concerns for the 5,000 DVLA staff arose following the Autumn Statement, welcomed the assurances, acknowledging fewer job opportunities but endorsing the benefits of direct debit and no tax disc, and expressing confidence that the response would reassure DVLA employees.

Mr Szijjarto told Reuters the EU should not interfere in Hungary’s “domestic issues” and said Poland would veto any move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights, a sanction that requires unanimous approval. The EU objects to Hungary’s tight controls on asylum seekers, its Higher Education Law, and planned NGO legislation: Hungary is forcibly housing asylum seekers in secured shipping containers; the Higher Education Law signed in April could force the closure of Budapest-based Central European University, founded by George Soros and ranked among the top 200 in eight disciplines; and rights groups say the NGO bill would stigmatise them as “foreign-backed.” Despite mass protests, Szijjarto said Hungary would not backtrack, while Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s Fidesz government faces sustained EU pressure to withdraw the measures, with Frans Timmermans warning of action if there are no positive developments; two of the three laws have already been passed.

A new Beauty and the Beast film has cast a star as Mrs Potts (originally voiced by Angela Lansbury), with Kevin Kline as Maurice, Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou; directed by Bill Condon (Dreamgirls and the last two Twilight films), it begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

Adrian (A.A.) Gill, the Sunday Times columnist who revealed last month he had the “full English” of cancers and was undergoing chemotherapy, has died; editor Martin Ivens called him the paper’s “heart and soul” and “a giant among journalists,” with his final column on coming to terms with his diagnosis to appear tomorrow. Known for dazzling, fearless prose and dictating copy by phone due to dyslexia, he was also frequently controversial, notably for describing shooting a baboon in Tanzania, derogatory comments about the Welsh, Rhyl, Norfolk and the Isle of Man, and a 2010 censure for calling Clare Balding a “dyke on a bike”; he was once ejected from a Gordon Ramsay restaurant. Tributes came from Jay Rayner, Tim Shipman, Stig Abell, John Witherow, Andrew Neil and Piers Morgan. Born in Edinburgh in 1954, he was educated at St Christopher School, Central Saint Martins and the Slade, began with art reviews in the 1980s, wrote for Tatler, and joined the Sunday Times in 1993. His personal life included marriages to Cressida Connolly (1983) and Amber Rudd (1991), with whom he had two children, Flora and Alistair; he later had twins, Edith and Isaac, with long-term partner Nicola Formby, whose engagement he announced during his illness, and whom he often called “The Blonde” in his reviews.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar (Amraa), lead singer of Khar Sarnai (Black Rose), was allegedly assaulted in Ulan Bator by a Russian diplomatic officer during a performance while wearing a red deel embroidered with a swastika, a symbol with long-standing, non-Nazi meaning in Mongolia; Russian reports said he was hit with a bottle and kicked. His father says he was struck with a metal object, suffered serious brain injuries, and spent about 10 days in a coma, while police say the injury was not serious and that the suspect was not detained for that reason, denying diplomatic immunity played a role. The Russian embassy, which has not identified the suspect, says press and social media accounts are distorted but is investigating. The musician’s lawyer, father, and a bandmate deny claims he shouted “Heil Hitler,” noting he often uses the symbol to reference Mongolian history and identity (though it is also used by far-right groups), and call for an investigation under Mongolian law; police say the case is ongoing.

Campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid staged a protest on the airport’s northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday to oppose its expansion plans. Police charged the men and women involved with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted area of an aerodrome, and they are due in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police said airport security will be reviewed.

In cloudy Cardiff conditions where bowlers dominated, Glamorgan’s innings was anchored by Nick Selman’s 101 off 144 balls—his second first-class century after being dropped on 8—with Aneurin Donald’s brisk 36 the next best and late contributions from Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten scraping a consolation bonus point; Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets, Taylor pleased to hit the stumps three times and saying they’d take bowling Glamorgan out for 220, while Gloucestershire then had to battle for survival in evening gloom, leaving the day evenly balanced; Selman welcomed a return to form after four ducks since his Swansea hundred and highlighted the challenges of opening on green wickets, and Glamorgan were captained for the first time by Michael Hogan in Jacques Rudolph’s absence with a neck problem.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after telling Tennessee’s Hope Line Crisis Centre he planned to make a false report to lure officers to the Dee Estuary and shoot them; he admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and was remanded by Judge Niclas Parry pending sentencing next week. The threats were made twice late at night while he was drunk. Police concerns were heightened because he was then on bail for firearms offences (later cleared) and had a 2009 conviction for possessing a firearm. His legal team said he had not intended to kill himself and would not have carried out the threats. The Hope Line centre offers confidential support to people in difficulty.

Surrey recovered from 8-2 to 255-7 thanks to a 130-run stand between Davies and Ben Foakes (90), after early losses of Dominic Sibley and Kumar Sangakkara (4); Matthew Waite took 3-48 but dropped Davies on 43 and later a tougher return chance from Foakes. Yorkshire, seeking to bounce back from a T20 Blast semi-final loss and reach Lord’s for the first time since 2002, were well placed at 75-2 before Stuart Meaker’s nine-ball burst (3-61) removed Jonny Bairstow (13), Gary Ballance and Jack Leaning. Despite Tim Bresnan’s 68 and Waite’s 38, 27 off the final three overs proved too much; Yorkshire were all out for 236, 19 short, with Bresnan holing out with seven balls left. Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised the decisive Davies–Foakes partnership and timely wickets, while Yorkshire’s Alex Lees said their bowlers set a reachable target but the top five didn’t contribute.

A 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler, located 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST because it was taking on water and its onboard pump couldn’t cope; the RNLI lifeboat crew provided an additional pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss next year’s Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her final-year veterinary medicine studies and May exams conflict with the April event; she’s disappointed but is prioritizing completing her degree as she returns to university next week. She finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m (won by Hellen Obiri, with Sifan Hassan third), and after five races in 10 days said she’s pleased and sees strong potential ahead. Muir may target the World Indoor Championships in March in Birmingham and believes she has two or three more Olympics in her.

Robbie Savage argues Liverpool are far from last season’s title-challenging level, having overachieved then and now facing a fight just to make the top four, which should count as success despite fan criticism of Brendan Rodgers. He faults the striker recruitment after Luis Suarez’s sale and Daniel Sturridge’s injuries (they scored 52 of 101 league goals last season), saying Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert and Fabio Borini lack goals and work-rate, blunting Liverpool’s pressing and fast starts (59 first-half league goals last season versus four in the first 10 this season) and seeing a dramatic drop in set-piece goals (over a third in 2013-14). Defensively they are no better despite heavy spending (£18m on Mamadou Sakho, £20m on Dejan Lovren) and a non-commanding Simon Mignolet. He backed resting players at Real Madrid; Liverpool can still progress by winning their last two group games. For Chelsea he suggests Mignolet; Johnson, Skrtel, Toure, Moreno; Can, Gerrard; Sterling, Coutinho, Lallana; Borini, with alternating full-back raids, but predicts a Chelsea win. Despite April’s slip and an uncertain contract, Steven Gerrard remains vital in a deep role and, though aging poses mental and physical challenges, his desire endures; at his peak, Savage calls him the Premier League’s best midfielder.

East Ayrshire Council plans a £45m education campus at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, comprising primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre, and will seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name it after Kilmarnock-born writer William McIlvanney; council leader Douglas Reid said this would preserve McIlvanney’s name and reflect his passion for good education. McIlvanney, an English teacher after graduating from Glasgow University, became a full-time writer in 1975, gained immediate recognition with his debut novel Remedy Is None, was dubbed the “Godfather of Tartan Noir,” wrote the Laidlaw trilogy and Glasgow-based works including Docherty and The Big Man, and was also an influential poet, journalist and broadcaster who contributed to Scotland’s political and sporting life through columns and TV programmes; he died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

A suspected British sea mine from the 1940s–50s spotted on Monday prompted the evacuation of three streets near a swimming pool in Gourock for most of the morning and early afternoon, with wider safety advice for residents within 500m to stay indoors and keep windows open. An exclusion zone remains on the river and about half a mile at sea, with small boat owners told not to sail, and Caledonian MacBrayne reported ferry disruptions affecting sailings from Gourock and Rothesay. Police said the evacuation was precautionary and there was no immediate danger, while the Royal Navy’s Northern Diving Unit noted the mine’s deterioration made its explosive content uncertain, so it would be moved to a safer location before being dealt with. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience.

UK Sport will invest £345m in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020—£2m less than for Rio—setting medal targets of 51–85 Olympic and 115–162 Paralympic medals (compared with 67 and 147 at Rio 2016). Cycling’s funding falls by over £4m to £25.98m, while archery, fencing, weightlifting and wheelchair rugby miss out entirely. Badminton, despite a Rio bronze from Marcus Ellis and Chris Langridge and a previous £5.74m allocation, loses all funding—the only podium sport to do so—prompting sharp criticism from Badminton England; judo, also a single-bronze sport with the same prior target, receives a slight increase. UK Sport leaders say prioritizing medal potential is essential to maintain success, a stance backed by the sports minister. Team sports bodies for basketball, volleyball and handball—previously defunded—accuse UK Sport of neglecting team disciplines and passing responsibility to others. Funding for sports newly added to Tokyo (baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing, surfing, plus Para-taekwondo and Para-badminton) is undecided pending medal-potential reviews, with £9m still unallocated.

Bournemouth councillors voted 7-3 to approve demolishing three Victorian hotels—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood and the Ocean View—on Grove Road and East Overcliff Drive at East Cliff to build a six-storey, four-star, 90-room hotel and two assisted-living blocks (nine and seven storeys, totaling 122 apartments). The East Cliff Project LLP is the applicant. English Heritage and the Ancient Monuments Society, along with 49 residents, objected, saying the scale would cause severe harm in the conservation area, but 246 letters supported the plan. Planning board chair David Kelsey said the existing buildings were no longer functional and argued the project would support tourism and improve accommodation for older people, acknowledging the loss of buildings and trees as regrettable.

Off-duty soldier Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, of the Royal Gibraltar Regiment and originally from Carrickfergus, was fatally attacked in Brecon in the early hours of 8 May while returning to barracks after a night out; CCTV showed 24-year-old Jake Vallely punching him outside The Cellar bar, beating him until motionless, then dragging his body away before fleeing after a seven-hour drinking binge during which he boasted he was the “hardest man in Brecon.” Boyd’s unconscious body was found by police, and Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter after a jury heard he had left before any violence. Det Supt David Guiney condemned the “despicable” attack and urged people to walk away from conflict, and Boyd’s family paid tribute to a loving “all-rounder” with a promising career, saying Vallely created an irreplaceable void and that the community’s support shows who the strongest people in Brecon are.

Andrew Travers left Barnet Council by mutual agreement after an election-day error saw voters initially turned away from all 155 polling stations because their names were missing from poll lists; at one station only three of the first 30 voters were on the register, with others told to return later. The council apologized, offered emergency proxy votes, and faced questions over the fairness of the result. Travers, who said electoral registration lists were to blame and expressed pride in changes and a growth program he believes will help the borough thrive, was praised by the council for his three-and-a-half-year contribution. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will take over temporarily. An independent investigation has been launched, and a council review—due to conclude by the end of May with findings presented publicly to the General Functions Committee—will assess the appropriateness of arrangements for the June EU Referendum, with the investigation lead still to be confirmed.

Gateshead beat Wrexham 2-1: Josh Gillies put the hosts ahead with a free-kick, Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham before half-time with another set-piece, and Ryan Bowman headed the winner from a right-wing cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby said his team improved their passing after a disappointing first half and praised the quality of the winning goal, while Wrexham’s Gary Mills lamented a weaker second-half display, being too open, and missed chances, noting Gateshead scored via a free-kick and a header.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measures the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries; as of 1 October 2014, Norway ranks first, while Afghanistan is last, followed by Mozambique.

Airbus and OneWeb are building a high-volume, low-cost satellite constellation to deliver global broadband—aiming to connect every school—with an initial 600 spacecraft and potential expansion beyond 2,000 at about 1,200 km altitude. Shifting from “gold‑plated” bespoke builds to assembly-line production, they target turning out three satellites per shift at under $1 million each, using new lines in Toulouse, France (now inaugurated), and two more in a forthcoming Florida factory, featuring automation like trolley robots and a scaled supplier network. The first 10 Toulouse satellites are slated to launch in April next year, another batch around November, and more than 20 Soyuz launches will place clusters of 32–36 satellites, aiming for just under 300 on station by late 2020/early 2021, over 600 about a year later, and 800+ by mid‑decade. Competing mega-constellation plans from SpaceX, Boeing, and ViaSat face financing hurdles; OneWeb cites first‑mover advantage, with $1.7bn in equity raised and loan talks ongoing. Registered in the UK’s Channel Islands, OneWeb will be licensed by the UK Space Agency and expects significant UK economic impact and regulatory leadership. Responding to debris concerns, OneWeb commits to de‑orbit satellites within two years—exceeding a five‑year guideline—adding hardware for reliability and an adapter to enable capture by a chase vehicle if needed. While the approach could reshape satellite manufacturing and serve other customers, bespoke, high-spec missions will still be required for certain applications.

Mr Swinney warned that the UK government’s recent spending review puts unprecedented pressure on Scotland’s finances, saying UK-imposed cuts since 2010 mean the Scottish government’s discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019–20 than in 2010–11, with 4.2% of that reduction and over £1bn of cuts still to come; ahead of presenting 2016–17 plans, he pledged not to sacrifice schools, hospitals or police and cited improved outcomes and a record health budget. He argued the deficit could have been reduced without such austerity. The UK government countered that Scotland will have £390m more to spend next year (£750m including underspend), with a block grant near £30bn, saying low oil prices show this is better than independence and urging focus on new powers. Labour’s Jackie Baillie accused Swinney of posturing, demanded a long-term budget, and promised a different tax approach from both the Conservatives and the SNP.

The passage highlights how many people with severe disabilities, and their families, face isolation when out because standard accessible toilets often lack the space and equipment (such as a hoist and a bench) needed by those requiring significant assistance. Changing Places toilets offer these enhanced facilities and are recommended for large venues but are not compulsory, prompting campaigns to make them mandatory. Lorna Fillingham has petitioned for changes to building regulations and submitted evidence to the Women and Equalities Committee, while Mencap estimates that over a quarter of a million people need such toilets; currently there are 893 in the UK. Families describe both the psychological toll of inadequate facilities and stopgaps like “pop-up” setups or using nearby city-centre sites. Although specifications are included as recommendations in BS 8300:2009, architects note these are often ignored; businesses cite space (12 m² vs 1.5 × 2.2 m) and cost constraints, especially in existing buildings, so campaigners emphasize requirements for new large complexes. Successful examples, such as Arsenal FC converting two toilets into one Changing Place with expert support, show feasibility and positive public impact.

A group of Italian consumers’ organisations filed a formal antitrust complaint to the European Commission alleging McDonald’s forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and fees, ties them to longer-than-average contracts that hinder switching, and leases premises at above-market rates, leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchised stores versus company-owned outlets. The SEIU and European unions, including the UK’s Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union, back the complaint, with SEIU’s Scott Courtney calling it an abuse of a dominant market position and urging an investigation. The Commission will study the submission and can open a probe if warranted. McDonald’s responded that it shares risks and rewards with licensees, supports franchisees, and that this model has long delivered strong opportunities and customer experiences. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald’s European restaurants, and McDonald’s received $9.27bn (£6.40bn) in worldwide franchised-restaurant revenues in 2014.

A #prayforjosh poster in Holywood by the A2 highlights a viral social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when a planned appendix operation at Belfast’s Royal Victoria Hospital led to the discovery and removal of a large primary cancer and five smaller growths. The hashtag began with Bangor Elim Church, where Josh’s father serves on the pastoral staff, and rapidly spread; one update was shared 948 times and seen by over 79,000 people. Senior pastor Gary Beattie expressed shock at the diagnosis and amazement at global support. A mystery donor funded a large billboard at Holywood playing fields, and Twitter activity—especially from Josh’s Bangor Grammar classmates—has amplified the now-global campaign as family and friends support his recovery.

A UK military estate reorganisation includes a proposed closure of Brecon Barracks, condemned by local Conservative MP Chris Davies, who cites its history since 1805 and launches a petition over concerns about local unemployment and potential harm to military tourism; the site employs about 85 civilian and 90 military staff, with jobs not thought at risk, and the Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school are unaffected. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon said Wales will gain a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, while Cawdor Barracks will close in 2024 and a Sennybridge storage depot in 2025. Labour’s Nia Griffith said restructuring the estate is right but warned closures will create uncertainty for many people’s livelihoods.

The House of Lords European Union Committee warns that the UK’s small fishing sector (about 0.5% of GDP, 12,000 fishers) must not be marginalised in Brexit talks, and that Britain may have to allow EU boats continued access to UK waters to secure zero‑tariff access to EU markets on which the largely export‑oriented industry depends; with most stocks shared with EU states and many fish eaten in Britain imported from the EU, the report urges retaining elements of the Common Fisheries Policy such as science‑based total allowable catches and continued international cooperation, and notes that leaving the CFP could split management across England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland; while industry figures remain optimistic—citing recent quota increases for plaice, haddock and prawns and hopes of controlling a 200‑mile exclusive economic zone for fairer shares and better, sustainable management—the government says it seeks maximum freedom to trade in the single market and will use Brexit to review fisheries to ensure fair quotas, sustainable stocks and a healthy marine environment.

Edward Snowden, a 29-year-old former CIA technical worker, identified himself as the source of leaks he called horrifying, while US intelligence chief James Clapper said they were extremely damaging. The documents suggest the NSA can collect chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking information, and that the government obtained millions of Verizon phone records including call duration, location, and both parties’ numbers. PRISM reportedly gives access to servers at Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube, and Apple to gather private posts, chats, and searches, though all deny involvement, its workings are unknown, and an expert argues access may be targeted and court-ordered rather than a broad backdoor. Officials including NSA Director Keith Alexander, President Obama, Senator Dianne Feinstein, and UK Foreign Secretary William Hague defended the programs as focused on suspects and vital to security. Data-protection laws mainly govern companies, whose policies typically allow sharing when legally required (e.g., Facebook), not government surveillance. Because user data is often stored in the US via cloud services, the Patriot Act and FISA can enable US access to foreign data with limited transparency; the EU expressed concern and said national judges arbitrate lawful transfers, GCHQ’s role is unconfirmed, and PRISM reportedly dates to 2007. There is no legal way to opt out of security monitoring, privacy advocates say PRISM confirms fears that the US can access much of the world’s data by default, and Snowden says he acted to oppose pervasive recording of people’s lives.

OpenAI, backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aims to advance digital intelligence for the broad benefit of humanity, conducting research free from financial obligations and unconstrained by the need to generate returns. While some scientists warn AI could threaten humanity—Musk calling it the biggest existential threat and Stephen Hawking cautioning it might redesign itself and surpass humans—other experts view the risk as remote. OpenAI acknowledges human-level AI could bring vast benefits or harm if misused, asserts AI should extend individual human wills and be broadly, safely distributed, and says only a tiny fraction of the $1bn pledged will be spent in the next few years.

Doncaster-based L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, severely injured in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack that caused a brain injury, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June, walking for nearly half an hour with an assistant supporting his arm and flanked by hundreds. Now speaking unaided, he spends 12 hours a day on rehab, walks with crutches, raises funds for military charities, and is patron of Pilgrim Bandits. After the torch event he received far more Facebook friend requests than the 5,000 limit allows; his page update drew 19,000 hits, thousands joined the Pilgrim Bandits website, and mail and email surged, leaving him elated, his mother Diane said. Facebook suggested he create a page or use the subscribe feature. The torch relay features 8,000 carriers over 8,000 miles in 70 days, culminating at London’s 27 July Olympic opening ceremony.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate was 15.0% (46.2 million people), unchanged after three years of increases, with 2010 marking a record high at 15.1%; real median household income fell 1.5%; the poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021 (£14,300); income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose 1.6%—the first annual rise since 1993; and the share of Americans without health insurance declined from 16.3% to 15.7%.

Jos Buttler, 25, has extended his Lancashire (Red Rose) contract until 2019 after joining from Somerset in 2013. A short-format specialist, he owns England’s three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball hundred against Pakistan last year. Coach Ashley Giles praised his talent, impact in Lancashire’s T20 Blast win at Edgbaston, and positive influence from international experience. After playing in the IPL with Mumbai Indians, Buttler will return for Friday’s T20 Blast home game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall—are moored in Portsmouth Harbour and are being disposed of, with interest registrations closed on 23 January; registered parties are finalizing bids, viewings are slated for late February and March, and a decision is expected in spring. The BBC understands no proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. The Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one ship to a UK recycler to test domestic capacity, while Portsmouth North MP Penny Mordaunt supports giving UK recyclers a chance but also wants at least one vessel saved, potentially as an artificial reef and diving attraction if it offers value and tourism benefits. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to achieve the best financial return and will not disclose bid details due to commercial sensitivity. Type 22 frigates evolved from anti-submarine specialists into versatile combatants with strong command and control capabilities and about 280 crew, and last year the carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold for scrap for £3m.

Since 1987 Fiji has faced persistent racial and political tensions that fueled instability and international isolation, including an indigenous-led coup overturning an Indian-dominated coalition, the introduction and later withdrawal of a constitution enshrining indigenous political supremacy, a 2000 coup in which the first ethnic Indian prime minister, his cabinet and several MPs were held hostage, and a bloodless military takeover in 2006—Fiji’s fourth coup in 20 years—events that damaged the economy, especially tourism, and its international reputation. Disputes over proposed amnesty for the 2000 coup participants lingered, and in 2009 Fiji was fully suspended from the Commonwealth for lack of democratic progress, only the second such suspension in its history. After agreeing in 2012 to hold free elections in 2014, Australia and New Zealand restored full diplomatic ties, and Fiji was readmitted to the Commonwealth following the vote. The population, concentrated on Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, is split between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians (descendants of Indian indentured laborers); once roughly equal in size, Indo-Fijian numbers declined after unrest, leaving indigenous Fijians a small majority, with minimal intermixing and deep informal segregation; small minorities include Chinese and Rotumans. Economically, the former British colony relies on sugar and tourism but is diversified into mining (gold, silver, limestone), services, and light manufacturing, yet persistent trade and budget deficits make it one of the world’s largest per capita aid recipients.

Syria’s Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad said the country is striving to meet its chemical weapons destruction timetable despite missing a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile, claiming one shipment was attacked twice and a second came under fire from “terrorist groups” en route to Latakia. He dismissed as “absolutely unacceptable” US criticism over barrel bombs in Aleppo and denied targeting civilians, while the Syrian Observatory reported 246 deaths (including 73 children) in five days from helicopter-dropped barrel bombs and the Aleppo Media Centre cited 14 deaths in Masaken Hanano with supporting footage. Conflicting reports surrounded Aleppo’s central prison: state media said an assault was thwarted; the Observatory and rebel sources said rebels freed hundreds and control the site, which holds about 3,000 detainees. Of roughly 1,300 tonnes of declared chemicals, the US says only 4% (30 tonnes) has left; the OPCW cites security delays; the US expressed concern; Russia urged transfer to the coast by 1 March, with full destruction due by end-June. Mekdad reaffirmed Syria’s commitments.
MODEL FAILED TO RETURN ANY OUTPUT

A celebrity known as PJS, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, is challenging a Court of Appeal decision to lift an anonymity ban preventing his identification in England and Wales over The Sun on Sunday’s plan to publish allegations of his extra-marital activities, including occasional encounters with AB since 2009 and a 2011 three-way with AB and CD. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant the appeal and, if granted, whether to allow or dismiss it, and has kept the interim injunction in place until the hearing concludes; earlier, the Court of Appeal had set deadlines for an application to the Supreme Court and temporarily barred publication. The case’s path saw the High Court refuse an injunction, two appeal judges then prohibit identification, and News Group Newspapers later seek to lift that ban, citing widespread publication in the US, Scotland and online. On Monday, the Court of Appeal found a permanent injunction unlikely because the allegations were so widely disseminated that confidentiality had probably been lost, noting that despite the claimant’s assiduous efforts to remove breaches, policing the internet had become a hopeless task.

Fosse Park, near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was bought in August for £345.5m; its new owners, Crown Estates, have met Blaby District Council to address potential planning questions and are preparing plans to improve parking, traffic congestion, the appearance of units, and the quality of common areas and facilities. Council leader Ernie White called Fosse Park a gateway from Blaby into the city and said improvements could replace the current view of “backs of sheds.” Crown Estates’ Paul Clarke said the site has become tired and emphasized prioritizing parking, congestion, and the spaces where people walk and park to make the location as good as possible.

Disney’s live-action Beauty and the Beast, originally slated for release in Malaysia on Thursday, was held for a content review due to an “exclusively gay moment.” The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) has approved the film with a minor edit to that scene and a P13 parental guidance classification, noting that release dates and venues are outside its jurisdiction; a new release date has not been announced, and cinemas are offering refunds to advance ticket buyers. In Muslim-majority Malaysia, homosexual activity is illegal, though the tourism minister called banning the film “ridiculous.” The review decision drew strong online criticism, including a widely shared tweet claiming a ban. Director Bill Condon said the moment involves LeFou grappling with feelings of lust and admiration for Gaston as a side-plot.

Southampton City Council says landlords letting to more than three unrelated people must obtain an HMO licence, but many are deterred by the ??1,000 cost despite fines of up to ??20,000, and it estimates about 1,500 unlicensed HMOs locally. Nationally, mandatory licensing targets houses of three storeys or more occupied by five or more unrelated people; in Southampton it applies in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood and Swaythling (Designation 1, 2013) and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook and Bassett (Designation 2, 2015). Shelter adviser Nadeem Khan reports frequent tenant worries about eviction and poor maintenance, linked to a shortage of affordable homes pushing people into unregulated rentals, with five or six related calls daily. The council says most landlords have cooperated, though a minority resist, and it has secured prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Following an election nearly two months ago that left Fine Gael with 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23 and Labour 7, no party has a majority and TDs have yet to elect a taoiseach. Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) want to avoid a second election; Martin says Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but not support a programme for government. The main sticking point is water charges: Fianna Fáil wants them abolished immediately, while Fine Gael supports their continued role, with a commission on Irish Water under consideration.

The Sorrento, a ferry owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, caught fire Tuesday afternoon on a car deck while en route to Valencia, about 27 km from Mallorca. After the blaze escalated, despite initial hopes to avoid abandonment, a full evacuation was ordered; passengers and crew moved to lifeboats and life rafts, were rescued by other ships, and ultimately boarded the ferry Puglia. At least three people were injured—one seriously—and were taken to hospital by helicopter. Multiple vessels, including two passenger ferries, responded, and distress signals were sent at 13:50 local time (11:50 GMT). The cause of the fire is unclear; rescued passengers were being returned to Palma de Mallorca with psychologists requested to provide counseling, and authorities warned the Sorrento might sink in its current position.

The Electoral Commission said 38 MPs had reported claims of people voting twice—a criminal offence with an unlimited fine—and, while finding little evidence for social media allegations, urged anyone with information to contact police. A record 46.8 million people were registered for the 8 June election with 68.7% turnout; applications spiked after the 18 April snap poll announcement and before the 22 May deadline, producing 2.9 million applications in six weeks. Between 1 December 2016 and 22 May, about 4.9 million applications led to only a 1.4 million net increase on the register, indicating many duplicates (estimated at 30–70% across areas), with big rises in student-heavy seats like Canterbury, Cambridge, Bristol West and Leeds Central. The watchdog blamed unlinked systems—the 381 local registers and the separate online service—which prevent collective cross-checking and burden administrators, and called for joined-up registers, clearer online guidance and a verification function (as used in Australia, New Zealand and the Republic of Ireland), plus requiring those registered in two seats to choose in advance where they will vote in general elections. Labour backed prosecuting double voting but warned against measures that would hinder young people and students or impose a blanket ban on dual registration needed for work or study.

Officials believe Lawrence Phillips, 40, died by suicide early Wednesday. A standout at the University of Nebraska and an NFL running back for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999, he was troubled on and off the field. After his NFL career he faced escalating legal problems, including convictions for driving his car into a group of teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend, leading to a prison term of more than 30 years. He had been placed in a cell alone after being accused of killing his former cellmate, Damion Soward, and a judge on Tuesday ruled there was enough evidence to try him in that death. The method of his suicide is unclear. His former Nebraska coach Tom Osborne said Phillips was intelligent with good qualities but struggled with anger and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official soldier-mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for good behaviour at a Chester event marking the regiment’s eighth year, with the honour awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams. He is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny, starting with the first Private Derby acquired in 1858 by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot, a tradition carried into the Mercian Regiment on its formation in 2007. Derby XXX joined in February 2014, has his own army number, is paid for rations, takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire, and has switched on Ashbourne’s Christmas lights and met Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial to the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool mounted a stunning 4-3 Europa League comeback against Borussia Dortmund at Anfield to reach the semi-finals, overturning a 0-2 deficit inside nine minutes and a further setback after Marco Reus scored; Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho and Mamadou Sakho leveled the tie before Dejan Lovren’s injury-time header won it. The match epitomized Jurgen Klopp’s “turn doubters into believers” ethos, echoing Istanbul 2005 and his “We decide when it’s over” mantra, in a fervent setting marked by an extended You’ll Never Walk Alone and a minute’s silence for the 27th Hillsborough anniversary, with Thomas Tuchel praising the stadium’s belief. Highlights included Origi’s rising form, Emre Can’s strong display before injury, and Coutinho’s creativity, while defensive vulnerabilities persisted, notably at left-back and in Sakho’s positioning. With Sevilla, Villarreal and Shakhtar comprising a strong last four, Liverpool’s run offers a path back to the Champions League, and Klopp has barred players from touching the “This Is Anfield” sign until they win a trophy.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, Mr Davis said the UK government would keep Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland updated, proposing monthly meetings and a two-way information flow so devolved administrations can voice their views as talks with Brussels are prepared; he called the meeting constructive and amicable and pledged to share thinking and work with them to implement the decision to leave the EU. Mr Russell welcomed involvement but said the UK’s strategic intentions remain unclear—particularly on remaining in the single market or customs union—urging greater transparency and stressing that single market membership is essential for Scotland’s prosperity. The UK government hopes the High Court ruling on triggering Article 50 will be overturned by the Supreme Court next month, while the Scottish government will oppose in the appeal, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe seeking to be heard.

At the University of Nottingham’s Sutton Bonington Campus, veterinary surgeon Dr Sandra Corr performs detailed joint exams on Daisy and 12 other cloned sheep, including four—Debbie, Denise, Diane, and Daisy—cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly, which, says lead researcher Prof Kevin Sinclair, makes them Dolly’s and the original ewe’s identical twin sisters. The intensively monitored flock is central to testing whether clones age normally or inherit “age‑memory” from adult donor cells that could accelerate senescence. Dolly died at six and a half from a lung virus and had osteoarthritis, prompting concerns about premature aging and the creation of more clones to investigate. The team has run exhaustive assessments—regular joint X‑rays and full‑body fMRI scans—focused on aging‑linked co‑morbidities: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. Results, with potentially profound implications for cloning, will be published next week; for now, the “dollies,” nearing nine to ten years old, appear in good health.

Unbeaten 4-7 favourite Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora by a length and three quarters from Vintage Folly on very soft ground after Gosden walked the course, giving both trainer and jockey a fifth win in the race; she will skip the longer Epsom Oaks—where stablemates Enable and Coronet are leading hopes—and head to Chantilly for France’s Oaks over a mile and a quarter, with Gosden pleased to have a month to prepare her after she previously beat Enable at Newbury. Dettori said the conditions were hard work and she’ll be better on faster ground. Tasleet (14-1) won the Duke of York Stakes for William Haggas under Jim Crowley, from Magical Memory and Comicas. Gosden is concerned about the ground for Cracksman in Thursday’s Dante Stakes and will walk the course before deciding, with the 16-day gap to the Derby another reason he may not run.

With 10 days until the EU referendum, sterling fell, briefly recovered, then slid again as the volatility index hit 2008-crisis levels; it was down 0.2% to $1.4226, 0.6% to 1.2605 euros, and 1% against the yen to just over 151, amid data showing lower odds of a Remain vote, two polls putting Leave ahead, Betfair cutting Remain’s implied probability to 68.5% from nearly 80%, and global economic worries. Analysts said polls would drive sharper moves and greater sterling volatility, hedge funds were short-selling, and traders put markets on full Brexit alert, with sterling down over 2% in two sessions. Stock markets weakened—Japan’s Nikkei fell 3.5%, Hong Kong 2.5%, and the FTSE 100 finished down 1.1% at 6,044.9, with Lloyds Banking Group off 4.2%. The Leave camp argued the pound had merely returned to March levels and that a weaker currency aids exporters; official data showed the UK trade deficit narrowed in April on higher exports.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-offs; after a six- or seven-hour journey they conceded after five minutes and lost to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games, while Braintree’s losing run reached three. Cowley told BBC Essex his team asked questions of a very good Barrow side and, despite the setback, praised their remarkable progress, noting they are a part-time team facing their toughest challenge to date, which they intend to embrace and enjoy.

Northern Ireland councils are gaining new powers—from off-street parking to tourism—with the most contentious change being that, from April 2015, elected councillors will take over most planning decisions from the central Planning Service. Supporters like Michael Corr of PLACE see this as a major opportunity for locally driven community and development plans, provided voters choose politicians with strong planning and regeneration expertise. Critics, notably Friends of the Earth, warn of risks of unfairness, politicized decision-making, and a return to past discrimination unless strict codes of conduct and robust transparency are enforced, especially given close ties between developers and political parties. They argue that greater disclosure of political donations is essential as planning powers carry financial consequences, though some politicians resist donor transparency on security grounds or say current thresholds are irrelevant; under recent legislation, the Northern Ireland Secretary will decide when to increase transparency on donations.

Teenie, a one-year-old cat from NiddryView, Winchburgh, was shot twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg—leading to amputation—and is now relearning to walk; owner Sarah Nisbett warned the attack endangered local children and urged anyone with information to contact police or the Scottish SPCA. The Scottish SPCA called Teenie “incredibly lucky” to survive, condemned the “callous” shooting, and said it highlights the urgent need for airgun licensing so only those with a lawful reason can possess such weapons and to help police trace irresponsible users. This stance follows a Scottish government consultation on licensing air weapons in which 87% of respondents opposed the plan—some calling it “draconian” and “heavy-handed”—though a small number felt ministers were not going far enough, and the charity appealed for information from the public.

Liverpool have signed Aston Villa striker Christian Benteke on a long-term deal after triggering his release clause, making the 24-year-old Belgium international their second most expensive and seventh summer signing, a week after selling Raheem Sterling to Manchester City for £49m. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after joining from Genk for £7m in 2012, said he joined to win trophies and believes in Brendan Rodgers’ project. Seeking to fix last season’s goal shortage after the £75m sale of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge—with Mario Balotelli and Rickie Lambert contributing only three league goals as Liverpool finished sixth—Rodgers has also added Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino, while Divock Origi returns from loan. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup with an Achilles injury but returned last October and scored 15 to help Villa avoid relegation and reach the FA Cup final. Former Villa boss Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge backed him to thrive at Anfield, praising his strength, pace, aggression and all-round No. 9 play; Aldridge cited Villa’s FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool and said he is more optimistic now, noting the strikers managed only eight goals last season.

A study of 671 state and independent schools commissioned by Tablets for Schools finds tablet use is widespread (68% of primaries, 69% of secondaries), with 9% providing one per pupil and highest adoption in academies; among non-users, 45% expect to introduce them, and device numbers are projected to rise from about 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. Researchers report no clear evidence that tablets directly improve academic results and cannot isolate technology’s effect on attainment, though headteachers cite gains in motivation and greater family involvement when devices go home, and expect technology’s role to grow. Young people are deeply immersed in devices: in 1:1 schools a quarter of secondary pupils call themselves internet “addicts,” about two-thirds take devices to bed, and Ofcom says roughly 70% of 5–15-year-olds have a tablet at home. A separate National Literacy Trust/Pearson study suggests touchscreens aid reading, especially for boys and poorer pupils. Head Simon Mason champions iPads for empowerment and practicality (portability, touchscreens, immediate start-up).

Growing Up in the City at the Museum of Liverpool showcases 25 photographs from the 1880s to the 1990s that depict children’s lives and Liverpool’s social history, from street play and special occasions to child labor. Highlights include an 1887 portrait of Florence, George, and Gertie Rollo of Waterloo Park dressed for a fancy dress ball hosted by the Mayor and Mayoress of Bootle, and a circa-1900 image of a young maid working for a well-to-do family. Curated by Kay Jones, Curator of Urban Community History, the selection was distilled from hundreds of items in National Museums Liverpool’s collections to reflect both the joys and hardships of childhood. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

The Gulls have added centre-back Myles Anderson, 27—who cancelled his Barrow contract by mutual consent to join and could face his former club on 18 February—and 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams after spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, with his move subject to international clearance. Anderson, an ex-Aldershot and Exeter player who has also played in Italy, was praised by boss Kevin Nicholson as a leader-type, while Keating was described as young, raw, and hungry. The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

Bolivia has enacted a law allowing 12-year-olds to work under contract with parental authorization, which Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera said reflects the country’s needs as one of South America’s poorest, while also toughening penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide. Approved by Congress earlier this month, the law was signed by Garcia while President Evo Morales was in Brazil; Garcia said Morales helped balance national realities with rights and international treaties. UNICEF estimates more than 500,000 Bolivian children already work, from shoe cleaning and food sales to hazardous mining and farm labor. The government hopes the measure will help eradicate extreme poverty. The International Labour Organisation, which sets a general minimum working age of 15 (14 for developing countries), is studying whether the law breaches international child labor regulations.

Rosie O’Donnell, 50, said she was “lucky to be here” after experiencing chest pain, nausea, and fever at home following an incident helping a woman near her Nyack, New York, residence; she searched “women’s heart attack symptoms,” took aspirin, and saw a cardiologist the next day who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery, describing the attack in a blog poem as a “widow maker.” Though she didn’t call emergency services, she urged readers—especially women—to recognize symptoms, trust their instincts, and call 911. The actress and TV personality, known for Drop Dead Diva, Will and Grace, and Nip/Tuck, also recently had The Rosie Show on OWN canceled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, from Harrow, was fatally stabbed around 00:30 GMT in an alleyway near Belvedere Way, Kenton, after a Saturday party where a group of youths had earlier tried to force entry; although invited and not involved in the initial altercation, he appears to have been targeted later and died about an hour afterward. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition in a north London hospital. Police, led by Det Ch Insp Chris Jones, are appealing for witnesses who were near the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, two boys aged 15 and 16 were arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed until mid-December, and a 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

Denmark overhauled cancer diagnosis after “alarming” survival data revealed long waits, especially for patients with vague or hard-to-spot symptoms, by creating three routes: fast-track pathways with strict time targets for patients with “alarm” symptoms and a legal requirement to investigate any physical illness within 30 days of GP referral; hospital-based diagnosis centres to quickly test undiagnosed cases and avoid GP–specialist “ping pong”; and “yes-no” centres offering rapid scans/tests for minor symptoms, identifying serious disease in about 1% and preventing previous 4–6 month delays. The reorganisation improved coordination without flooding referrals and has been linked to rising survival, with Denmark catching up to Nordic peers. A Welsh delegation visited Aarhus to learn from this model, noting the breakdown of barriers between GPs and specialists in a health system similar to Wales.

Following the UK government’s decision to disband the OFT, Powys Council won a competitive bid to take over its estate agency enforcement role, receiving £170,000 a year to run a new team led by James Munro that can issue warning and banning orders against agents acting dishonestly or breaching the Estate Agents Act. People complaining about estate agents will still contact their local authority trading standards department, which may prosecute, but suspected breaches of the Act will be referred to Powys; Munro hopes the role will demonstrate Powys’s ability to take on more contracts and outside work in future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan, informed by a Nuffield Trust review, to expand nurses’ and pharmacists’ roles through additional training so they can take on tasks currently done by hospital doctors and GPs, helping plug gaps in junior doctor rotas and ease GP pressures. The think tank cites existing examples of such role substitution and argues it suits the shift toward managing long-term conditions like diabetes and heart disease; with doctors only about one in 10 of the 1.3 million-strong workforce, more is needed from other staff, though dedicated funding will be required. Report author Candace Imison described “huge opportunities,” and NHS Employers’ Danny Mortimer pledged to take forward the recommendations, while the BMA’s Dr Mark Porter warned skills expansion must not undermine doctors’ training or roles, and Unison’s Christina McAnea cautioned against a quick, cheap fix amid squeezed training budgets.

A crash at 03:00 GMT led Avon and Somerset Police to close the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot, with the A36 closure causing rush-hour disruption and bus delays until it was lifted at 14:00; investigations are ongoing, and while some First services have resumed, the company expects a few hours before full normalization, aiming for a full service by the evening commute, with managing director James Freeman thanking the public and staff for their support.
