Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated the proposed Swansea tidal lagoon would cause annual deaths of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout during migrations, a claim Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputed as lacking clear scientific basis and based on unshared “what if” methodology; TLP’s own expert modelling suggested a worst-case 2% mortality across all fish species. The £1.3bn project is viewed by TLP as a test bed for larger lagoons at sites including Cardiff, Newport and Colwyn Bay, while UK ministers consider a six-month viability review yet to be published. Wales’ Environment Secretary expressed strong support but sought rapid clarity from the UK government. NRW rejected TLP’s criticism, stating it had shared extensive data and methodology over 18 months, with assessments by independent and in-house experts, and maintained it used the best available evidence to fulfil its legal environmental duties.

DETI Minister Arlene Foster announced plans for an industry-led agri-food marketing body for Northern Ireland, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board and modeled on Scotland Food and Drink, highlighting the sector’s importance with nearly 100,000 jobs across farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. She said it will provide strategic leadership and coordinate marketing across government and private organizations. Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the move, calling agri-food key to export-led growth and noting industry demands for better coordination, but warned it could impact other organizations’ work, including her department, and said she will discuss the plans with the AFSB.

Members of the public are invited on Saturday afternoon to help plant thousands of trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, part of a Woodland Trust initiative creating four new UK woods. This four-year programme aims to plant millions of native trees to commemorate those who died in WW1, under the pledge “We will stand for those who fell.” At Brackfield, 40,000 trees will honor the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives, with plans for wildflowers including poppies to create a place for wildlife and quiet reflection. The trust will provide saplings and advises volunteers to wear welly boots or stout footwear. Brackfield Wood is about seven miles from Derry, just off the Glenshane Road, with limited parking. The trees are intended as a living tribute to Irish soldiers, their families and loved ones who played a part in the war.

At the start of Harrogate’s annual crime writing festival, Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for Someone Else’s Skin, the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome that tackles domestic violence and so-called honour crime; judge Alison Graham called it “an emotionally exhausting and powerful story,” and programming chair Ann Cleeves praised it as finely and tightly written, conjuring atmosphere in few lines with well-handled, well-plotted subject matter. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago; Cleeves hailed Warshawski as a game-changing, action-hero-like female protagonist who shifted readers’ views of women writers. Actress Kathleen Turner played Warshawski in a 1991 film based on the Deadlock novel and in a BBC Radio 4 adaptation, and Paretsky founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers.

Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner who made his Test debut in 2015, will rejoin Worcestershire Rapids after June’s ICC Trophy in England, having broken a finger in only his second county game in 2016—a setback director of cricket Steve Rhodes said was a major blow to their qualification hopes. Santner, who was injured in his first T20 match, said he enjoyed his time at Worcester and aims to make up for lost time with bat and ball next summer. Additionally, Worcestershire have signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats.

In 2008, Barry Pring, 47, was killed in Kiev when a speeding car with stolen plates, no lights, and that did not stop hit him as he tried to hail a taxi on a dual carriageway. At an Exeter inquest, coroner Dr Elizabeth Earland recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, saying the evidence was overwhelming beyond reasonable doubt and noting his guard was lowered by inebriation and the challenges of investigating deaths abroad. Witnesses described the impact as deliberate. Pring’s wife, Ganna (Anna) Ziuzina—19 years younger—had returned to a restaurant for a glove, later tried to claim his assets, sold his Range Rover and flat contents, moved funds, and was entitled to the first £200,000 of his estate; computer records showed she was having an affair with a Ukrainian man. Family and a lawyer friend alleged murder and suspected her involvement. Ukrainian police closed, then in 2011 relaunched, a murder inquiry that remains active but not actively pursued; Ziuzina did not attend the inquest, saying she had already given three statements to Ukrainian police.

Sophie and Rob Fearns from Litherland, Merseyside, say their son Charlie, ill since age three, must urgently return to Seattle Children’s Hospital for experimental T‑cell therapy unavailable in the UK after a failed T‑cell transplant and a third relapse in April. The family, previously heartbroken by the failure, is now “ecstatic” and “overwhelmed” after an anonymous donor who specifically asked to fund Charlie paid for the treatment. The hospital emailed confirmation on Wednesday; with financial clearance secured, therapy will begin as soon as possible, and they expect a treatment date next week.

After suggestions that third-party software was used to steal celebrities’ iCloud photos, Apple expanded its two-step verification to cover iCloud backups, aiming to block tools like Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker; the feature remains opt-in. When signing in on a new device, users must enter a four-digit code sent via SMS or the Find My iPhone app; without it, iCloud access and iTunes/iBooks/App Store purchases are denied, though a 14-character recovery key can restore access if a trusted device is lost. Elcomsoft’s owner, who had said his tool was likely used in the hacks, now acknowledges there is no workaround and notes Apple also now emails users immediately when a backup begins downloading, regardless of two-factor status. He warns recovery keys can be lost or stolen, while another expert downplays that risk and argues two-factor should be the default. Apple says it will push users to enable two-factor and use stronger passwords, with CEO Tim Cook emphasizing the need to raise user awareness.

Dan Groves said the finer points of a deal that could see Wright buy 20% of Billericay are yet to be released, with The Sun reporting the 30-year-old would become a club director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points off the play-offs. Wright, runner-up in I’m A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, previously played non-league football for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who said he was comfortable investing £10,000 a week, and they signed 35-year-old former England international Paul Konchesky at the start of March.

Following a BBC investigation into the company’s Derbyshire warehouse practices, Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, chair of the BIS select committee, asked Mr Ashley to give evidence on the treatment of low‑paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage, giving him until 21 March to respond. Ashley had invited the committee to meet at Sports Direct’s Shirebrook base, but the committee said it would adhere to its normal practice of meeting in public at Westminster and offered several alternative dates, none of which Ashley has accepted or agreed to in principle. Wright warned that failure to agree to one of the dates could lead the committee to seek House of Commons support over any complaint of contempt. Sports Direct did not comment, and the company has previously pledged to review worker rights under Ashley’s oversight; he also owns Newcastle United Football Club.

After Boris Nemtsov’s murder, his colleagues led by Ilya Yashin completed his report “Putin. War,” compiling previously published facts about events since Crimea’s annexation to argue that President Vladimir Putin is waging war in eastern Ukraine for his own ends. While Russia denies sending regular forces, calling participants “volunteers,” the report claims Russian troops and equipment secured key rebel victories and that soldiers admit being sent under Russian command; it cites volunteer pay of $2,000–3,000 a month and estimates Russia’s costs at 53bn roubles (about $1bn). Nemtsov began the project after hearing families of dead soldiers weren’t compensated, but they have stayed silent out of fear. The dossier lists units and weapon photos, though verification is tricky, and faces limited publication (2,000 copies) amid publisher reluctance. Many Russians accept involvement; the opposition says Putin used the war to boost popularity, as with Nemtsov’s earlier unheeded reports.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, 34, from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham, was found at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday; a post-mortem found he died from head injuries, and a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

Despite some shared aims like free trade within the single market, tensions flared over the Article 50 letter: Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones said he discussed it only in general terms with Theresa May, did not see or contribute to the letter before publication, and called the process disrespectful to devolved administrations; Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered that the PM had engaged repeatedly with Wales and must act for the whole UK, noting Wales was mentioned. May’s letter promised full consultation on which repatriated powers stay at Westminster or are devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, and expected a significant increase in devolved decision-making, but offered no specifics. Questions persist over which powers (e.g., farming, economic aid) and whether funding will follow after 2020; Cairns gave no answers, Jones fears a funding gap, while Labour pledges to maintain EU regional aid beyond 2020. Some in Whitehall argue Wales’s use of EU funds supports centralizing those powers, though that now seems less likely politically. A Great Repeal Bill white paper may clarify, but the intended devolved powers remain unclear.

Two cars were damaged on Friday night in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry during an incident in which police carrying out their duties were attacked; Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the “mindless attacks” on PSNI officers and the community, and a PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook post urged parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

American Apparel founder Dov Charney was ousted last year after employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. In a San Francisco court filing, the board said it does not expect him to return, citing evidence of illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts, and asserting he repeatedly violated sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies; it argued no board would hire him due to the risk. Charney’s lawyer called many statements false and accused the company of invading his privacy to extort leverage. The filing responds to Charney’s defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. Earlier this month, a restraining order barred him from making negative press statements about the company and from trying to remove board members.

Great Britain play Greece at the Copper Box in their only home game before FIBA EuroBasket 2017, with live coverage on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website/app from 17:30–19:30 BST. Greece, European title contenders, beat GB 92–64 earlier this month in Patras, but three members of that team will be missing for the rematch, giving GB a chance of revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor, from Stratford, said playing at the Copper Box will help ensure they’re 100% ready for EuroBasket and that some teammates will be playing in London for the first time with a great atmosphere expected. After facing Greece, coach Joe Prunty’s team head to a four-team tournament in Poland for their final warm-ups before EuroBasket starts at the beginning of September with a qualifying group in Istanbul, Turkey.

A journalist recalls the 2007 iPhone unveiling, scrambling to get a device on camera by borrowing Apple marketing chief Phil Schiller’s handset for the BBC Ten O’Clock News, then facing criticism for giving a product launch undue prominence. He defended the coverage as a potential step change, a Model T comparison he later doubted but now finds reasonable, as smartphones have put powerful computers in the hands of more than two billion people and disrupted many industries. A personal photo comparison (an underwhelming SLR shot of Steve Jobs versus a 2017 Las Vegas image taken on an iPhone and instantly shareable on social media) shows how the iPhone transformed photography and other activities on the move. While phones already had cameras and internet before 2007, Steve Jobs’s key insight was that an attractive user interface would spur use beyond talk and text. Despite early distaste for launch hyperbole, the author feels grateful to have witnessed a historic moment, noting that while firms like Amazon and Google are now taking us forward with AI-imbued products, the mobile connected era began on that sunny January morning in San Francisco.

In Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, the RSPCA said tests confirmed all cats near Victor Avenue had ingested a toxic substance; seven-month-old Meereen, who came home shivering on Friday, was later found foaming at the mouth, confirmed by vets to have consumed antifreeze, and died three days later on Monday. Three other cats in the area have died in the past week, and another died two weeks earlier. The RSPCA said it is unclear whether the poisonings are accidental or deliberate and urged residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, check for car antifreeze leaks, and clean any spills.

Despite Syriza preparing to accept more austerity and liberalisation measures it once decried, Athens has seen no street protests even as tourism surges, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals, up from 21 million. Greeks face VAT hikes, pension cuts, reduced farm subsidies, privatisations and market openings as Tsipras seeks a third €86bn bailout after July’s bank closures and economic collapse turned Syriza into TINA (“there is no alternative”) converts. Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity and adding monetary austerity via partially closed banks, which are choking credit and threatening retailers’ autumn orders—and even Christmas. Greece is in a vicious squeeze that will further impoverish citizens; for the bailout to lead to real recovery, many argue creditors must grant substantial debt relief (by a third to a half), with Brussels and especially Berlin avoiding triumphalism and delivering forgiveness in response to Athens’ capitulation.

Ross Kemp will make a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Barbara Windsor’s final episodes after Peggy Mitchell’s surprise reappearance revealed her cancer had returned; producers confirmed Peggy will die from the disease in emotional scenes airing in the spring. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990–1999 and again in 2005–2006 (last appearing in 2006), said he couldn’t turn down reuniting the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time and is looking forward to filming classic episodes. Grant, a memorable character who arrived with brother Phil in 1990 and was central to family dramas—including an affair with Phil’s wife Kathy and Phil later marrying Grant’s ex-wife Sharon—will return to bring the Mitchell family back together. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins said Grant is returning to Walford to say goodbye to his mother and be reunited with old loves and his brother, showcasing Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best.

Lance Corporal Trimaan “Harry” Dhillon, 26, stalked and fatally attacked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles last October; her parents, Sue Hills and Prof Clive Ruggles, recalled police informing them and immediately suspecting him, with Dr Hills feeling deep guilt for having reassured Alice and dismissed another daughter Emma’s warning days earlier. At Newcastle Crown Court, the jury heard Dhillon had become obsessed and stalked Alice; he denied murder but was found guilty and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years. Acknowledging they hadn’t realized the danger despite signs, her parents founded the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of stalking and to remember Alice’s vibrant, smiling, cheeky personality.

EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear plant in Somerset, with contracts due to be signed, but hours later the UK government launched a further review—Business Secretary Greg Clark said it would “consider carefully”—prompting EDF’s chief to cancel a visit and raising doubts over a pause versus a policy shift. The plant, expected to supply about 7% of UK electricity, is largely financed by EDF with roughly a third from Chinese investors and under a 2013 strike price of £92.50/MWh, yet EDF’s financial strain—shareholders backing a €4bn share issue and the resignations of finance director Thomas Piquemal and board member Gérard Magnin over risk—has heightened concerns. Industry figures urge a swift decision to avoid supply risks, higher costs, and dirtier power, while critics warn of environmental damage, escalating costs, foreign state involvement, and poor value for money, with Greenpeace calling for more renewables. The sudden review surprised EDF, halted a post‑Brexit run of major investment, and strained UK‑French relations; key milestones include nuclear backed in 2006, Hinkley construction approved in 2013, the strike price agreed in Oct 2013, Chinese investment agreed in Oct 2015, and EDF’s July 2016 investment decision followed by a UK postponement to autumn.

A newly redesigned online divorce application form in England and Wales now directly asks for “the name of the person your spouse has committed adultery with,” prompting concern from family lawyers that naming third parties adds conflict and complexity. The Ministry of Justice says there is no obligation to name anyone and the form’s guidance states it is “not normally necessary,” but practitioners fear users—especially those applying without legal advice—may still fill in the box. Vardags director Georgina Hamblin notes the previous form only provided space for co-respondents where appropriate, while the new wording invites disclosures many “broken hearts” will make; Resolution vice-chair Margaret Heathcote adds that simply having the box encourages people to use it. Naming someone makes them part of the case, triggers service of papers and a right to respond, and non-response can delay proceedings and increase costs; judges take a dim view of petitioners trying to embroil new partners, and Hamblin says 80% of her new adultery clients want to involve them even though it reflects badly on the petitioner. In 2015 there were just over 100,000 divorces in England and Wales, with 12,148 citing adultery and 46,815 citing unreasonable behaviour, and the MoJ emphasizes it has always been possible—but never mandatory—to name the person believed to have committed adultery with the spouse.

Confor and other industry voices argue ministers are prioritizing environmental goals over timber production, even as Britain is the world’s third-largest wood importer; in Wales, conifer forests have long supported a £450m-a-year industry, but at least 16,000 hectares (40,000 acres) of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need replanting. Half of Welsh woodland is managed by Natural Resources Wales and half by private firms. The Welsh government says it seeks a balance of environmental, economic and social outcomes, pointing to the Glastir scheme and its Woodlands for Wales strategy, and ministers say they are encouraging commercial investment in woodland creation. Tensions persist as policy favors native broadleaf species and public access, conservationists claim commercial forests harm wildlife, and remote sites plus timber transport through rural communities create local conflicts. Confor’s Martin Bishop calls the system too bureaucratic, noting only 90 hectares were planted last year versus a 20,000-hectare annual need to meet ministers’ long-term targets, despite strong demand that sawmills say they could meet if timber were available.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge, prompting emergency crews to respond to Bank Street near Langloan Primary School around 16:40; he was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Russian defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoy veterans, including 91-year-old Able Seaman Charles Lewis of Calmore, Hampshire, who said he was honoured but “not a hero,” echoing Churchill’s description of the campaign as the “worst journey in the world.” The convoys, which sailed from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union under constant U-boat and air attack and harsh Arctic conditions, cost by May 1945 a loss of 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with more than 3,000 men killed. Russia viewed the convoys as a material symbol of the wartime alliance, providing weapons and ammunition vital to defeating Germany on the Eastern Front. Although the Foreign Office initially blocked Russia’s plan (May 2012) to award the Ushakov medal under foreign-medal rules, the UK created the Arctic Star in 2012 and later granted an exception; President Vladimir Putin presented the first Ushakov medals in London on 16 June 2013.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant failings in “community payback,” including delays starting work and weak enforcement of absences—citing a case of only 16 hours completed in 17 months—despite courts ordering 40–300 hours for offences like theft or drug crimes and 70,000 people receiving such sentences in 2014. Reviewing 100 cases and interviewing 86 offenders, inspectors issued 15 recommendations, urging fewer turnaways when offenders report on time and tailoring objectives to individuals. While some projects delivered skills and were viewed positively by offenders, organization remains a major problem, long predating current policy efforts to make unpaid work tougher and faster, and unpaid work is too often treated merely as punishment, a “wasted opportunity,” according to Chief Inspector Paul Wilson, who called for urgent remedial action. The Ministry of Justice accepted the recommendations, emphasizing stricter attendance and consequences and said it is already acting to implement them.

A newspaper (The Sun) accused comedian Russell Brand of hypocrisy for advocating economic and political “revolution” while living in a luxury London home, a charge often leveled at him and highlighted by footage from his vlogs showing his airy, stylish flat. When questioned outside Downing Street—where he was supporting east London estate residents fearing displacement for richer renters—about his own rent, he called the Channel 4 News reporter “a snide” and walked off. Brand did not respond to Newsbeat about possible legal action against The Sun and Rupert Murdoch, though he tweeted criticisms using #TheSunLogic. In past responses, he acknowledges his wealth and fame, says he must change personally and share wealth but argues systemic change is essential, admits “daft” past actions under capitalism, and contends that attacks on his alleged hypocrisy are attempts to distract from real issues like inequality and ecological crisis; he adds that any hypocrisy can be addressed incrementally.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist-entrepreneur known for wealth and outspoken self-confidence, turned the effort to map the human genome into a competitive race that vilified him in the scientific community but accelerated genomics. Shaped by service as a Vietnam War medic, he pursued research at the NIH, adopted automated sequencing in 1987, and pioneered focusing on messenger RNA to speed gene discovery, drawing criticism from James Watson. Leaving the NIH in 1992, he founded The Institute for Genomic Research and in 1995 produced the first complete genome of a free‑living organism (Haemophilus influenzae); in 1998 he launched Celera to decode the human genome, with both Celera and the public project publishing results in 2001 amid disputes over open data. Financial success enabled independent work, including forming the J. Craig Venter Institute in 2006 to create synthetic life and publishing details of a synthetic organism, Synthia, in Science, a controversial breakthrough. He also led the Sorcerer II ocean expedition to sequence microbial genomes, and argues synthetic microbes could spark a new industrial revolution by doing the production we want, helping wean society off oil, and capturing carbon dioxide.

An online survey commissioned by England’s School Food Trust of about 1,000 parents (conducted 26 February–5 March), including 628 with children who eat school lunches, found four in five such children had tried foods at school they hadn’t had at home, and half of parents said their child had asked for school foods to be cooked at home. Carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least popular (percentages reflected the share of parents reporting their child would eat each). Prompted by a Mumsnet survey suggesting some parents opt for packed lunches due to fussy eating, Trust and Mumsnet leaders highlighted school meals’ healthier, more varied options, peer influence, and value in broadening diets. School meals in England must meet strict nutritional guidelines. About four in ten primary pupils in England eat school lunches (slightly fewer in secondary schools), compared with roughly 46% in Scotland.

Alvaro Morata, 23, a 6ft 3in striker playing for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid, with Real retaining a buy-back option reportedly up to €30m (£23m). Previously linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, he has scored three goals for Spain in France, totaled 27 goals in two years for Juventus while winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and appeared in back-to-back Champions League finals—coming on as a substitute in Real’s 2014 win and scoring in Juventus’ 3-1 defeat to Barcelona in 2015. A Real youth product, he debuted for their first team at 18 and scored 10 goals for the club.

Wilson, 30, rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground after previously spending four seasons at the club before signing for Celtic, has also played for Preston North End and Notts County, and has been without a team since being released in May.

Tesco, the world’s third-largest retailer, is exiting the US by transferring much of its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain to Los Angeles–based private equity firm Yucaipa, with about 4,000 of 5,000 employees moving to the new business and the remaining 50 shops understood to be closing; Fresh & Easy has operated 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona and has lost money since its 2007 launch. As part of the deal, Tesco will loan the new business around £80m and expects total disposal costs of about £150m, part of which may be repaid, and it retains an option to buy a stake if Yucaipa makes the business profitable. Tesco described the move as an orderly and efficient exit from the US market; Yucaipa is run by billionaire Ron Burkle and focuses on supermarket and restaurant businesses. In April, Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits in 20 years.

An athlete tells BBC Sport’s Nick Hope how he overcame early racial abuse, briefly considered representing France, and is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics, with the piece also directing readers to a guide on getting into martial arts.

Research presented at the AGU Fall Meeting by Marie Gardent (University of Savoie) shows French Alps glacier area shrank from about 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to roughly 275 sq km in the late 2000s, passing through around 340 sq km in 1985–86—an average 26% loss over 40 years with accelerated retreat. The inventory covered about 600 glaciers across the Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, Grande Rousse Arves, and Mont Blanc massifs, using map archives, satellite imagery, aerial photos, and manual checks to correct for debris cover and deep shadows. Retreat is uneven and strongest in the southern Alps (Belledonne glaciers have nearly vanished; Ecrins retreat is over three times that of Mont Blanc), while the northern Alps fare better, likely due to higher precipitation, more cloud, and higher elevations; La Mer de Glace on Mont Blanc is just over 30 sq km today versus 31.5 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s. These findings mirror broader Alpine glacier losses, including accelerating mass loss reported by Swiss researchers.

Scotland’s women have won all five qualifiers and host unbeaten, top-seeded Iceland (ranked one place higher at 20) at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, with this match and the 20 September return in Reykjavik likely to decide the group; a win would all but secure qualification, and with the best six of eight runners-up also advancing automatically, Scotland are in pole position to reach next summer’s finals in the Netherlands without a play-off. Forward Lisa Evans, 24, desperate to avoid a third near miss after play-off losses for Euro 2013 and last year’s World Cup, says it would be “more heartbreak than humiliation,” urges a big home crowd, and stresses a step-by-step focus. Twelve of the 20-player squad are based abroad (five in England, four in Sweden, two at Seattle Reign, including BBC Women’s Footballer of the Year Kim Little). Evans, recently a Bundesliga winner with Bayern Munich, recalls celebrations alongside Franck Ribery and Arjen Robben and argues that experience in elite leagues—especially Germany’s—raises standards for the national team as the Scottish league continues to improve.

Stuart Campbell, the Wings Over Scotland blogger and pro-independence campaigner, was arrested in the west of England after a south London woman in her 30s reported alleged online harassment over a two-year period; he was released on bail pending further inquiries to mid-September. Campbell, a former computer games reviewer born in Stirling and living in Bath, said the allegations relate solely to tweets that remain publicly visible, insisted none were threatening, and accused the media of encouraging speculation. The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating an allegation of online harassment.

Peta has urged Skegness to replace its Jolly Fisherman mascot with a modern, animal-friendly alternative—a fish bearing the slogan “Skegness - A Happy Plaice”—arguing the current figure evokes cruelty associated with fishing; spokesperson Dawn Carr described fish being impaled and crushed in nets and said the change would rebrand the resort as progressive. The Jolly Fisherman originates from a 1908 Great Northern Railway poster, commissioned for 12 guineas, featuring the slogan “Skegness is so bracing” and now synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort. Mayor Carl Macey welcomed suggestions but predicted little support for removing Jolly, saying the character is loved and not seen as promoting cruelty; he said the idea would go to council but “if it isn’t broken we won’t try and fix it.”

Georgia struck first through scrum-half Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland then dominated possession and territory (91% in the opening 30 minutes) to surge ahead with tries from Tommy Seymour (chasing a Stuart Hogg dink), a penalty try after Kote Mikautadze collapsed a maul and was sin-binned, Sean Maitland, and Hogg before half-time, with Greig Laidlaw adding conversions and a penalty. Early in the second half Hamish Watson powered over to make it 38-11, before Georgia’s scrum earned them a second Lobzhanidze try and Scotland’s Moray Low was yellow-carded amid set-piece pressure. A late counter sparked by debutant Ali Price, with support from Rory Hughes, set up Hogg for his second and Scotland’s sixth try, while Merab Kvirikashvili kicked two penalties for the visitors. Head coach Vern Cotter praised a clinical, possession-heavy first half and pragmatic game management in wet, cold conditions, highlighting Laidlaw’s leadership and ongoing team improvement.

Widnes built a 14-6 half-time lead through tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van and Chris Bridge, with Castleford’s Paddy Flynn replying against his parent club; although Flynn scored again early in the second half, Widnes surged to 38-12 with further tries from Ah Van, two by Lloyd White and one from Joe Mellor, who capitalized on a short kick-off to make it a 26-point advantage. Castleford hit back with three tries in four minutes from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale and Flynn, who completed his hat-trick, but Widnes held on despite having lost nine of their previous 10 matches. The Tigers suffered a fourth straight home league defeat, while Widnes moved above Wakefield into seventh; Castleford remain sixth, one point ahead. Flynn is on loan at Castleford from Widnes until season’s end, and Patrick has signed a three-year deal to move from Huddersfield after his loan spell.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, a Kuwaiti held at Guantanamo since 2002 after his arrest in Pakistan on suspected links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies, was released after a US Periodic Review Board in July determined he no longer posed a continuing significant threat. He had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court and was flown home on a Kuwaiti government plane, but must spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center under the release terms. Kuwait had pushed for its detainees’ release, and al-Odah says he traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan for religious teaching and humanitarian aid. He is the first inmate freed since the May swap of five Taliban detainees for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl, reducing Guantanamo’s population to 148; the facility opened in January 2002 after the 11 September attacks, and President Obama has repeatedly pledged to close it.

PPAP (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen), a minute-long earworm by animal print-clad DJ Piko-Taro—a fictional character of Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka—pairs a simple beat, absurdly catchy lyrics, and a basic dance; first posted on his YouTube channel, it quickly spread to Facebook, with the original surpassing 4 million views and 9GAG’s version topping 44 million. Piko-Taro said he made it while “playing” and sang it “too soon.” Reactions ranged from amused obsession to irritation, with some noting his flamboyant look and comparing him to One Piece’s Borsalino. Despite broad international pickup, it drew little mainstream coverage in Japan and didn’t particularly trend there. Dubbed the next Psy, some suggested it was engineered for global virality via digital influencers, and it spawned hundreds of covers—from Japanese stars like Riko and Rika to heavy metal renditions and a version by Thai social media star Happy Polla.

Anzac Day, marking the first major World War One battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces, was commemorated in London with thousands at a Hyde Park Corner dawn service, a parade of up to 400 before wreath-laying at the Cenotaph, and a service at Westminster Abbey where the New Zealand and Australian anthems were sung. First observed in the capital in 1916 when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service after the Gallipoli landings, it has become an important moment for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians to honor sacrifices in all wars. Australian high commissioner Alexander Downer addressed the dawn service and laid a wreath, reflecting on the Gallipoli landings and the courage and heroism of the Anzac troops. Veterans' associations, service and ex-service personnel and families took part, with crowds including Australian and New Zealand ex-pats watching prayers by schoolchildren and the national anthems of all three countries. The eight-month Gallipoli campaign in Turkey was one of the war's bloodiest and aimed to force the Ottoman Empire out of the conflict.

Clarkson, 30, who joined Premiership Well for a second spell in July, could make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has mostly been a substitute this term, but says he is fully fit after playing U20 games and training hard. Capped twice for Scotland in 2008 with one international goal and nearly 400 senior club appearances, his previous clubs include Bristol City, Brentford and Bristol Rovers. With St Mirren eighth in the Championship, seven points above bottom side Alloa, Clarkson says every game is big and aims to help the team build confidence, go on a run, and climb the table.

Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, easing fears about pensions after Unite’s Steve Harley said talks at the Great Witchingham HQ secured guarantees that all current agreements will be honored; the final salary scheme closed in 2004, and members’ alternative scheme is unaffected, with Boparan’s office confirming current pension arrangements will continue, while the new owner aims to restore profitability through investment, cost savings, and using spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkeys.

At a council scrutiny meeting on problems with the new Cowes chain ferry, leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until 2 July to acknowledge issues and gather feedback, and said auditors would review the project after a “frustrating and disappointing” start. Since its 14 May launch, the ferry has broken down, run aground, been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training issues, and caused vehicle damage. Local shopkeeper Angie Booth warned of severe business losses and asked about compensation; transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation is under discussion, described the ferry as a prototype with expected teething problems, and noted electrical issues have been fixed. The council authorized ramp extensions to prevent vehicles scraping, and said groundings linked to seamanship have been resolved.

A House of Lords EU Committee report warns the UK may have to allow EU boats to fish in its waters to secure tariff‑free access to EU markets, noting fishing communities—strong supporters of Brexit due to dislike of the Common Fisheries Policy—risk being sidelined because the sector is small (0.5% of GDP, 12,000 fishers). With most UK catch exported to the EU and much UK‑consumed fish imported from the EU, continued market access is vital, and trade‑offs are likely. The report says many CFP elements should be retained, including science‑based total allowable catches and quotas, and the UK will still need to cooperate internationally over shared stocks. It also warns that leaving the CFP framework could splinter management into four regimes across England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite risks, industry figures are optimistic—buoyed by recent quota increases—about gaining control of a 200‑mile EEZ, fairer shares, and better sustainability, while the government aims for maximum freedom to trade in the single market and to review fisheries management for fair access, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney admitted taking or permitting images between April 2004 and February 2014; a court heard most were of young boys partially dressed in erotic poses with no sexual activity. He received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register, and was ordered to attend a special programme for sex offenders. A General Teaching Council Scotland hearing found his conduct fundamentally incompatible with teaching, citing a long-term pattern, failure to uphold professional standards, and a strong likelihood of recurrence, and therefore removed him from the professional register. Geaney, 69 at sentencing, did not attend the hearing and is prohibited from applying to re-register for two years.

A 2 March blaze at a Duncan Street site kept firefighters there for several days, disrupted train services, and led the Environment Agency (EA) to suspend Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste; despite Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) saying the operators, Asset and Land Group, were broadly compliant with fire safety law after nine visits in the past year, GMFRS had raised concerns in February about risks to residents, transport, and the environment, prompting joint inspections and EA enforcement. The EA has decided to revoke the site’s environmental permit, effective 7 August subject to appeal by that date, after which the company cannot operate there but must remove all waste. The company could not be reached for comment, and the fire’s cause remains undetermined.

Syria’s Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad said the country is “doing its best” to meet the chemical weapons destruction timetable despite missing a deadline and claiming two shipments to Latakia were attacked, stressing commitment to OPCW and UN obligations. Syria has declared about 1,300 tonnes of chemical agents, but the US says only 4% (30 tonnes) has left, prompting concern from US Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel; Russia expects transfer to the coast by 1 March and all weapons are to be destroyed by end-June, with the OPCW citing security delays. Mekdad rejected as “absolutely unacceptable” US criticism of alleged barrel bomb use in Aleppo, denied targeting civilians, and accused the US of aiding “terrorists,” while the Syrian Observatory reported 246 deaths, including 73 children, in five days from helicopter-dropped barrel bombs, and the Aleppo Media Centre reported 14 killed in Masaken Hanano. Conflicting accounts surround Aleppo’s central prison: the Observatory says Islamic Front and al-Nusra assaulted it and freed hundreds, with fighting ongoing; Ahrar al-Sham and the Aleppo Media Centre claim full rebel control; state media says the attack was thwarted; the prison reportedly holds at least 3,000 detainees in horrific conditions.

England thrashed Pakistan at Old Trafford, winning with a day to spare to level the four-match series after declaring at 589-8 and 173-1 for their second-biggest win over Pakistan by runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was player of the match with 254 in the first innings, an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second, four catches, and a wicket; captain Alastair Cook added 105 and 76 not out and praised Root’s controlled response after errors at Lord’s, echoed by coach Trevor Bayliss. Michael Vaughan called it an “absolute hammering” and Root’s best Test innings, while Geoffrey Boycott said Pakistan’s spirit was broken. Pakistan managed 198 and 234, batting only 63 and 70 overs, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq having passed 50 in the series; Misbah admitted poor shot selection and low confidence but expects a response. Pakistan play a two-day tour match against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August, with Vaughan still predicting a tight series.

Older People’s Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is gathering experiences from pensioners, their friends, and families to inform a review of the quality of life and care in Welsh residential care, with evidence used to make recommendations to care providers and public bodies. Having travelled across Wales, she intends to showcase good care while highlighting the impact of poor care and what she deems unacceptable variations in standards; the review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, and will include input from care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. The goal is to ensure services understand daily realities and take action to improve residents’ quality of life. Care Forum Wales supports the review’s aims but criticizes the advisory panel for lacking a provider expert or anyone who has lived in, worked in, managed, or owned a care home, calling it a missed opportunity for partnership working.

Paul Sheerin, 39, a former Aberdeen midfielder and Arbroath’s player-manager since 2010, has been chosen by Aberdeen boss Derek McInnes to replace Neil Cooper at Pittodrie after a comprehensive selection process, said chief executive Duncan Fraser; Arbroath chairman John Christison cooperated despite wishing to keep Sheerin, respecting his desire to return. Sheerin previously played for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s, guided Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division and promotion in 2011, and saw the club relegated to League Two after finishing bottom of League One in 2013–14.

After Bob Bradley’s sacking, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead Swansea against Bournemouth while the club seeks a swift appointment, with ex-Derby boss Paul Clement the first choice. Curtis says Swansea need a manager to pull them out of trouble and warns that relegation would make an immediate return difficult given the Championship’s strength and the club’s likely inability to retain top players. He reflects on Swansea’s rise—promotion in 2011 after near-bankruptcy and a 2003 brush with dropping out of the Football League—and their reputation for a possession-based “Swansea Way.” Curtis believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup’s 2014 departure due to frequent managerial changes and insufficiently replaced departures, though he still thinks the current squad can stay up. He adds that new signings are shown the “Jack to a King” documentary to understand the club’s journey and the importance of survival to the area.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist-entrepreneur, turned the effort to map the human genome into a competitive race that sped progress but drew vilification for perceived immodesty, disputes over open data, and a lavish use of private jets and yachts. Shaped by service as a Navy hospital orderly in Vietnam, he pursued research over medical practice and, at the NIH in the 1980s, adopted automation and shifted from DNA to messenger RNA to identify genes rapidly; criticism and funding setbacks led him to found The Institute for Genomic Research in 1992, which in 1995 delivered the first complete genome of a free-living organism, Haemophilus influenzae. In 1998 he launched Celera Genomics to decode the human genome in three years; both Celera and the public project published in 2001, and the financial rewards gave him unusual independence. He formed the J. Craig Venter Institute in 2006 to lead a more than decade-long push culminating in the synthetic organism “Synthia,” reported in Science, a controversial breakthrough he publicized as it neared. Meanwhile, his Sorcerer II voyages collected ocean microbes to sequence their genomes and illuminate gene and protein evolution and function. Venter argues synthetic microbes could spark a new industrial revolution by producing desired compounds, reducing reliance on oil, and capturing carbon dioxide.

The Sutton Trust, citing a Boston Consulting Group study, warns that many apprenticeships in England are low quality and too short, with fewer than 200,000 of 520,000 annual starts at level 3 (A-level equivalent), 58% since 2010 below level 3, three-quarters aimed at over‑25s already in work, and 11 young people competing per place; only 20% of employers offer apprenticeships versus 51% in Germany, where 570,000 new places go to youngsters and 90% are A-level equivalent, and England’s system has 18,000 qualifications versus Germany’s 330. Calling England’s provision a confusing “patchwork” and a “cruel deception,” the Trust urges up to 300,000 new starts annually, mostly three‑year level‑3 and some four‑year level‑4 courses (higher than A‑levels), with no more than 10% at two‑year level‑2, arguing this is vital for social mobility and competitiveness. The Association of Colleges says creating 300,000 places would be a major challenge, supports prioritizing level 3 but wants respected level‑2 routes like construction preserved, and stresses delivery only in institutions with high‑quality facilities, expert staff, and better careers guidance. The Department for Education says it is already reforming apprenticeships to raise standards—mandating a one‑year minimum, adding more English and maths, ensuring every apprenticeship is a job—with over a million starts since 2010 and further plans due later this month.

Briton Storey won in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland’s Anna Harkowska, saying it was a relief to win as the 37-year-old targets further Paralympic success at next year’s Games in Rio de Janeiro; she can win a 17th title when she rides in Saturday’s road race. Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian, she has 22 Paralympic medals—11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze—across six Games in cycling and swimming, including four golds at London 2012, and now holds 21 world titles across both sports. She began her career in swimming, earning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United were expelled from the Football Conference on 10 June after failing to provide assurances and to pay £148,000 owed to football creditors by a series of extended deadlines (initially 5 June, then 6, 7, 9 and 12 June), despite months of fundraising and a takeover by Tommy Agombar; overall debts were about £225,000, including over £70,000 owed to HMRC for PAYE. The decision reverses their last-day on-field survival and sees Chester reinstated to the Conference Premier while Hayes & Yeading remain in the Conference South. Fans’ group HUST offered to buy the club for £1 and clear roughly £220,000, but chairman David Keyte preferred other bidders and ultimately sold to Agombar. The crisis was fueled by unpaid wages—former manager Martin Foyle issued a winding-up petition—and falling gates since relegation from the Football League in 2012 (average attendance down from 3,270 to 1,758 in 2013-14). On the day of the decision, Foyle, now Southport manager, signed owed-wages goalkeeper Dan Lloyd-Weston, while ex-Bull Kingsley James joined Chester.

Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, earned 61 England caps after his 2009 senior debut, featured in squads for two World Cups and two European Championships but played only three minutes at Euro 2016, said the decision reached was common sense and wished Sam Allardyce, players, staff, and supporters success, holds the England Under-21 caps record with 46 after debuting in 2004, and scored his sole senior international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova in the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Conductor Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after an illness lasting several months; his funeral will be private with a memorial service to follow. Considered one of the most influential exponents of the early-music movement, he worked with leading orchestras worldwide and founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973, directing it for about 30 years across six continents; the AAM made over 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments, and his 1980 Handel’s Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson was named by BBC Music Magazine among the top 20 recordings of all time. Trained in keyboard at Cambridge with Rafael Puyana and Mary Potts and later with Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt, he began as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields under Sir Neville Marriner and was a founding member of the Early Music Consort of London; he later served as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, and held academic posts at Harvard, the University of Cambridge, and Cornell. Tributes from Christopher Purvis, Richard Egarr, Dame Emma Kirkby, and David Thomas praised his generosity, scholarship, influence on generations of players, and belief in letting the music speak for itself.

A boy from Northern Ireland was withdrawn from mainstream school in June because he was not coping, and despite his family requesting a special school place, they were told in September that all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full with no timeframe for a place; his mother left her job to care for him and says he feels isolated and confused about not attending school like his siblings. The family has since been told an extra classroom assistant has been hired at a local special school, raising hopes he can start within weeks, but his mother fears capacity issues will continue to affect other families. The Education Authority declined to comment on the individual case for privacy reasons, and said it is reviewing the need for special school places across Northern Ireland to ensure availability near children’s homes, with work ongoing to assist placements from 2016.

Newport Gwent Dragons’ proposed takeover by the Welsh Rugby Union, which views Rodney Parade as a rugby venue, goes to a shareholder vote on 9 May, while Newport County, holding a 10-year lease signed in 2013 with fixture primacy through 2023 if they remain in the Football League, insist their contract be honoured; Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey says County and Newport Squash Club are protected under current agreements and the WRU has been informed. The WRU’s plan to install an artificial surface conflicts with Football League rules. On the field, County are two points above the League Two drop zone with two games left after six wins in 10 under caretaker Mike Flynn, and can secure survival this weekend if they win and Hartlepool lose; Foxall says relegation back to the National League would be a massive blow for fans and the city.

After Sierra Leone was declared free of Ebola following nearly 4,000 deaths in 18 months, a former child soldier recounts being abducted at 15 by RUF rebels during the civil war that began in 1991, branded, threatened with mutilation, forced into violence under drugs, then escaping to Freetown, being jailed for pickpocketing, and being rehabilitated by preacher Richard Cole through the Lifeline Nehemiah project, which returned him to school and a mission to rebuild (a vision continued after Cole’s death in 2006). When Ebola struck in 2014, his group, though not medics, treated it as a common enemy: they educated more than 10,000 people in Temne, Krio and Limba, delivered food and essentials to about 11,000 people in urban and rural areas, and, with local chiefs and partner agencies and little funding, set up an Ebola treatment unit that saved many lives, overcoming fear and beliefs in witchcraft; seeing a pregnant suspected Ebola patient while no one could enter the house because it was too dangerous spurred the clinic’s creation. He now sees himself as changed, regrets his past, and invests in young people to help rebuild the nation. The Ebola outbreak caused 11,314 deaths in total (4,808 in Liberia, 3,955 in Sierra Leone, 2,536 in Guinea, 8 in Nigeria, plus one in the US and six in Mali).

A public campaign led by the Art Fund raised its target within a month to save the Wedgwood Museum’s 80,000-piece collection from being auctioned to pay pension debts inherited after Waterford Wedgwood’s 2009 collapse. Administrators Begbies Traynor signed off the sale to the Art Fund, which will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum and have it loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum, keeping it on display in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The museum had gone into administration in 2010, and a 2011 High Court ruling had allowed the collection’s sale to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund. Supporters, including administrator Bob Young, Alison Wedgwood, and MP Tristram Hunt, hailed the outcome as preserving a culturally significant national asset.

Dan Groves said the finer details of a deal under which Wright could buy 20% of Billericay are yet to be released, with The Sun reporting the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points off a play-off place. Wright, runner-up in I’m A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, previously played non-league football for Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who said he was comfortable investing £10,000 a week, and they signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, at the start of March.

After speculation over whether Bank of England Governor Mark Carney would leave in 2018 or stay until 2021 following the Brexit vote, he chose a “third way”: a one-year extension beyond 2018. While acknowledging the job’s heightened demands amid Brexit and recognizing markets’ desire for certainty, Carney said the decision was entirely personal, driven by family considerations—two daughters completing major exams in 2018 and plans to return to Canada—stressing the role requires total attention and that these were the only factors. Those around him dismissed suggestions of political pressure, tension with Prime Minister Theresa May, or sensitivity to criticism of pre-referendum forecasts. By the end of his extended term, the Article 50 process should be complete, after which a new governor will steer the UK’s economic future.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1: Jamille Matt put Blackpool ahead after 12 minutes by turning in Nathan Delfouneso’s chipped cross, but Kurtis Guthrie equalised from a corner five minutes later following Sam Slocombe’s save from Matthew Briggs. Slocombe then denied George Elokobi on the stroke of half-time before Guthrie hit the bar from two yards, and Blackpool’s Tom Aldred wasted late chances, including heading wide unmarked from eight yards with 15 minutes left. Colchester finished with 10 men when substitute Sean Murray was sent off in injury time.

Action Mental Health, a Northern Ireland charity, has launched the Healthy Me programme for P6–P7 pupils to help them cope with change and the stress of transfer tests and moving to secondary school. Piloted in five schools and launched at Carrick Primary School, Lurgan, the programme uses interactive workshops to promote emotional wellbeing, encourage help-seeking, identify support sources, and provide basic teacher training. P7 pupils face added pressure from unofficial transfer tests run by AQE and GL Assessment, with 14,681 entrants this year, up from 14,575 in 2015. Carrick’s P7 teacher Helen Hamilton notes rising anxiety among pupils and parents during the transition, highlighting the shift from close primary support to less frequent contact in secondary. Workshops teach breathing and relaxation techniques and encourage balancing busy schedules, reflecting the school’s view that emotional readiness underpins learning. Chief executive David Babington emphasizes building resilience amid modern stress, aligning with chief inspector Noelle Buick’s call for stronger preventative education to bolster young people’s resilience within pastoral care.

Developers Fawley Waterside plan a £1bn “merchant city” at the disused Fawley Power Station, retaining its 198 metre-high chimney as an attraction—touted as the tallest of its kind south of London’s Shard—within a scheme featuring a petal-shaped glass centerpiece, marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth; an outline planning application is due later this year, with construction possibly starting in 2018. The oil-fired plant on the western side of Southampton Water was commissioned in 1971, produced 2,000 MW using fuel from the nearby Esso refinery, contained 1,100 miles of cabling, could power one million homes, and closed in 2013 after more than 40 years; the 300-acre site was sold to Fawley Waterside in 2016, and the developer calls the chimney a signature asset that can be spectacularly reused with relatively little investment.
MODEL FAILED TO RETURN ANY OUTPUT

Ross Kemp will make a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Barbara’s final episodes, reuniting with brother Phil (Steve McFadden) to say goodbye to their mother Peggy after Dame Barbara’s surprise comeback revealed Peggy’s cancer had returned; producers confirmed Peggy, who reappeared on Friday after leaving in 2010, will die from the disease in emotional scenes airing in spring. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990–99 and again in 2005–06, said he couldn’t turn it down and expects classic episodes, while executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins hailed Grant’s homecoming with reunions including his brother and “old loves,” noting Grant’s storied history of family drama.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds at Anfield as second-placed Tottenham disappointed, leading Mauricio Pochettino to criticize their poor start, lack of desire, and inability to handle pressure, and to warn that if Chelsea win at Burnley to go 12 points clear it would be a big problem for their title hopes. Spurs’ away form is poor—just two wins on the road since 24 September, with defeats at Chelsea and Manchester United and draws at Arsenal and Manchester City—and they have only one win in their past 17 away games against fellow top-six sides. Pochettino said the first half showed a team not ready to fight for the Premier League, while Danny Murphy condemned their defensive setup—arguing they should have used a back three—citing a lack of pace and a poor away mindset that must improve quickly.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 declared governorships, delivering the biggest setback to the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999 and following the PDP’s first presidential loss, with APC leader Muhammadu Buhari to be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP lost key northern states including Katsina, Kaduna, and Adamawa (hit hard by Boko Haram), but retained Rivers, while winning eight governorships mostly in the south-east; Taraba’s result was pending and Imo was inconclusive due to spoiled ballots exceeding the victory margin, with no elections held in seven states. Analysts say the APC’s gains have reduced the PDP to a largely regional party strong in the south-east and Niger Delta: most northern states and Lagos went APC, yet the APC failed to win any of the five oil-producing states, raising concerns for Buhari about militant threats to oil output and federal revenue. INEC reported 66 violent incidents—more than in the presidential poll—mainly in Rivers and other southern states, prompting voting extensions in some areas, though overall the elections were more peaceful than in previous years. With the APC retaining Lagos, the president’s party will control the commercial capital for the first time since 1999, a significant shift given governors’ wide powers and large budgets. After 16 years in power, the PDP faces internal rebuilding amid defections, corruption allegations, and criticism over its handling of the Islamist insurgency.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis (19–22 July) is offering an augmented reality app that lets visitors trigger online content from on-site signs and posters, delivering videos and band interviews to phones and tablets. This year’s acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. Director Caroline Maclennan says the feature enhances visitors’ enjoyment and lets people worldwide interact with the festival, with content updated before and during the event to provide instant access to information and interviews, ticket purchases, and a taste of the festival wherever they are.
MODEL FAILED TO RETURN ANY OUTPUT

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, 38, was arrested at Tehran airport last April and in September received a five-year sentence on undisclosed charges; her secret appeal, understood to be held in Tehran on Wednesday, bars family attendance and has an unpredictable outcome that could quash, reduce, or increase the term. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, 41, criticizes the UK government’s lack of action, believes she is being used as a diplomatic bargaining chip, and says she endured solitary confinement, felt suicidal, and began a hunger strike before being moved out of solitary at Christmas. Their two-year-old daughter Gabriella remains in Iran with grandparents after her passport was confiscated, has largely lost her English in favor of Farsi, and communicates with her father mainly via Skype; he is seeking a visa to visit. Amnesty International UK calls her a prisoner of conscience held for peacefully exercising her rights and urges the appeal to order her immediate release.

Vincent “Vinnie” Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. At Ipswich Crown Court, prosecutors allege that optometrist Honey Rose, 35, failed to detect swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation, leading to a fatal buildup of brain fluid and pressure. They argue his death was preventable and that her conduct fell so far below expected standards as to be criminal; Rose denies gross negligence manslaughter. The trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, formerly of Guthrie near Forfar, arranged for a woman to have sex with a man he found via an adult website, filmed the encounters, and on 25 December 2014 sent a sexually explicit clip to the woman’s sister; after denying the charges, he was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing the woman into sexual activity and intercourse between 10 September 2013 and 17 September 2014, and of intentionally causing her sister and father to view sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner, was placed on the sex offenders register, and had his case remitted by Sheriff George Way to the High Court in Edinburgh due to its greater sentencing powers, where Lady Wolffe said the sentence must reflect society’s abhorrence; the woman said she felt blackmailed, Weatherhogg was assessed as a moderate risk of sexual re-offending, was a first offender, and his counsel said being remanded ahead of sentencing was a dramatic shock.

Afghanistan beat Ireland in a T20 in Greater Noida, replying to Ireland’s 165-5 with 171-4 and two overs to spare thanks to Samiullah Shenwari’s 56, Mohammad Shahzad’s 47 and an opening stand of 51 with Najeeb Tarakai (27). Ireland recovered from Paul Stirling’s early duck through opener Stuart Thompson’s 56, captain William Porterfield’s 39 and Gary Wilson’s unbeaten 41, while Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2-23, the only multiple-wicket haul on a batting-dominated day. Porterfield said Ireland were about 15 runs short of the 180 they targeted and didn’t execute well with the ball. The teams meet again at the same venue on Friday, while paceman Boyd Rankin misses the T20s with a back issue but is expected back for the five ODIs starting 15 March.

Barcelona insist they committed no offence in Neymar’s transfer and, to address differing interpretations of the contracts, filed a supplementary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 while maintaining their original tax payment was compliant and denying any tax-related crime. They signed Neymar, 22, from Santos for £48.6m, with his parents receiving £34m, and say that when the initial fee, signing-on fee, five-year wages, agents’ fees, and this tax payment are included, Neymar will have cost the club £106.8m. Although Barcelona initially stated a €57m (£48.6m) fee, it is alleged the true cost was higher, and a judge has ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue investigating the deal. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating money and is being investigated, which he denies, and there is no confirmation the case will be dropped after the payment. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league matches and three in seven Champions League games this season.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on Koh Tao beach on 15 September. UK Metropolitan Police officers who flew to Thailand last month to review the case have completed their work “as far as possible,” will return to the UK to compile a report, and will update the families, thanking Thai authorities for facilitating the visit. Two 21-year-old Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, allegedly confessed; Thai police deny reports they later retracted their confessions. The suspects are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty. The UK Foreign Office summoned the Thai charge d’affaires over concerns about DNA verification and alleged mistreatment, and the UK visit followed an agreement between Thai PM Prayuth Chan-ocha and David Cameron after earlier refusals of assistance. Post-mortems found Miller died from drowning and a head blow, and Witheridge from head wounds; Thai police say DNA on Witheridge matched the suspects.

Virtual reality is increasingly used beyond entertainment to deepen understanding and engagement across society—by journalists, educators, healthcare providers, and retailers. In the UK, the National Autistic Society created a VR film that simulates an autistic child’s sensory overload in a shopping centre to improve public understanding (despite 99% awareness of autism, only 16% understand it; over a quarter of autistic people have been asked to leave public places). Alzheimer’s Research UK’s A Walk Through Dementia shows everyday challenges of the condition. Retailers employ VR for sales: estate agents offer virtual property tours, Westfield showcases fashion, and Ikea’s HTC Vive kitchen app on Steam let users redesign spaces—and, after demand, throw virtual meatballs—prompting consideration of in‑store rollout. Healthcare uses include surgical training—Dr Shafi Ahmed’s live VR operation drew 5,000 viewers in 14 countries and led to Medical Realities’ Virtual Surgeon—and therapy for PTSD and arachnophobia (83% of 23 participants improved after approaching a virtual spider). In education, Google Expeditions (Cardboard + app) brings virtual field trips to UK schools, while Evanescent Studios pilots Mandarin learning; firms like NetDragon test head‑tilt cues to gauge engagement, though costs and computing needs remain barriers.

Russia officially opened the Su-24 jet’s black box in Moscow before journalists and diplomats, but investigation head Nikolai Primak said flight information appeared to be missing; an analysis due next week could clarify the jet’s location when it was hit. The Su-24, part of Russia’s Syria contingent supporting President Assad, was shot down by Turkish F-16s on 24 November, with Turkey insisting it violated its airspace despite warnings and Russia claiming it was within Syrian airspace; President Putin accused Turkey of subservience to the US and “creeping Islamisation.” Both crew ejected—the pilot was apparently killed by militants on the ground while the navigator was rescued—and a Russian marine sent to rescue them was also killed, with a helicopter destroyed on the ground. The incident sparked a Russia-Turkey crisis, with Moscow demanding an apology and imposing sanctions, including a ban on package holidays that could cost Turkey billions.

Scotland’s women have won all five qualifiers and host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, with that game and the 20 September return in Reykjavik likely to decide the group; Iceland, the top seeds, are ranked one place higher (20th) and have four wins from four, but Scotland are in pole position to reach next summer’s Netherlands finals—either by topping the group or as one of the six best runners-up—avoiding a play-off. Bayern Munich forward Lisa Evans, 24, says missing out again after play-off losses for Euro 2013 and last year’s World Cup would be devastating, yet believes home support can help them beat Iceland. Twelve of the 20-player squad are based abroad (five in England, four in Sweden, two at Seattle Reign, including BBC Women’s Footballer of the Year Kim Little), and Evans—formerly of Glasgow City and Turbine Potsdam, now a Bundesliga champion with Bayern—argues that the competitiveness and different playing culture of top leagues, especially in Germany, are improving players and strengthening Scotland as they push for a first major finals.

A review for the Commission on Local Tax Reform, led by Prof Kenneth Gibb of the University of Glasgow, found no “magic bullet” for fixing Scotland’s local taxation, noting council tax had structural flaws from inception and lack of reform worsened problems. Property taxes, used by almost all OECD countries, are seen by academics as “good” due to stability, resistance to avoidance, and potentially positive housing market effects, but cause confusion over whether they are wealth taxes or service charges and are viewed by some as unfair because they aren’t linked to current income. Local income taxes are generally perceived as fairer but create revenue volatility for local authorities and offer limited scope to vary rates to match local priorities. The commission, set up by the Scottish government and council body Cosla, will hold a public consultation and report in the autumn. A Scottish government spokesman called the current council tax “as a whole” unfair and said ministers await the commission’s autumn report on fairer alternatives.

After reports that third-party software was used to steal celebrities’ photos from iCloud, Apple expanded its two-step verification to cover iCloud backups: logging in on a new device now requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted phone or via Find My iPhone in addition to the password, or access to iCloud and Apple’s stores is denied; users can recover access with a 14-character key and now get email alerts when a backup download starts. Previously, backups weren’t protected, enabling tools like Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker to download full data; Elcomsoft’s owner says Apple’s update securely blocks his method and even stops listing linked devices/backups, though he warns recovery keys can be lost or stolen. Another expert downplays that risk and argues two-factor should be the default rather than opt-in. Apple says it will more aggressively encourage two-factor and stronger passwords, with Tim Cook emphasizing user awareness.

During the 23 January–22 May campaign period, UKIP, which won May’s election, spent £2,956,737 (68p per each of its 4,376,635 votes); the Conservatives spent £2,980,815 (79p per vote); Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339 (26p per vote); and the Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote) while losing 11 of their 12 MEPs. The Green Party, which came fourth, spent £534,249 (43p per each of its 1,255,573 votes), and the SNP spent £267,372. In total, the six highest-spending parties spent £9,347,087 on campaigning, according to the Electoral Commission, and all but Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has cancelled his Barrow contract by mutual consent to join their National League rivals and could face his former club on 18 February; the ex-Aldershot and Exeter defender has also played in Italy. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21—recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams and previously with Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps—is set to move subject to international clearance. Nicholson praised Anderson’s leadership and Keating’s hunger, while the Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred gelding, collapsed and died after narrowly beating Thistlecrack to win the Cotswold Chase on Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority said he suffered a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, noting such incidents are rare, can occur without underlying health issues, and the sport aims to better understand and prevent them. Although he had previously shown post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling), he had never collapsed and showed no such symptoms on Saturday; his welfare had been closely monitored, and a BBC correspondent emphasized there were “no significant underlying health issues,” with the report concluding a rare racetrack haemorrhage. Owned by Trevor Hemmings and ridden by Leighton Aspell, he fought back after being headed by King George winner Thistlecrack to secure victory. He had earlier won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and trainer Oliver Sherwood called him the “horse of a lifetime.”

Ahead of the 5 May election, Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, herself standing down, was moved to tears as the Scottish Parliament heard farewell speeches from departing MSPs including former first minister Alex Salmond, Labour backbencher Duncan McNeil, and Annabel Goldie. In his valedictory, Salmond (first minister 2007-2014) said Scotland is "not divided, but diverse," argued there is broad consensus for Holyrood to assume greater responsibility, welcomed new powers in the Scotland Bill while insisting they fall short of referendum-period pledges by unionist politicians, added light-hearted jokes, and signed off with "goodbye... for now"; Marwick thanked him for his contribution as an MSP and as first minister, saying he had served the parliament and Scotland "with distinction." McNeil, an MSP since 1999, warned Holyrood must strengthen accountability, scrutiny and its committee system, saying it now has lessons to learn from Westminster or face consequences. Goldie also bid farewell, joking she would miss dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney and his "huge outbursts of faux indignation."

A forthcoming Beauty and the Beast film adds a star as Mrs Potts (the housekeeper magically turned into a teapot, voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version), with Kevin Kline as Maurice, Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou; directed by Bill Condon, it begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and is set for US release on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service will reveal its intentions and inform relatives of its decisions at a private meeting in Warrington at 11:00 BST regarding potential charges over the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, in which 96 fans were fatally injured at an FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest in Sheffield; last year, new inquests found the fans were unlawfully killed. In January, evidence files on 23 suspects were referred to the CPS—15 from Operation Resolve into the causes of the disaster and eight from an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into the conduct of South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police afterward—with Sue Hemming of the CPS to brief families. Margaret Aspinall of the Hillsborough Family Support Group described the long wait, anticipated mixed emotions, and the families’ determination to seek accountability.
