Chelmsford Prison has warned residents about numerous recent incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, with a former inmate claiming the jail is notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A nearby resident said she witnessed four such throws in two weeks and that the prison plans an evening meeting to advise locals on what to do if items are thrown over. The Ministry of Justice said staff work extremely hard to stop contraband but more must be done, with the Justice Secretary asking for a review of tools to tackle the issue; it also said there is no evidence of drones at Chelmsford despite claims they deliver goods to windows. Laws now allow up to two years’ imprisonment for people who smuggle packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a married mother-of-three and lollipop lady for 20 years, suffered serious head injuries last December outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston when she was hit by a VW Golf driven by Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston. At Luton Crown Court, Wright admitted striking her but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving, saying he was blinded by the setting sun and could not remember the traffic light color. Prosecutors said his car failed to stop at a red light while Blackburn, wearing appropriate clothing, stepped into the road to escort a woman and her six-year-old daughter as traffic in the opposite direction had stopped. Blackburn is now in residential care; Judge Michael Kay QC briefly paused proceedings as Wright apologized, and the court heard the sun was about 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into his eyes. The trial continues.

Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss next year’s Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her final-year veterinary medicine exams in May clash with the April event; though disappointed, she is prioritizing her degree and believes she has two or three more Olympics ahead, with events undecided. She says the World Indoor Championships in March are potentially a target and she’d like to run in Birmingham, despite her studies being very full on. At the World Athletics Championships in London she finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m, where Hellen Obiri won gold ahead of Almaz Ayana with Sifan Hassan third; Muir set a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 and, after five races in 10 days, was pleased and optimistic about her future.

Irish police have begun an excavation-based search expected to last several weeks at a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, near the R112 and River Liffey, as part of a renewed investigation into the December 2000 disappearance of 22-year-old Trevor Deely from County Kildare, last seen walking home after a Christmas party. A six-detective team reviewed the case, enhancing CCTV that shows Deely speaking to a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street—where Deely had returned to get an umbrella—and a similar-looking man later following him on Haddington Road. Footage was released in April, but the man has not been identified; Gardaí have renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Del Potro, the former US Open champion ranked 165 after more than two years out with injuries and three wrist operations, beat Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 at Wimbledon in his first Grand Slam since the 2014 Australian Open; in Andy Murray’s half of the draw, he will next face either 32nd seed Lucas Pouille or Donald Young, saying he now feels “alive” and is enjoying tennis again. Also in that half, 15th seed Nick Kyrgios came from two sets to one down to defeat Germany’s Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 in a rain-affected second round and will meet 22nd seed Feliciano Lopez, who rallied past Fabio Fognini 3-6 6-7 6-3 6-3 6-3, with the winner to play Murray or John Millman in the last 16; elsewhere, 10th seed Tomas Berdych beat Benjamin Becker 6-4 6-1 6-2 and 12th seed Jo-Wilfried Tsonga defeated Juan Monaco 6-1 6-4 6-3.

Morocco regained entry to 2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualifying after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned CAF’s ban stemming from Morocco’s refusal to host the 2015 finals over Ebola concerns, also reducing a fine from $1m to $50,000; Equatorial Guinea stepped in to host 2015 with just 64 days’ preparation. Tunisia nearly faced expulsion from the 2017 tournament after furious complaints about a contentious late penalty in their 2015 quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea, but after a meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou they apologised, stressed they never alleged corruption, and the dispute was resolved. In the 2017 qualifying draw, Tunisia face Togo, Liberia and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco meet Cape Verde, Libya and Sao Tome in Group F. If Tunisia reach the 2017 finals in Gabon, it would be their 13th consecutive Nations Cup, a record.

Once-dominant McLaren—182 wins, 12 drivers’ and eight constructors’ titles—now view a fourth-row start and some points as success after a slump that began in 2013 when they lost their chassis direction; today the car is strong but the Honda power unit is the weak link. Their story is cyclical: early titles in 1974 and 1976, rebuilding under Ron Dennis to domination in 1984–85, an all-conquering Honda era with Senna/Prost (15 wins from 16 in 1988), renewed success with Hakkinen and Mercedes in 1998–99 (their last constructors’ crown), then setbacks including 2007’s disqualification and $100m fine over Ferrari data and 2009’s “lie-gate.” Despite wins through 2012, titles dried up (bar 2008) and victories have since ceased. Dennis, back after 2013, insists McLaren will be the next to break Mercedes’ hegemony and win “championships, plural,” saying the chassis is already among the best and Honda will fix the engine next year. The team still fields two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, who rejoined in 2015 betting the renewed Honda partnership could deliver his third title; for now, belief in a turnaround is all that sustains both his hopes and McLaren’s storied reputation.

At Limavady Magistrates Court it was heard that after paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, police found people still on the premises and receipts showing alcohol served until 04:49, leading the judge to order a three-month closure. License holder Colleen O’Neill, 43, of Kevin Lynch Park, was charged with two counts of allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours and fined £3,000; James Thomas, 44, of the same address, faced one count and was fined £1,000. The defence admitted licensing laws were not strictly adhered to and the bar operated into the morning; the judge described O’Neill’s record as appalling, called the case among the worst he had seen, and noted he lacked power to impose a custodial sentence.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA single-season three-point record by hitting eight threes (six before halftime) and scoring 45 points with nine assists to rally the Golden State Warriors from 13 down to a 116-105 win over the Portland Trail Blazers, avoiding their first three-game losing streak; Klay Thompson added 26. Curry surpassed his previous mark of 272 set two years ago in Portland. LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 points and six rebounds, and Damian Lillard 20 points and eight assists for Portland, which has clinched the Northwest Division. In Chicago, Pau Gasol’s 16 points and 15 rebounds led the Bulls’ comeback from a 19-point halftime deficit with a 39-8 run to open the second half in an 89-78 win over the Miami Heat, dealing a huge blow to Miami’s playoff hopes; Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson scored 14 each, Mike Dunleavy and Derrick Rose 12 each, Chicago moved back to No. 3 in the East, while Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds and Dwyane Wade scored nine on 4-for-20 as the Heat were outscored 57-27 after halftime.

At Melwood, Liverpool’s Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Markovic met YouTube free-kick sensation Bas van Velzen, initially believing he was a competition winner there for a dead-ball masterclass; after a few attempts it became clear he wasn’t a regular fan as he showcased his skills, including a top-corner strike that left the stand-in keeper helpless, while Balotelli, after a poor first effort, also sent a perfectly executed free-kick into the top corner. Van Velzen said meeting his idols, pretending he wasn’t very good, and seeing their surprised reactions was amazing, and he capped the session by unveiling Balotelli’s infamous slogan, referencing the famous T-shirt the forward wore during Manchester City’s 6-1 win over United in October 2011.

A Canadian study reported in JAMA Oncology found that, among 676 women with BRCA1/2 mutations (345 underwent oophorectomy), removing the ovaries after a breast cancer diagnosis markedly improved outcomes for BRCA1 carriers: overall 20-year survival was 77.4%, oophorectomy was associated with a 62% reduction in breast cancer mortality and a 65% reduction in deaths from all causes (no similar benefit seen in BRCA2), and nine ovarian cancer deaths occurred in women who did not have the surgery. Although oophorectomy occurred on average six years after diagnosis, BRCA1 carriers who had the procedure within two years saw a 73% reduction in death, with protection evident immediately and lasting 15 years, particularly in oestrogen-receptor–negative disease, which affects about one in four cases and is especially aggressive. Reflecting Angelina Jolie’s choices, editors urged that oophorectomy be part of treatment discussions at diagnosis for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage cancers, while researchers called for more studies, especially for BRCA2 and earlier surgery. BRCA1/2 mutation carriers face a 50–80% lifetime breast cancer risk and heightened ovarian tumor risk; mutations occur in about 2.3% of Ashkenazi Jewish women, and genetic testing is available for BRCA1/2 and other genes (TP53, PTEN).

On Easter Sunday shortly before 10 a.m. in Durham, North Carolina, married couple Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed while lingering on the tracks by Amtrak’s northbound Carolinian (Train No. 80) traveling from Charlotte to New York City on Norfolk Southern property. Both were pronounced dead at the scene. None of the 166 passengers were injured, though one person fell ill during the nearly 2-hour-45-minute delay before the train continued. A man who knew the couple from collecting scrap metal said they may have lived in a homeless camp and had recently asked for help moving a grocery cart across the tracks, urging compassion for people in need. Durham is about 25 miles northwest of the train’s next destination, Raleigh, and the Charlotte–New York trip typically takes about 13 hours 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, 66, a former mid-level Medellín cartel member who fled Colombia in the 1980s, worked unpaid for 27 years as a DEA undercover informant in exchange for a promise of U.S. citizenship, aiding global stings and prosecutions of figures like cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and ex-Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. After declining health forced his retirement, his last temporary visa expired January 1, and the DEA refused to help with his citizenship once he went public, leaving him technically in the U.S. illegally, unable to collect Social Security without a green card or passport, and fearing he would be killed if deported. Supporters including former handler DEA agent Mike McManus—who gave Toro $5,000 for an operation after the agency declined—call the situation government bureaucracy at its worst, while Toro seeks the promised citizenship and is prepared to go into hiding.

ICANN, which initially approved the .sucks top-level domain as part of a broad expansion beyond .com and .org, is reconsidering after an advisory panel of industry groups and firms like Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay complained, and has asked the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada’s Office of Consumer Affairs to assess whether Vox Populi Registry Ltd.’s practices are illegal, saying it could declare a contract breach and seek remedies if so. Vox Populi began accepting .sucks registrations from trademark holders and celebrities on March 30, recommended charging $2,499 per year (with most sales via resellers around $2,000), and plans to offer consumer registrations for $10 per year starting in September—an approach critics call a predatory “shakedown” that leverages the threat of later public availability. Numerous brands (e.g., youtube.sucks, bing.sucks, visa.sucks, bankofamerica.sucks, yahoo.sucks, telusmobility.sucks) have been purchased, Kevin Spacey reportedly paid to have his .sucks domain removed, and Taylor Swift has previously paid defensively over .adult domains, while Vox Populi’s CEO argues the domain enables companies to engage with critics and complies with ICANN rules.

In 1988 a newborn boy’s body, wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury’s bag, was found in Windmill Pit pond at Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk; despite an inquest, the cause of death and the mother’s identity were unknown and villagers funded his burial at St Peter’s church. During a periodic review, police exhumed the remains last year and, using DNA from a leg bone matched via a relative on the national database, identified and arrested the mother, who admitted she had concealed her pregnancy, delivered the baby alone stillborn, and placed him in the pond. Police ruled out third-party involvement, and the initial suspicion of infanticide was dropped; she remains on bail while the CPS considers charges of failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. A second post-mortem found no evidence of foul play. The baby was reburied on June 5 last year—the 26th anniversary of his discovery—and named Peter after the church, with a new headstone funded by the charity Hana’s Gift. Detectives said advances in DNA solved a 27-year mystery and expressed empathy for the mother.

In Bath, Somerset, taxi driver Michael Young, 56, was ruled by High Court Justice Edis to have unlawfully imprisoned passenger Kristopher Hicks after wrongly suspecting him of planning to evade the fare in 2010 and driving him back toward the rank despite objections; Hicks, then 23, jumped from the moving taxi at over 20 mph, sustaining devastating brain injuries, developing epilepsy, and requiring 24-hour care from his mother. The court held Young liable for damages but imposed a 50% reduction due to Hicks’s decision to jump, and awarded an additional £250 for the unlawful imprisonment. The final compensation—expected to be around half of the hundreds of thousands of pounds sought—will be determined at a later hearing, and both sides were granted permission to appeal.

Tornado sirens sounded Wednesday night in Kansas as storms brought multiple twister reports, including one spotted about 6 miles northwest of Goddard that moved northeast and missed Wichita, with additional sightings near Aetna in the southwest. The National Weather Service indicated a possible tornado in Potosi, Missouri, where reports and images showed wind damage, flooding, a fallen tree, roof damage, and a street overtaken by water; nearby, Leadington residents shared photos of dark clouds, and a Farmington user reported baseball-size hail. CNN’s Chad Myers warned storms would pop up all night and that nighttime tornadoes are especially dangerous, and the Weather Service forecast more storms Thursday across the Midwest, the Mississippi and Tennessee river valleys, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Ahead of their middleweight fight in New Jersey on Saturday, Luke Rockhold targets a fourth straight win and a title shot, vowing to be the “bull” pressing forward against Lyoto Machida’s “matador” style by cutting him off, forcing exchanges, and leveraging his all-around game; he believes Machida has limited paths to victory—especially on the ground—despite respecting his long-standing elite status. Rockhold says he’s prepared to chase Machida down, coming off a win over Michael Bisping. Machida, fresh from defeating CB Dollaway, insists that applying his style and strategy can stop Rockhold, argues the winner deserves a title shot (noting the scrapped Jacare vs Yoel Romero eliminator), and reports an eight-week camp with Glover Teixeira and others, feeling calm and ready while keeping specific reads on Rockhold close to the vest.

Footage from Fort Pierce, Florida shows a light Aerostar aircraft approaching the Aero Acres residential airpark and touching down without deploying its landing gear, scraping its belly as the propellers strike the runway; the pilot then applied full throttle, the props hit again but the engines kept running, and he regained control and departed. The videographer, who first thought it was a fly-by, realized the gear was up and described the unforgettable sound of the belly and prop impacts while fearing a crash. According to WPBF 25 News, the pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis, who has flown for almost 50 years and was accompanied by his dog Buddy, flew about 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. Gear-up landings are most commonly caused by human error, with mechanical faults another possibility, and the FAA is investigating.

Manuel Pellegrini admitted disappointment with Yaya Toure’s form but said he won’t rest him and will back him through the season, even as Manchester City are prepared to listen to offers for the 31-year-old, who has two years left on a £220,000-a-week deal and is determined not to be forced out. City, with just 18 points from their last 39, host West Ham without injured captain Vincent Kompany, and a defeat could let fifth-placed Liverpool close to within a point with a win at West Brom next weekend. Joe Hart said players must take responsibility and that Pellegrini retains dressing-room support, while the manager noted he picks the team. Meanwhile, West Ham’s Sam Allardyce, amid interest from City and Chelsea in left back Aaron Cresswell—valued for his homegrown status—warned him not to repeat Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair’s limited-playing-time experiences at City.

Domenico Rancadore, a 65-year-old Sicilian mafia fugitive dubbed the “Godfather of Uxbridge,” who was convicted in absentia in 1999 and given a seven-year term for Cosa Nostra association, will be allowed to remain in the UK because his sentence expired in October 2014 under Italian law (penalties are extinguished after more than double their length), leading to the withdrawal of his European Arrest Warrant; his conviction stands, and the case may still be appealed to Italy’s Supreme Court. Arrested in August 2013 after over two decades in Britain living as “Marc Skinner,” Rancadore had lost an extradition ruling in February, but it later emerged the sentence had already expired; a CPS consent order and Westminster Magistrates’ Court approval are expected to discharge him, and he need not attend. Known as “the Professor,” he was convicted for acting as a “man of honour” taking bribes in Palermo, and earlier extradition rulings considered his heart condition and Italian prison conditions. Legal experts criticised the time and cost wasted; the Italian embassy blamed a CPS failure to appeal a March 2014 decision—requiring Italy to restart the process and allowing time for expiry—while the CPS disputed the impact of that delay but acknowledged the earlier error.

Mr Mole, AP McCoy’s mount trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites for Saturday’s seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown, alongside Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson’s Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville in place of the injured Barry Geraghty. The race gives McCoy six rivals and will be his last ride in a Grade One, with his book of rides for his final day as a professional to be finalised on Friday morning. McCoy announced his intention to retire after winning on Mr Mole at Newbury in February. Other runners include Mick Channon’s Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was raped and strangled in 1975, recently chose to view long-avoided crime scene photos on a police investigator’s laptop, saying she now wants revenge and regrets following her late husband’s advice not to see them; she described Marcia’s swollen face, blackened mouth, vomit, pulled-out hair, and blood on her scalp. Marcia’s body was found 33 days after she disappeared, 150 yards from home in a rarely used windowless garage, under a shower curtain and a child’s wading pool, with cookies scattered, her cookie money missing, and a fractured neck. The murder was Nashville’s most notorious unsolved case for 33 years; a 1979 charge against a 15-year-old neighbor was dropped for lack of evidence. Jerome Sidney Barrett—incarcerated on sex charges for most of 1974–2002—was arrested in 2006 after DNA on Marcia’s clothing matched his following his arrest for the 1975 murder of Vanderbilt student Sarah Vannatta Des Prez, and in 2009 he was convicted of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years.

Rory McIlroy, the world No 1 at age 25, says it is “unthinkable” he won’t win the Masters during his career to complete the Grand Slam and join Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus and Tiger Woods, calling his 2011 Augusta collapse—when he led by four before a closing 80 and finished 10 behind Charl Schwartzel—the most important day of his career for what it taught him. He rebounded by winning the US Open by eight two months later and has since added the 2012 US PGA and both the Open and US PGA last year. Despite only one top-10 in six Masters (T8 last year, when he was outscored by his marker in round three), he believes Augusta suits him, expects to win there multiple times, and views securing a first green jacket as crucial. After calling off his wedding to Caroline Wozniacki and settling a costly legal dispute with his former management, he says the course is his sanctuary and he aims to block out Augusta’s hype and simply play his best.

A CNN roundup of the week’s trending stories includes: four rainbows over New York City captured by fashion CEO Amanda Curtis; China cracking down on the growing practice of hiring exotic dancers for rural wakes; RDJ becoming agitated during a UK Channel 4 interview about his private life; the #KylieJennerChallenge lip-plumping fad of sucking on jars; 102-year-old Alice Barker “going back in time” with filmmakers; a bomb-referencing prom-posal rejected by a school, with the student alleging racism; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast; an almost unrecognizable Johnny Depp in the Black Mass trailer; a Fresh Prince-themed pregnancy announcement; and a military dad photobombing his son.

Official data show 272 children in England were hospitalised in the past year with disabilities from foetal alcohol syndrome after prenatal alcohol exposure, but experts warn the true number is higher, with WHO research suggesting at least 1 in 100 UK babies—about 7,500 annually—may suffer learning, behavioural and physical problems, including deformed limbs. Elizabeth Mitchell of the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome says affected children do not get better and the condition is vastly under-diagnosed. A case highlighted is 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who needs help getting dressed, has no sense of danger and will never live independently; her adoptive parents noticed issues at age three, she was diagnosed at five, and they founded the Foetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder Trust in 2007. Alcohol in pregnancy is also linked to liver, kidney and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss and epilepsy. Government guidance advises pregnant women not to drink—and if they do, no more than two units twice a week—though Mitchell argues it should recommend total abstinence.

A masked, axe-wielding Shaun Andrew McKerry, 31, from Coundon near Bishop Auckland—an ex-juvenile offender nicknamed “Boomerang Boy” or “Homing Pigeon Boy” for always returning home after crimes—attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores, County Durham, at 8 pm on March 15, demanding cash from assistant Andrea Brighty. Owner Sab Dhillon rugby-tackled him while his wife Sam struck McKerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him and turning his face to the cameras before police arrived minutes later to arrest him. McKerry pleaded guilty at Durham Crown Court to attempted robbery and was jailed for six years. He began shoplifting at 12, had been arrested 80 times by 15, had convictions including aggravated vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters, and burglary, once stole 22 charity boxes while dressed as a woman, and was described as a one-man crime wave, with 80 arrests in 1995 and 45 during 36 weeks out of prison in 1998.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow, 23; Craig Stoner, 24; Simon Radford, 31; and Darren Smalley, 35—were charged in Nova Scotia with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, alleged to have occurred on April 10 after an alcohol-fuelled party at Canadian barracks following a Royal Navy ice hockey tournament; police sources say all four had intercourse with a woman in her early 20s from Halifax. Granted bail of over £2,000 each, they must remain in Nova Scotia until trial, surrender their passports, live at Halifax’s Stadacona naval base, not apply for new passports, avoid contact with the victim and six witnesses, and remain employed by the Royal Navy without resigning unless the court permits. Under a deal with the British government they will continue to work and be paid, and the British High Commission is assisting; the men did not seek return to the UK. They are due back in court on May 27, the investigation is still at an early stage with forensic results potentially leading to additional charges, and the offenses carry penalties of up to 14 years in prison.

Valerie Jackson, a Las Vegas mother, cares for her four-year-old son RJ, one of just 70 people worldwide with Netherton’s syndrome, an extremely rare congenital skin disease and severe form of ichthyosis that makes skin red, scaly, and seemingly scalded, and can bring infection and allergy problems; infants often lose heat, water, and protein, gain weight slowly, and face high infection risk. Misunderstanding of RJ’s appearance has led to adult bullying, denial of entry to play centers, and a frightening incident where five armed police surrounded them in a Walmart after a stranger reported suspected abuse; the officer apologized. After RJ’s rash worsened in intensive care at birth and doctors had no answers, Valerie identified his condition through a Facebook Netherton’s group started by UK parents of Jack Oldacres; their tips guide his care, including frequent cleansing and heavy moisturizing with Vaseline multiple times a day (previously every few hours) and limited bathing. There is no cure, diagnosis is difficult because many diseases cause red skin, the condition can appear without family history yet is thought genetic (carried by parents), symptoms often improve over time though skin may remain red, itchy, and sensitive, and his family, including father Reginald and supportive siblings, manage the pain while hoping for greater public awareness.

Transport for London began removing Protein World’s “Are you beach body ready?” posters featuring model Renee Somerfield from the London Underground, a move campaigners celebrated, though TfL said it was simply the scheduled end of a three-week paid run, noted it had received one complaint, would consider customer reaction and ASA/CAP guidance for future ads, and condemned graffiti. The ad triggered a major backlash: over 50,000 petition signatures, defaced posters, 216 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (under assessment), a May 2 Hyde Park protest in the works, and thousands of critical tweets. Protein World claimed the image was unphotoshopped and replied combatively on social media, calling critics “sympathisers for fatties” and asking “why make your insecurities our problem?”. On Good Morning Britain, Susanna Reid called the ad “anxiety inducing,” while Protein World’s marketing head Richard Staveley defended it as promoting health, labeled critics an “irrational minority,” reported a bomb threat under police investigation, and said the “fantastic” campaign would not change. Supporters included Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick, and the controversy comes amid rapid UK growth in protein powder sales, from £73m in 2007 to £170m in 2012, with £358m forecast by 2017.

Rail firms faced criticism for planning fare hikes of up to 87% just ten days after the general election despite pledges to freeze prices, prompting Prime Minister David Cameron to write to First Great Western (FGW) requesting an urgent review of near-doubling fares on the London–Cotswolds route through his Witney constituency. From May 17, Charlbury–London off-peak returns that currently permit evening peak travel would rise from £33.30 to £62.40 (87%). Train companies can raise unregulated fares—about half their revenue and including off-peak and advance-purchase tickets—three times a year. FGW said the change aligns the North Cotswolds route with others and highlighted cheaper advance singles that could make a return about £20 if booked ahead. Other increases include London Midland’s Crewe–Northampton off-peak first-class single from £30 to £37; Virgin’s Stafford–Liverpool anytime return from £26.50 to £33 (24.5%); and a Virgin Manchester–Stoke anytime first-class day return from £29 to £35.30 (22%), with Virgin saying most rises are on its “Virgin Trains-only” fares, at least 20% cheaper than rivals’, and that its West Coast overall rise is 1.65%. Trainsplit.com said passengers may be surprised given party freeze pledges and reported that hundreds of anytime and off-peak returns rose 40% in January, with increases on tickets bought on the day and on rural routes.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left blind in his left eye after yobs threw stones and bricks at his Oldham, Greater Manchester home around 11–11.20 pm on April 18; when he opened the door to confront them, a brick was thrown directly at him, causing a forehead wound and irreparable eye damage despite emergency surgery. Young, a retired HGV driver who served with the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers, and his wife Elaine, 54—newlyweds of three weeks who met 14 months ago—had been writing wedding gift thank‑you cards at the time. Police say there is no known motive and it may have been reckless vandalism; an investigation is underway with appeals for information via 101. Shaken and feeling unsafe, the couple plan to move to Elaine’s flat in Southport.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, a former England Under-19 international, has signed a one-year contract extension keeping him at the county until the end of the 2016 season after a successful return from injury. He missed the entire 2014 season with leg injuries from a road accident last April that killed his father, Keith, and required ankle surgery, but made his comeback during Derbyshire’s pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the season. Derbyshire’s elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton’s character, work in training and off the field, and recent form, expressing delight at his return and hoping the new deal boosts his confidence.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw from Stretford was diagnosed with aggressive neuroblastoma that had spread to his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones; after 80 days of chemotherapy, surgery to remove a kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy at the Christie Clinic in Manchester—during which he decorated his immobilizing mask like a Ninja Turtle and wore a superhero costume—doctors have declared him cancer-free, with regular check-ups planned. His story drew worldwide attention, gifts from Nickelodeon, and a Cancer Research UK Little Star Award; he now fronts the charity’s Kids & Teens campaign, and parents Oliver (25) and Stacey (23) say he’s active and hope he’ll soon return to school. The piece also explains that neuroblastoma is a rare, aggressive childhood cancer (fewer than 100 UK cases annually), usually starting in the adrenal glands or nerve tissues along the spine, capable of spreading widely; most patients are under five, it is the second most common solid childhood tumor (8% of children’s cancers), symptoms vary by site (including fatigue, appetite loss, bone pain, abdominal swelling, bowel/urinary and breathing/swallowing problems, or leg weakness), diagnosis requires multiple tests, and treatment can include surgery, chemotherapy, antibody treatment, and radiotherapy.

Aston Villa manager Tim Sherwood says 19-year-old Jack Grealish should focus on securing his place at Villa before deciding between the Republic of Ireland and England, after starring in the FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool. Sherwood, referencing similar advice he gave Nabil Bentaleb to follow his heart when choosing Algeria over France, stresses the choice is Grealish’s and should come after more first-team appearances, praising his confidence and dribbling. Sportsmail says Grealish is split and expected to decide at season’s end; he has played for Ireland’s youth teams while England are interested. Grealish’s father, Kevin, agrees the priority is club form, calling the decision difficult and noting a friendly soon where he suggests Jack could play 45 minutes for each country.

Private jet travel is a large and growing industry—2.5 million US flights and 705,000 in Europe in 2013, with a market worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe—where landing fees vary widely and can be steep. TheRichest, using a 767-400 as the baseline, lists the 10 most expensive airports to land: Haneda/Tokyo £4,559 ($6,850), Narita/Tokyo £3,728 ($5,600), Kansai/Osaka £3,594 ($5,400), Toronto Pearson £3,461 ($

A video from Clackamas County, Oregon, shows Cooper the Labrador, owned by dogpatch resort operator Katie Gallegos, gulping a McDonald’s ice cream cone in one bite while his smaller pal Daisy takes a few polite licks; the clip has been viewed over seven million times. Gallegos says Cooper always eats quickly and ensures Daisy gets her share first, adding that Daisy only gets a few licks due to her size. While some viewers called the scene cute and hilarious, others criticized giving dogs ice cream; Gallegos defends it, noting Cooper is in excellent health and that her previous dog Sammy lived to 19 while having ice cream about once a week. Another video shows the dogs getting a Starbucks “pup-uccino,” with Cooper taking the whole cup in his mouth to finish it; Gallegos says it’s just whip cream in a cup with no coffee.

Kilmarnock have appointed interim manager Gary Locke as permanent boss on a three-year deal after a successful interim spell; the former Hearts manager joined as assistant to Allan Johnston last summer and took charge when his ex-Tynecastle team-mate quit at the start of February, with the 41-year-old losing just once in seven games since, set to speak at a Friday morning press conference after signing alongside chairman Jim Mann.

Jessica Kemp, a 32-year-old mother from Eustis, says teachers at a Seminole County elementary school threatened to remove and suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, from class because the doterra essential oils she applies to his head and neck to help keep him calm and focused smell and distract other students. She says he has used the oils all year but a teacher’s aide complained, and she received a school board letter saying the scents had become a problem for staff and students. Kemp insists the oils help and will fight the decision, while the Lake County School District later said Logan would not be suspended, calling it a health issue. The family uses oils such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood; the company describes its products as “beautifully and powerfully fragrant,” and the Daily Mail Online has contacted doterra for comment.

A massive fire around 3 p.m. Wednesday obliterated the Sandpiper beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, destroying 90 condos and causing the building to collapse as smoke and flames, visible from three miles away, poured toward the ocean. Twelve fire crews used cranes but could not enter due to the blaze’s intensity, which melted paint on nearby buildings; offshore winds aided visibility for firefighters. The complex, open May–November and used as holiday homes, included units owned by residents like Janice Sklarek, while building manager Rob Taber, who lived there, said he lost everything. The cause remains unknown and is under investigation, including reports it may have started near a car parked by the complex.

Approaching her 89th birthday, the Queen, 88, was seen riding her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park with a groom, opting for a silk scarf instead of a helmet, which she has never worn and resists because of her hair, as noted by trainer Ian Balding. A lifelong horsewoman since receiving Shetland pony Peggy at age four, she has ridden notable mounts such as Betsy and Surprise (galloping at Ascot in 1961), and once presided over Trooping the Colour on horseback, though a knee injury has reduced her riding. She remains actively involved at her Windsor stables; some horses are ridden by grandchildren Lady Louise and James, Viscount Severn. She breeds Thoroughbreds, Fell ponies at Hampton Court, and Highland ponies at Balmoral. Fell ponies—docile, hardy, 13–14hh, usually black/grey/bay—have roamed Cumbria’s moors since the Neolithic, were prized by Carvetii and Romans (who increased their size), served as pack and industrial ponies, and, since the 1950s, are popular riding ponies.

In north Brisbane, a noise dispute between neighbors ended in tragedy when 55-year-old Leon Yeaman died after a single punch allegedly thrown by 28-year-old shift worker and father of three Phillip Pama during a confrontation outside their Muller Road homes around 9 pm Thursday; paramedics could not revive Yeaman and he was pronounced dead about 11 pm. Pama, who works a 3 am warehouse shift and was sleeping at the time, confronted Yeaman, whom his lawyer said was known for drunkenness, loud music, and yelling, and claims Pama was being pushed and struck out blindly. Neighbors described Yeaman as generous, and a friend said he was a schizophrenic pensioner who enjoyed loud music. Charged with manslaughter, Pama—who has no history of violence and was reportedly grief-stricken—was granted conditional bail Friday, required to surrender his passport, observe a 6 pm to 2 am curfew, and report to police twice weekly; the case returns to court on May 18.

In Shatura, near Moscow, 52-year-old music teacher Yulia Simonova was caught on hidden camera hiring what she believed was a hitman—actually an undercover police officer—to torture and murder her 15-year-old former pupil, Damian Vanya, after he ended their year-long relationship for a classmate. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400), instructed the supposed killer to break the boy’s arms and legs, damage his kidneys so he would bleed out, and said she wanted to “finish him” herself. After handing over expense money, she was arrested by armed police in her car, remanded in custody, and charged with attempted murder, facing up to 15 years in prison. Vanya said he was relieved and hoped authorities would “throw away the key.”

Jose Mourinho, the 52-year-old Chelsea manager and father of two, told the Daily Telegraph he speaks to God and prays every day but never about football and does not discuss the game with his wife; he prays only for personal matters, goes to church when he feels the need—always when in Portugal—and tries to keep professional and family life separate. He said his family “know about poverty” and have worked with the Food Programme as an ambassador against hunger. Despite an intensely arrogant sideline persona, he insists he is a good, supportive family man and friend who admits mistakes in a highly competitive, emotional profession, emphasizing that work is only part of a person. Chelsea are top of the league and play QPR this weekend, and earlier this season he was fined £25,000 for alleging a “campaign” against Chelsea after Cesc Fabregas was booked for diving.

On the April 1 edition of The Price Is Right, 91-year-old former host Bob Barker returned for the first time in eight years, briefly taking over from current host Drew Carey to run the classic “Lucky Seven” game before handing hosting duties back; Barker, who led the show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, appeared spry and didn’t miss a beat.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested by Washington, D.C.’s Metropolitan Police around 12:30 a.m. Friday on the 3200 block of D Street SE after allegedly trying to break into a house, and he faces felony attempted burglary and destruction of property charges. The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave; Baldwin is assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch, attached to the State Department and dealing with U.S. diplomatic activities. Court records indicate he was to be arraigned Friday afternoon, with no attorney listed and no phone contact found. The arrest comes amid other troubles for the agency, including a supervisor placed on leave in a case under police and DHS inspector general investigation, and a separate IG probe into a March 4 incident in which two senior officials allegedly drove into a secure White House area after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life in the city’s safari park by leaving his car and lying on the ground to photograph a hungry male lion from about 10 feet away. Armed only with a camera, he fired a few frames before the shutter clicks alerted the lion, which then aggressively jumped toward him, forcing him to scramble back into his car. Saeed said the lion treated him like prey and that his aim was to show the animal’s character and status. He laughed at the time but later admitted he wouldn’t attempt such a close encounter again.

New York City police released images of a distinctive right-leg tattoo—a heart with a ribbon topped by a rose, believed to read “Monique”—to help identify an unnamed woman, estimated to be 25–45, who was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend, Brooklyn, and pronounced dead that evening after paramedics could not revive her; with no identification and the cause of death pending the medical examiner’s report, authorities ask anyone with information to call NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

After returning from the UK in 2009 and unable to afford property, New Zealanders Hannah and Alex bought a 1986 Hino flatbed and spent about a year and a half building a wood-and-steel, two-bedroom house on it. Powered mostly by solar (their first power bill was $25), with gas for the stove and hot water and spring water for supply, the roughly $25,000 project features cypress-lined interiors, a wood-fired stove, and stained glass. They drove it to a lot they purchased in Nelson, where they live with their cat amid trees and a brook; a loft doubles as a spare room, and the setup lets them live nearly self-sufficiently. They love the home and plan to build another.

Researchers report that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class over an academic year significantly outperformed peers with no iPads or one-to-one devices on early literacy tests, scoring about 30 points higher; the study, led by Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University with 352 students in a Midwestern suburban district, suggests the advantage comes from collaborative learning around the technology and recommends schools reconsider tablet use in early grades. The findings, to be presented at the 65th International Communication Association conference in Puerto Rico, follow skepticism from the National Association of Head Teachers’ general secretary about using technology in non-IT classes.

A piglet born without hind legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan, has become an internet sensation after a People’s Daily Online video showed it learning to walk and forage by balancing on its two front trotters. Despite wobbling and nearly tipping over at times, the piglet—nicknamed “Super Pig”—regains its balance, mixes with its four-legged littermates, and has drawn crowds of villagers to farmer Ms. Duan’s home. The story echoes another Chinese animal celebrity: a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo in Guangxi that learned to walk on its front paws and attracts many tourists.

During Sunday’s inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana in Avondale, pit crew member Todd Phillips, the front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when Francesco Dracone, pitting on lap 25 for tires and fuel, spun while exiting his pit box and clipped Phillips’ leg; Phillips received stitches for a leg cut at the infield care center and was released. Rain before the green flag left many cars struggling with traction, and Dracone did not finish, placing 23rd.

CCTV in Rio de Janeiro captured 32-year-old Milton Vieira Severiano murdering his wife, 29-year-old dancer Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno) just four days after their wedding: he dragged her into their garden, slammed her head into concrete 11 times, punched her 10 times, then retrieved a handgun and shot her in the face five times. A neighbor heard a violent argument with Severiano hurling insults and threats before the gunshots. Severiano fled in a stolen car, crashed, and was arrested; police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in the vehicle. He confessed, saying he was jealous of men looking at her, and now faces life in jail; de Sena performed with the dance group Jaula das Gostozuedas.

Sarah Wilson, the 41-year-old journalist and best-selling I Quit Sugar author, reveals that severe anxiety—compounded by stress, thyroid disease, and distant family—left her isolated, without a partner or children, and close to suicide, though she has recently found some peace and accepts she is an anxious person. She believes depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and says acknowledging this link is crucial to tackling rising anxiety among Australian women, calling anxiety the “new depression.” Citing Beyond Blue, she notes one in three Australian women will experience anxiety, and the piece lists support lines: Beyond Blue 1300 224 636 and Lifeline 13 11 14.

Prosecutors dropped second-degree assault charges against Elena Curtin, 23, of Portland, who, while seven months pregnant in November 2014, struck her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend with a crowbar after finding her shooting heroin in Curtin’s bathroom and refusing to leave; they deemed Curtin “completely justified in her outrage” under Oregon law permitting force against an intruder who won’t leave. Curtin, who gave birth in January, had faced nearly six years in mandatory prison if convicted. Her attorney said the ex had harassed and threatened Curtin, stolen from her, and tried to pull the boyfriend—who has a history of heroin use—back into addiction. The ex and the boyfriend, who share a five-year-old, have since reconciled; Curtin now lives with her parents, and the boyfriend is not involved with his new child.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed being fed treats when her owner slipped in a broccoli spear; she made a disgusted face as she chomped it and then spat it out, showing she dislikes the vegetable. The piece notes she’s not setting a great example for the two children she lives with, and adds that other videos show her sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official site to the Young Entrepreneur Awards page redirected users to a pornographic site. The awards were scrapped in 2011, and when the organizers let the hsbc.com.hk registration lapse, the URL was taken over by a porn business, causing the misdirection. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its community projects webpage, denied any association with the external site, issued an April 20 statement apologizing for the inconvenience, and insisted its website remained secure.

Early Sunday morning in Clinton, Maryland, 13-year-old Marcus called 911 after a fire broke out on the first floor, reporting that he and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom because the hallway was too hot. Remaining calm during an 11-minute call, he soothed his sister, told her to stay low and breathe, and gave precise directions to responders (“go up the steps right in the back hallways… it’s a black door to the right”). Prince George’s County firefighters entered the home, broke a window, and Lt. Kenny Ward handed Marcus out to another rescuer before giving his gas mask to Aaliyah, an effort praised as heroic by Assistant Fire Chief Alan Doubleday. The siblings were taken to Children’s Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while their older brother, mother, and stepfather escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Amazing photos show blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia’s east coast, captured at Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales by photographer Andy Hutchinson, who called it a “beautiful supernatural scene” created by millions of glowing plankton. According to Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales, the glow comes from Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in spring and autumn and is natural in 90% of cases; this carnivorous cell preys on diatoms and emits light as a defense mechanism. A similar display occurred at Sydney’s Manly Beach in August 2014, when there was no need for concern about the algae.

New genetic-marker tests for breast cancer, notably EndoPredict, analyze tumor cells after surgery to gauge aggressiveness and predict recurrence within days, allowing some women—especially those with low scores indicating around a 5% ten-year recurrence risk—to opt out of routinely given chemotherapy, whose added benefit may be minimal and whose side effects include hair loss, nausea, weight changes, and extreme fatigue. While these tests are currently mostly available privately at about £2,500, specialists hope for NHS adoption; surgeon Hemant Singhal argues costs would be offset by reduced chemotherapy, and consultant Kefah Mokbel says the tests enable informed choice instead of giving chemo to almost everyone. In one case, 49-year-old mother Becca Cornford received a low EndoPredict score after surgery by Prof. Mokbel, was told chemotherapy would not markedly improve her odds, and emphasized regular monitoring since no treatment reduces risk to zero.

More than 25 women were airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five medevacs from HMS Ocean over nine years, at least one from HMS Illustrious, and cases across 18 other ships such as HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, according to FOI data reported by The Sun. The Ministry of Defence enforces a “no touching” rule at sea, suggesting the pregnancies began before boarding or during leave; the figures surfaced months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown home amid claims of a relationship with a crew member, replaced, and investigated, with the MoD declining details as she left HMS Portland for personal reasons. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, made up about 9% of personnel in 2014, and three women became the first female submariners. Separately, 99 servicewomen were repatriated from Afghanistan between 2006 and 2013 and 102 from Iraq due to pregnancy (including 16 in 2013 and 18 in 2011 from Afghanistan); mothers-to-be are barred from war zones, returns often use flights for injured troops with possible undercounting via routine flights, troops are advised but not required to take pregnancy tests before deployment, most pregnancies were conceived before departure though a few may have occurred on tour, and the MoD says pregnant personnel are returned at the first convenient opportunity.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s residence in Tokyo, prompting a police investigation with dozens of officers and raising fears of drone-enabled terrorism. The quadcopter, about 50 cm wide, had a camera, smoke flares, and a bottle containing small, not immediately harmful amounts of cesium believed to have been placed there; Abe was in Indonesia at the time. The discovery came the same day a court approved restarting two reactors at the Sendai nuclear plant, a move unpopular after the Fukushima disaster. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga warned of potential threats at events like the Olympics and G7 and called for reviewing drone rules. While flights are restricted near airports, most of Tokyo—including government buildings and the prime minister’s residence—has no drone flight restrictions.

Chinese security guard Lu Xincai from Zhejiang province takes his 84-year-old mother, who has Alzheimer’s, to work every day on the back of his motorbike because she might get lost if left alone, especially after previously wandering while collecting firewood and following his father’s death earlier this year, which left no one else to care for her (his wife works in another city and his son is in school). He helps her up at 5 am, secures them with a sash around their waists, and rides the 4 km slowly, taking about an hour so they can chat. His bank employer has given her a room, and he checks on her during work. Saying he is repaying her lifelong care—“I was an apple in my mum’s eye, and now she’s my apple”—his devotion has touched people nationwide, according to People’s Daily Online.

A major study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation found that heavy drinking in the U.S. rose 17.2% from 2005 to 2012, driven largely by increases among women as social norms shift; the CDC defines heavy drinking as over one drink per day for women and two for men, and binge drinking as four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on one occasion in the past month. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers, with women’s binge drinking rising more than seven times the rate of men nationwide; in Santa Clara County, women’s binge drinking rose nearly 36% vs 23% for men (2002–2012). County extremes included Madison County, Idaho (lowest binge drinking, 6%), Menominee, Wisconsin (highest, 36%), Hancock County, Tennessee (fewest heavy drinkers, 2%), and Esmeralda County, Nevada (most, 22%). Despite rising heavy drinking, the share of people who drink at all remained stable. Researchers and clinicians cited cultural and economic factors: greater acceptability of women drinking, higher binge rates among youth, more affluent populations in certain cities, alcohol taxes lagging inflation, increased alcohol advertising ($3.45 billion in 2011), and weakened alcohol control policies. Alcohol was linked to about 88,600 U.S. deaths in 2010 and over $220 billion in annual costs. The study, the first to track adult drinking at the county level, analyzed BRFSS data from about 3.7 million adults aged 21 and older.

UN officials from the World Health Organization warn that caesarean sections are being performed too readily and should be done only when medically necessary due to risks including infections, complications, disability, and even death, as well as higher costs. In England, just over a quarter of births are by caesarean—more than double the rate in the early 1990s—with some women opting for planned procedures due to anxiety about natural childbirth (tokophobia). The WHO says an ideal rate is 10–15% and notes that overuse diverts funds, with a planned caesarean costing the NHS £2,369 versus £1,665 for a natural birth. This position contradicts NHS/NICE guidance since 2011 that allows elective caesareans without medical justification and advises them in cases such as previous complicated birth, age over 40, or conditions like asthma, diabetes, or depression. WHO adds that doctors underestimate risks, and prior research suggests up to one in ten caesareans result in infections.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested April 17 after allegedly breaking into a Martha’s Vineyard summer home in Edgartown, living there for at least a week, and selling or giving away the owners’ belongings; owner Mark Conklin found her inside, she claimed she owned the house and fled, police noted a broken window, and later arrested her when she tried to return. She is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, and a construction worker reported she appeared to be holding a yard sale. Missing items include four Crate & Barrel deck chairs, a Weber grill, two Ethan Allen side tables, one Ann Chase lamp, two Crate & Barrel lamps, two framed posters, various pots, pans and linens, and a painting by the owner. Police are asking anyone who received items to return them to the Edgartown Police Department, noting purchasers are also victims and will be assisted with restitution, and Filkins is due in court May 14.

After losing her unlocked iPhone at a friend’s party on Saturday night, Melbourne woman Bella Crooke had it handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW–Victoria border Sunday morning, where officers used the device to post humorous selfies, puns, and updates on her Facebook page (e.g., the phone in a holding “cell,” promises it would be fully “charged,” and jokes about “early release” and “posting bail”) to track her down; they also replied to texts from her friends. When Bella arrived around 1 pm—after a security guard had told her the phone would be left at the station—she was immediately recognized from the posts, laughed at the officers’ joke-filled updates, reclaimed her phone without giving her name, and later set a password and thanked the “boys in blue,” while friends shared the posts and praised the police as “legends.”

In iSimangaliso Wetland Park, eastern South Africa, a five-day-old hippo calf was fatally injured after getting caught in a prolonged fight between two male hippos: it was seized in the jaws during the melee, dragged along the water’s surface, and flung into the air while its mother looked on and tried to intervene. The mother had stayed with her herd and spent hours chasing away sub-adults, then attacked the aggressor’s neck in an attempt to reclaim the calf, prompting a harder bite and the fatal flick; the calf died of its injuries hours later. Tour operator Stacey Farrell, 30, of Shoreline Hippo and Safari witnessed the incident and said the motive—whether intentional killing, rough play, or jealousy—was unknown.

A three-bedroom unmodernised maisonette in Egerton Place, Knightsbridge, is on sale for £575,000 because it has only three years left on its lease, effectively costing about £191,000 a year (£15,000 a month), similar to renting; the 1,990 sq ft flat has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception and utility room, lift, parking and a communal garden, and needs renovation. A second, larger 2,500 sq ft maisonette nearby with the same three-year lease is priced at £595,000. Agents say such short-lease opportunities are rare and interest is high, but warn of a large premium to extend: a 90-year lease, to be negotiated with the current freeholder, thought to be the welcome trust, is estimated to cost £3.35–£4.5 million. Modernised values are estimated at £2,750–£3,000 per sq ft, implying about £6 million for the smaller and £7.5 million for the larger; by comparison, the next cheapest three-bedroom property in Knightsbridge is £1.5 million with a 28-year lease.

Starbucks experienced a point-of-sale register outage Friday evening that disrupted sales at about 8,000 company-operated stores in the U.S. (7,000) and Canada (1,000), also affecting Evolution Fresh and Teavana; the glitch, attributed to a failure during a daily system refresh, prevented ringing up sales and credit-card transactions, prompting many locations to give away free drinks and baked goods or close early, while some accepted cash, and social media filled with customers sharing their freebies even as some stores in states like Florida, Tennessee, and Arizona shut to avoid giveaways; the company said the issue was resolved late Friday and stores would open “business as usual” Saturday, and the incident followed record quarterly net revenues of $4.6 billion, with shares up 4.4% to $51.50.

Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit told Ceredigion Council that rural West Wales—Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire—is being used to radicalise and train extremists who appear to take part in ordinary community activities but have ulterior motives, emphasizing that terrorism is not confined to big cities; examples cited include claims that in 1998 Abu Hamza sent 10 extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons (also used by the British military), the 2005 photographs of 7/7 bombers Mohammad Sidique Khan and Shehzad Tanweer white-water rafting in Bala, the 2010 arrests of Cardiff men Omar Latif, Gurukanth Desai, and Abdul Miah after secret meetings with Mohammed Chowdhury and Shah Rahman, and a local link to Michael Adebowale—convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby—who is understood to have studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences at Highmead near Llanybydder, which is understood to have been set up by Iraqi clerics; Jones stressed the vital role of community intelligence in addressing these threats.

An Omura’s whale, a species feared to be extinct, was found washed up on a remote Exmouth beach at Western Australia’s North West Cape after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn, marking the first sighting in WA and only the second in Australia. The 5.68 m juvenile female was difficult to identify and was confirmed as an Omura’s whale through DNA profiling. Authorities called the find highly significant because little is known about the species, first described in 2003 and apparently restricted to tropical and subtropical waters; it is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. Omura’s whales have a sleek body and distinctive skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, with plans to recover the skeleton in a few years for research and possible museum display to improve identification guides and understanding of its regional distribution.

A Texas marketing CEO, Cheryl Rios, claimed Hillary Clinton shouldn’t be president because women’s hormones could make them irrational, but the article counters that male leaders’ hormones have impaired decision-making, studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks, and male scandals (e.g., Schwarzenegger, Sanford, Edwards) highlight this. It critiques Time’s framing of Clinton as “perfect” due to being postmenopausal and argues the real issue is entrenched gender bias that limits women despite their strong presence in college, graduate school, and the workforce. Citing Adam Grant and Sheryl Sandberg’s work, it notes evidence of overt and covert bias—such as more male board members named John/Robert/William/James than all women combined, and students calling men “geniuses” and women “nice.” The piece asserts equality benefits everyone: companies perform better, involved fathers help children, shared responsibilities strengthen marriages, and diverse teams excel. It urges telling girls to pursue goals despite bias and mocks Rios’s vow to move to Canada by noting Canada had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993, with a correction about an earlier misstatement of her election.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is auctioning his extensive antiques in a £100,000 sale as he downsizes, with more than 200 items across 238 lots to be sold by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, on Saturday. Highlights include a hand-painted limewood 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt by L.M. Rendall (estimated £4,000–£6,000), a yew longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle and a portrait of Hardy holding it (up to £2,000), early Victorian Gillows cabinets (up to £4,000), plus paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and dozens of books dating to the 17th century, including an early 20th-century Frank Owen Salisbury painting of Alfred the Great rebuilding London. A Cotswolds-based military historian and longbow expert, Hardy studied under J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis at Oxford, has written two books on the longbow, and advised on the raising of the Mary Rose. Known for All Creatures Great and Small, frequent portrayals of Winston Churchill, and as Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films, he expressed sadness at parting with his treasured library but hopes new owners enjoy the items; after a fall forced his retirement from stage work during The Audience, he says he will continue television work.

Florida man Michael Scott Shemansky has been on the run since Saturday after being named a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, whose body was found at their shared West Colonial Drive home in Winter Garden following a well-being check; police say foul play is suspected, they have the (unidentified) murder weapon, and have not confirmed how she was killed. He came to police attention after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son that day (confirmed by his estranged wife’s attorney). Shemansky is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was previously involuntarily committed after an attempted suicide; his mother was helping him through a divorce, and his wife filed a domestic violence injunction two years ago. Neighbors at the Winter Garden RV Resort said his mother may have prevented the visit and believe divorce stress and bad paperwork received Friday may have pushed him over the edge. He was allegedly seen at the trailer park office asking for water shortly after the killing and was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication; his estranged wife is reportedly taking protective measures in case he arrives at her home. Anyone with information is urged to call 407-656-3636.

The IAAF Council awarded Eugene, USA, the 2021 IAAF World Championships, bypassing the usual bidding process to seize what it called a unique strategic opportunity to stage the event in the U.S. for the first time. Though Eugene lost the 2019 bid to Doha, a recent presentation convinced the IAAF it could successfully host, supported by public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and strong public enthusiasm. IAAF president Lamine Diack said the move serves the sport’s global development by accessing a key market, and noted a precedent: the 2007 Osaka championships were also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, 25, an aspiring model and care assistant from Gillingham, Kent, was jailed for 16 years after a jury (10–2) found her guilty of manslaughter for luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, from a Mayfair casino and leaving the door of his Islington flat unlocked so her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson, 28, and Nicholas Chandler, 29, could enter, bind him with parcel tape, kick him to death, and ransack his home for hidden winnings. The trio stole £3,000, a TV and a phone; police linked them through Granger’s phone records and a video on her mobile of the men throwing £50 notes. Judge William Kennedy called the attack “pitiless and wicked,” rejecting mitigation that Granger acted out of love, saying she was deceitful from the outset; she wept as she was convicted. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder, robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison and received life terms with minimum 36 years; they were also found guilty of plotting to rob Grosvenor Casinos employees and conspiracies involving firearms and false imprisonment linked to earlier raids. The court heard Hassan, a divorced father of three who sometimes won up to £15,000 at Mayfair casinos and kept cash at home, was targeted as a “soft target,” and his family said his death will haunt them forever.

The passage argues that Cesc Fabregas is experiencing a familiar late-season slump: after a brilliant start at Chelsea, he captained Spain in a 2-0 loss to the Netherlands on his first international appearance since October, struggled to make an impact, and was rated 4/10. Having reached 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, he has produced just one in his last five league games and four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015, jeopardizing his bid to surpass Thierry Henry’s single-season assist record of 20. Barcelona had warned of this recurring decline when he left, and a long, intense campaign appears to be taking its toll, with Jose Mourinho concerned by his recent toils. Still, with Chelsea already Capital One Cup winners and potentially needing up to six wins from their final nine league games, several upcoming opponents he has previously unlocked offer hope, and Mourinho will look to his recent assist for Diego Costa at Hull as a sign of a timely resurgence to help clinch the title.

West Ham are discussing a deal and closing in on the signature of 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United after he impressed coaches during a two-week trial with their academy earlier this month; Beckford, linked with multiple European clubs and regarded as one of the Caribbean’s top prospects, also has offers from clubs in Belgium. Separately, West Ham announced Olympic Stadium season tickets will start at £289, set to be the cheapest in the Barclays Premier League, to help fill the 54,000-capacity venue when they move for the 2016–17 season.

Wiltshire Police have shelved, pending further information, their investigation into a January 24 assault on huntsman Mike Lane, 40, near Everleigh, despite video footage and a dossier naming suspected hunt saboteurs and their car registrations. Lane, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was attacked by balaclava-clad protesters—some wielding iron bars on ropes—while the hunt followed an artificial scent; he was punched, kicked in the head, hospitalized with concussion and broken teeth, suffers memory loss, and has spent £500 on dental treatment. Although the suspect’s face was captured on video and a photo released, no one has been identified, charged, or prosecuted, prompting condemnation from Lane and supporters, including witnesses and hunt officials, who criticize police inaction and the use of face coverings; the Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban masks to help bring offenders to justice.

Adam Gadahn, 36, an American-born al Qaeda propagandist known as “Azzam the American,” was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January, the White House said; neither he nor fellow U.S. al Qaeda operative Ahmed Farouq—killed in what was likely a separate operation—was specifically targeted. The strike that killed Farouq also killed U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein, abducted in Pakistan in 2011, and Italian hostage Giovanni Lo Porto. Born in 1978, Gadahn grew up in rural California, converted to Islam in 1995, left the U.S. for Pakistan in 1998, and rose to become al Qaeda’s chief English-language propagandist, appearing in mid-2000s videos threatening Western targets, urging lone-wolf attacks, and calling for toppling Pakistan’s regime. Indicted in 2006 for treason and material support and placed among the FBI’s Most Wanted Terrorists, he criticized U.S. presidents, tore up his passport on camera, praised the Fort Hood and Benghazi attacks, and in a 2014 video urged overthrowing the Saudi and Pakistani governments. A 2011 letter by him on media strategy was found among Osama bin Laden’s documents; he reportedly married an Afghan woman and had at least one child.

China’s enthusiasm for child prodigies has a new focus: five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, whose viral video shows him sinking successive hoops and dribbling two basketballs in rhythm—a skill he has practiced since age two-and-a-half—winning fans across basketball-mad China, where Yao Ming has been the top star. The clip has sparked thousands of online reactions, ranging from disbelief (“I can’t believe it... It must be special effects!”) and curiosity (“Who is his father?”) to self-deprecating awe (“I want to reincarnate and start over again! What have I been doing for the past 32 years?”).

Tom O’Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) and former Open University information officer, has joined supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off and attended its February 25 rally at the Houses of Parliament—chaired by John Cleese—to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, set up after the phone-hacking scandal, opposes what it sees as the biased and unfair Independent Press Standards Organisation and wants MPs to create a statutory press regulator as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. PIE, founded in 1974 to campaign for legalising sex with children, allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), which lobbied to cut the age of consent to ten if a child “understood the nature of the act” and consented and to legalise incest; O’Carroll served on the NCCL’s gay rights sub-committee and was jailed in 1981 for corrupting public morals. He confirmed his attendance in a blog, and a Hacked Off spokesman said the meeting was open and free to the public; news of his backing will be an embarrassment to the group.

Bondi’s Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to host Ten Pieces’ Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia presentation, temporarily displacing lap swimmers to the beach. Ten Pieces, headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and partner Lucy Hinckfuss, staged an androgynous, monochrome, unisex capsule of ten pieces designed to be worn in 20 ways and suitable from day to night. Models walked through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall against an ocean backdrop, while guests watched from the club and roadside, enjoying Icebergs nibbles and Santa Vittoria drinks under sunny, unseasonably warm 28°C skies. Beachgoers paused to watch, and the collection included scarves and hoodies.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan, 28, spent Friday at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa, posing with giraffes and sea lions and feeding a rare white tiger; earlier in the week he confirmed his next bout will be a welterweight fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, despite pressure to face IBF welterweight champion Kell Brook in June and links to Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman, saying he was already deep in negotiations with another opponent.

Palestinian teenager Mohammed Abu Khdeir, 16, who prosecutors say was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, was briefly listed on Israel’s Mount Herzl memorial to fallen soldiers and terror victims as Memorial Day approached. His family objected, with his father refusing to have his son’s name displayed alongside “soldiers of the occupation” and noting no permission was sought. Almagor, a group representing terror victims, also opposed the inclusion, calling the killing a rogue act rather than terrorism and urging the National Insurance Institute (which maintains the site) to remove his name, threatening to seek removal of their relatives’ names if not. Israel Radio reported the Institute will remove Abu Khdeir’s name, which has already been taken off the website listing, and a panel of judges began hearing evidence in January against the three suspects in his killing.

A California-based YouTube user, “lionel hutz,” filmed his young son repeatedly trying to use the family cat as a pillow in the garden: the boy plonks his head on the cat’s belly as it licks its fur, the cat promptly gets up and moves, and the child follows to try again. After a few repeats, the cat retreats indoors. A later video shows the pair reconciled, with the boy gently feeding the cat treats.

In an ongoing Philadelphia police corruption trial, witness Robert Kushner, 32, lost his varsity basketball coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying that he previously sold marijuana and alleging undercover officers stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. The school, which hired him in 2010 after a background check, learned of his past through his testimony; he said the 2007 charges were expunged via probation. Under cross-examination, he acknowledged a 2011 arrest resulting in four years’ probation and a 2008 DUI guilty plea. Kushner, a seasonal employee who also coaches in a Narberth summer league, said he did not intend to deceive the school and expressed remorse. The six former drug squad officers—Thomas Liciardello, Brian Reynolds, Michael Spicer, Perry Betts, Linwood Norman, and John Speiser—face a 26-count indictment including racketeering conspiracy, extortion, robbery, kidnapping, and drug dealing, while their lawyers argue the case relies on 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at an oil storage facility at a controversial paraxylene (PX) plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian, on Monday night sparked a huge fire, injuring six people—five hurt by broken glass and hospitalized—with more than 600 firefighters deployed and the blaze brought under control; local media reported no toxic chemical spill. The plant produces PX, a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in polyester films and fabrics. Residents nearby heard the blast, felt slight tremors, and shared photos on Weibo. The facility previously suffered an explosion in July 2013 without casualties or toxic leaks. PX projects have prompted sometimes-violent protests in China despite demonstrations being illegal, and this plant was moved from densely populated Xiamen to its current, more remote site after a 2007 backlash over pollution concerns.

Aston Villa teenager and Republic of Ireland U21 international Jack Grealish says he will ignore Premier League referees’ requests to pull his socks up, keeping them low as part of a lifelong superstition; he does wear shinpads, but children’s size, and notes he hasn’t been kicked on the shins yet. He made his first Premier League start in Tuesday’s 3-3 draw with QPR, calling it a tough relegation scrap, and while unhappy with the result he was pleased to start, appreciative that the manager told him he deserved it, and hopes for more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, 22, is no longer in a medically induced coma but remains unresponsive with “global and irreversible brain damage,” according to her grandmother Cissy Houston; a source says her neurological state has been unchanged for nearly three months, she doesn’t respond to voices, her eyes don’t track, and she has a tracheostomy. These reports came two days after her father, Bobby Brown, told a concert crowd she was awake, and the family’s attorney later said her condition has improved with doctors indicating she may have a long life, though the quality is unknown for years as she begins a lengthy rehabilitation. Bobby Brown’s wife added that she is out of ICU, has opened her eyes, and started rehab.
