Russia took a 2-0 lead over Germany in their Fed Cup tie on Saturday, with Svetlana Kuznetsova beating Julia Goerges in straight sets and Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saving a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with Lisicki’s power and had 13 double faults, but Lisicki’s 63 unforced errors proved decisive; Lisicki noted she had a match point and played a poor tiebreak. Russia now needs one win from Sunday’s three matches to reach the final and pursue their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents across New South Wales are being warned to prepare for another potential east coast low later this week, with heavy rain likely from Thursday to Saturday, particularly along the state’s northeast coast (Northern Rivers and Mid North Coast) and into southeast Queensland; unlike last week’s system, this one appears farther offshore, is unlikely to focus heavy rain over Sydney, and should move through more quickly. The SES, deluged with 24,196 requests last week and still facing 4,409 outstanding jobs, fears renewed flooding on saturated catchments and more tree falls—especially in the hard‑hit Hunter region—and is urging communities to prepare as more than 1,000 personnel, including 200 from other states, work to finish as much cleanup as possible. The Bureau of Meteorology says it is still too early to determine the storm’s exact severity.

Nina Moric, 38, a model who appeared in the video for Ricky Martin’s hit “la vida loco,” denied Italian media reports that she attempted suicide, saying on Instagram (to 40,000+ followers) that she collapsed due to low blood pressure, fell and hit her head in a domestic accident, was treated in hospital Saturday night, and is now recovering; she posted photos showing heavy bruising and said her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, was in Naples at the time. Media had reported she was found by her mother in the luxury Milan apartment she shares with Favoloso and quoted him as saying she had tried to commit suicide, while Moric said she was shocked by the claims and had no intention to end her life. Reports also noted a claimed 2009 suicide attempt after an overdose. The Croatian-born model was previously married to paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, 41, jailed for blackmailing celebrities; they have a son, Carlos Maria (born 2002), and police tapes captured Corona telling Moric he “ruin[s] lives.”

A YouGov poll for the Sunday Times found Britons hoping for a traditional name for Prince William and Kate’s second child, with Diana the top choice for a girl (12%), followed by Alice and Charlotte (9% each)—Alice honoring the Queen’s late aunt and Charlotte nodding to Charles—while James leads for a boy (13%) ahead of Alexander. Of 2,200 people surveyed, 25% wanted a girl and only 3% preferred a younger brother for George. Social media users also backed Diana as a potential name. Additionally, 68% supported William’s plan to take six weeks’ paternity leave from his pilot job.

Police in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, said a suicide bomber detonated near a group of protesters on Thursday, killing 17 and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker; the blast occurred around 10 a.m. local time as the protesters—among them MP Humayoon Humayoon—were heading to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed the attack.

Brazilian right-back Dani Alves, 31, will leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club’s final offer of a three-year extension that required him to play in 60% of matches, his agent and ex-wife Dinorah Santana said, declaring negotiations over. Alves has spent seven successful years at the club, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies, but failure to agree a new deal means he will depart the Nou Camp.

29-year-old Pablo Osvaldo, on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton and already an instant hit with three goals in six games, has urged his former teammates Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian giants, saying their South American-style qualities would make them perfect for Boca and adored at La Bombonera; he named them as the two players he’d pick to bring, highlighting Pirlo’s status as a top midfielder and Totti’s Roma-legend appeal, and predicted the stadium would go crazy for them.

At Paul Nicholls’s yard on Thursday morning, 18-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson received no special treatment, mucking out stables as usual with only a cut on his nose after his spectacular double somersault fall from favourite Merrion Square in the 4.20pm at Wincanton, a spill watched hundreds of thousands of times online; back riding and undeterred, he said the incident was a blur he only understood after watching the replay as fellow jockeys looked away in horror, noted there was nothing he could do and that he was very lucky, took some dressing-room abuse and a few hundred new Twitter followers as good banter, and joked he might consider a gymnastics career after racing.

As Avengers: Age of Ultron premiered at Westfield London with fans queuing to see stars Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth and Scarlett Johansson, England flanker and Wasps captain James Haskell joined the hype by posting a Thursday Instagram photo dressed as Iron Man, captioned “Avengers movie is out so thought I would release the inner Iron Man. @underarmouruk #transformyourself #iwill #avengersageofultron.” Windsor-born Haskell began at Wasps in 2002, earned his first England cap in 2007, left in 2009 for two seasons at Stade Francais, then moved to Tokyo’s Ricoh Black Rams after the 2011 World Cup, spent four months there before joining New Zealand’s Highlanders for 12 appearances, and returned to England in 2012 to rejoin Wasps; since then he has surpassed 100 club appearances and amassed 57 England caps, having played in France, Japan and New Zealand.

The passage spotlights the wide‑leg trouser as a leading SS15 trend—across denim, cropped, printed, and striped styles—offering an effortless, 1970s‑inspired alternative to long‑dominant skinny jeans. Louise Redknapp (with Emma) advises that proportion and footwear are key, especially for shorter wearers: choose high heels that expose the top of the foot, opt for high‑waisted, very long lengths, and keep the top half simple (knits, shirts, or tees) to avoid being swamped by fabric. Denim is the easiest entry, with Gucci’s SS15 vintage‑wash flared jeans and Topshop’s Miller 1970s‑style flare as a high‑street option; Celine and Stella McCartney offer dressier evening versions, and Finery London provides similar styles at lower prices. The look appeared widely on SS15 runways (including Gucci and Celine), works even without great spring weather, has celebrity backing (e.g., Poppy Delevingne at the AW15 Chloe show), and Louise previously embraced it with Stella McCartney flares she kept; more inspiration is available at astylealbum.com.

The University of Michigan will proceed with screening “American Sniper” at a UMix student event after initially canceling it in response to a petition by over 200 students who argued the film’s Iraq War depiction reflects negatively on the Middle East, a sensitive issue in the Detroit area with its large Arab-American population; after backlash and a counter-petition, Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper said canceling was a mistake inconsistent with the university’s commitment to freedom of expression, so the showing will go on, with “Paddington” offered as an alternative, a decision praised by head football coach Jim Harbaugh; the film stars Bradley Cooper as Navy SEAL Chris Kyle, who was killed in 2013.

Two French male tourists, aged 18 and 24 and living in Cockburn Central, allegedly ignited an aerosol with a lighter on April 3 on Rottnest Island off Perth, producing a large flame that singed a quokka; the animal survived. Detectives questioned the men on the island, seized video evidence, and evicted them. Both have been charged with animal cruelty and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas, about the size of a domestic cat, are found on small islands off Western Australia, particularly Rottnest and Bald Island near Albany.

With help from filmmakers, 102-year-old Alice Barker—who danced in chorus lines at New York venues like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s alongside Bill “Bojangles” Robinson and Frank Sinatra—finally saw herself dance for the first time. Although motion pictures of her existed, she had never seen them and had lost her photos and memorabilia. Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers compiled “soundies” and showed them to her at her nursing home, and she was delighted, saying, “It’s just fabulous.”

A UK survey by vehicle leasing firm OSV of 1,100 adults shows the tradition of washing your own car is fading: 31% of men have never washed their car and only 12% of those who do, do so regularly, while three-quarters of women never wash theirs; just 5% have ever asked children to do it for pocket money. Drivers increasingly use forecourt, hand, or automated car washes, with reasons including Sunday shopping, more live football, larger 4x4s, and convenient, cheap alternatives. Holiday periods buck the trend—an estimated 15 million cars were owner-cleaned over the recent Easter break—though one in four did it mainly to get out of the house. Weekly owner-washing is most common in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, least in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh; Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most likely to be owner-washed, and Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes least. OSV’s Andrew Kirkley frames this as the decline of a Sunday tradition due to time pressures and easy alternatives.

Martin Skrtel lauded Steven Gerrard’s influence on him since Skrtel’s 2008 arrival at Anfield, calling Gerrard still one of the world’s best and synonymous with Liverpool, and thanking him for daily help settling in. He noted Liverpool will be different without Gerrard but believes the team has players who can fill the void with support and teamwork. Gerrard is set to play the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, with a potential final versus Arsenal on May 30—his birthday—before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel, signed by Rafael Benitez from Zenit seven years ago, has become a defensive mainstay after early inconsistency. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return against Villa after serving three-match bans for violent conduct in the 2-1 loss to Manchester United in March.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus thrilled Augusta National’s Par-3 Contest by making his first-ever hole-in-one there, spinning a tee shot on the 130-yard fourth back into the cup while playing with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, after joking earlier he’d “win the par-3 and make a hole in one.” The day produced five aces, tying the 2002 record; Camilo Villegas made two (at the fourth and eighth) but lost the title in a playoff to world No 74 Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus, the Golden Bear, was the youngest Masters champion in 1963 and won his sixth green jacket in 1986, and he is one of five to complete the career Grand Slam, an achievement favorite Rory McIlroy could match if he wins his third major in a row.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as storms produced reported twisters, including one spotted 6 miles northwest of Goddard that moved northeast, missing Wichita but threatening other communities; additional sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas, with three near Aetna, 125 miles southwest of Wichita. The National Weather Service said a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis, where wind damage, flooding, a fallen tree, roof damage, and a water-covered street were reported; nearby, unusual dark clouds were photographed in Leadington and baseball-size hail hit Farmington. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned storms would pop up all night and that nighttime tornadoes are especially deadly. More storms are expected Thursday across the Midwest, the Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old Oklahoma reserve deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter in the April 2 fatal shooting of Eric Harris, which he says happened when he mistakenly fired his gun instead of a Taser during a weapons sting. A judge allowed him to travel to the Bahamas for a family vacation, prompting criticism from Harris’ family, who said it showed apathy toward the killing. A preliminary hearing is set for 10 a.m. July 2. Bates and Sheriff Stanley Glanz have apologized; meanwhile, Harris’ family’s lawyer alleges Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to donations and a friendship with the sheriff. The Tulsa World reported supervisors were told to forge Bates’ records and were reassigned when they refused, allegations the sheriff’s office denies. Bates’ lawyer released training documents claiming he had proper law enforcement training, and two deputies involved in Harris’ arrest were reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor, the 26-year-old Irish “Notorious,” is preparing to challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight title in Las Vegas on July 11 and has unveiled a new tiger-face tattoo on his stomach, adding to his chest image of a gorilla eating a heart, captioned on Instagram, “If you see the tiger, it’s too late. You’re food.” Aldo is set for the eighth defense of his belt, while McGregor claims he is more motivated, saying Aldo doesn’t want the belt near him. Their rivalry has been heated, highlighted by McGregor grabbing Aldo’s belt during a March promotional stop in Dublin before 5,000 home supporters, with under three months to go until the fight.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after skolling a schooner of beer in about six seconds at a University of Technology Sydney Bats function, where players cheered and he delivered a light-hearted speech. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert said it was problematic for a leader to showcase masculinity through rapid drinking, arguing it glorifies binge drinking and shifts focus from socializing to how much and how fast one drinks; she also faulted media and political reactions. Opposition Leader Bill Shorten joked about Abbott’s beer habits, while Health Minister Sussan Ley defended him, saying there was nothing wrong and praising his fitness. Witnesses said Abbott was “proud as punch” after downing the beer, and although past prime ministers like Bob Hawke displayed similar antics, Robert noted today’s heightened concerns about binge drinking and the risk of reinforcing the stereotype that heavy drinking defines an Australian “bloke.”

Indiana health officials report a significant rise in HIV cases tied to Scott County—now 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary—more than two weeks into a 30-day emergency needle-exchange program approved by Gov. Mike Pence on March 26, with cases expected to increase as testing expands and pressure mounting on Pence, who opposes exchanges, to decide early next week whether to extend it beyond April 25. The outbreak is among IV drug users, largely involving the painkiller Opana, in a county that typically sees about five HIV cases annually; so far, 86 participants have received 5,322 clean syringes and returned about 1,400, aided by a mobile unit building trust. The program’s future and broader policy remain uncertain: Senate leaders call the emergency move the right short-term reaction but question long-term use, while a House-passed bill (54–39 on April 7) to allow exchanges in 23 high–hepatitis C counties—an indicator of HIV risk per CDC—is headed to a House-Senate conference before the April 29 adjournment. Funding is also unclear, as federal dollars are banned and Pence’s order included no money, leaving state agencies to find resources, which critics say is not sustainable.

An Arsenal-obsessed boyfriend made his girlfriend, Saskia, sit a homemade “Arsenal exam” with multiple-choice, tables, and “in your own words” questions, complete with school-style instructions and red-pen marking; she scored 43.5/50 (87%), earned an A, and he joked he wouldn’t dump her as a result. Saskia shared photos on Twitter (@saskiaisabxlla), noting the ordeal, while his feedback said she could have done better on Q17, should learn all player positions, and remember that “Tottenham are scum.” Questions covered the 2014 FA Cup final score and winning scorer, the current manager, fans’ nickname, kit identification, and naming the season’s starting XI; she struggled with positions (misplacing Özil and Welbeck, missing Koscielny). Her creative answer on why Alexis Sánchez is better than Eden Hazard—calling Hazard a “p***k”—earned double marks, and the boyfriend drew angry faces next to wrong answers. Online reaction was mixed: many hailed him as a “legend” and called Saskia “proper gf material,” with some men vowing to test their own partners, while others criticized the stunt as excessive.

Carlos Toro, 66, a former mid-level Medellín cartel member who fled Colombia in the 1980s, spent 27 years as an unpaid DEA informant under a promise of U.S. citizenship, becoming one of the agency’s strongest assets by aiding undercover stings worldwide and contributing to prosecutions of Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. After declining health forced his retirement, the DEA refused to help with his citizenship once he went public, leaving him undocumented and facing deportation. Toro says he would be killed if returned to Colombia, his last temporary visa expired January 1, and he cannot collect Social Security without a green card or passport, prompting him to consider going into hiding. Former DEA handler Mike McManus condemned the situation as bureaucracy “at its worst” and personally gave Toro $5,000 for a medical operation after the agency declined to assist. Toro admits past wrongdoing but says he has atoned and seeks the citizenship he was promised.

In Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, a 14-year-old girl allegedly raped by five men from her village set herself on fire with kerosene after her family reportedly told her to keep quiet; her brother extinguished the flames, and she is being treated at Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns, while the accused men have been arrested. The incident comes amid heightened sensitivity in India after officials banned the documentary India’s Daughter over fears it would cause further disorder following protests and vigilante incidents related to sexual violence. The film examined the 2012 Delhi bus rape and murder of student Jyoti Singh, which sparked nationwide protests and led to death sentences for four men, the prison death of another, and a three-year sentence for a minor. Recent vigilante killings in Nagaland include the public lynchings of Ibo Cha, accused of raping and murdering an 11-year-old girl, and Syed Sarif Khan, later declared innocent, who had been accused of repeatedly raping a 19-year-old student.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal, preparing for his first Manchester derby at Old Trafford, said he dreams of beating Manchester City on Sunday but ruled out Robin van Persie and likely Luke Shaw for lacking match fitness despite van Persie’s claim he was ready. With City coming off defeat at Crystal Palace, he sees a chance to take three points to move toward third place (and as high as second), almost secure a top-four finish, and avoid a Champions League qualifier, while emphasizing United must control their aggression after the 1-0 loss in the reverse fixture and downplaying any notion of revenge. He also praised the strong support from United fans as the squad trained for the game.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a coordinated protest over rising ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their lunchtime Premier League match at the sold-out Emirates Stadium, following the announcement of the league’s £5.14bn TV rights deal. With tickets for the 12:45 kick-off starting at £64—among the highest in the league—supporters displayed banners inside and outside the ground, including “£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket” and “Football without fans is nothing.” The action was organized by Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement with Liverpool groups Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906; organizers called prices “extortionate,” criticized late fixture changes and unreasonable kick-off times, urged unity across rival fans, and warned that without tangible reductions in line with working-class wages a generation of supporters could be lost. Further protests were expected after full-time.

Newborn Star Reader from Barnsley, West Yorkshire, was diagnosed within days of birth with biliary atresia after persistent jaundice; an operation to unblock her bile ducts failed, and with both parents (Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave) unsuitable as donors, her mother’s twin sister, Shanell Reader, donated part of her liver, saving Star’s life. Biliary atresia affects about 1 in 16,000 babies, involves absent or blocked bile ducts, causes jaundice and pale stools, and can be fatal without treatment; the Kasai procedure is a common treatment. Star received the transplant in November, spent six weeks in hospital, and is now home and recovering well, though she requires weekly blood and liver function tests and lifelong anti-rejection medication; her family expressed shock, gratitude, and Shanell said she did not hesitate to help.

Chelsea’s Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake teamed up against Loic Remy and Willian in Audi’s football challenge, winning the first round by firing balls into a car boot (5-3) and then a tennis-style game played over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus to lead 6-0 after two rounds. The final, highest-scoring challenge required long-range shots into a convertible Audi, which Remy and Willian won to claim a shock victory over their teammates. A notable mishap saw Willian smash a wing mirror with a long-range effort, drawing a hands-on-head reaction from Remy, while Willian was also seen laughing after being allowed to drive one of the Audis.

Former Fortune 500 executive Robert Dellinger, 54, told the court during his sentencing that he was not suicidal when, on December 7, 2013, he drove his pickup across a Lebanon, New Hampshire highway median at over 100 mph, went airborne, and sheared the top off an SUV, killing Amanda Murphy, 24, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé, Jason Timmons, 29; the couple had planned to name their baby Reagan Elizabeth. Though prosecutors said Dellinger had told investigators he was trying to kill himself and was “driving around, depressed and loopy” after arguing with his wife over medications, the defense attributed his actions to Ambien withdrawal, effects of a psychiatric drug overdose and Prozac, and advanced multiple sclerosis. Dellinger pleaded guilty in February to negligent homicide in the couple’s deaths and one count of assault for the fetus’ death, and faces 12 to 24 years in prison when sentencing resumes Thursday; he also faces a wrongful death lawsuit filed by Murphy’s estate. He was initially charged with two counts of reckless manslaughter, later upgraded to negligent homicide. In court, his wife described him as ethical and plagued by serious health problems, expressed condolences to the victims’ families, and Dellinger wept at the defense table.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul, with salt via his feeding tube at a suburban New York hospital and was sentenced to 20 years to life, short of the 25-to-life maximum, showing no emotion as the judge cited her mental illness and called the crime unfathomably cruel. Prosecutors said she manufactured and worsened illnesses to gain attention, argued for the maximum, and presented her social media posts alongside evidence of repeated unnecessary hospitalizations and procedures, blaming her—who lived in Chestnut Ridge near New York City—for the child’s short, tormented life and for loading his feeding tube with lethal salt while continuing to blog. Her attorney, Stephen Riebling, sought 15 years to life, portrayed her as a hardworking single mother who loved her son, maintained her innocence, blamed hospital negligence, and said he would appeal; Spears did not testify. While awaiting sentencing she was held at Westchester County Jail in Valhalla. After the sentencing, the child’s father, Chris Hill, vented on Facebook, urging that she be placed in general population, predicting she would not survive there, and criticizing her lack of emotion.

Australia’s flu vaccine supply is arriving a month late because the formulation was updated to include protection against influenza A(H3N2) and influenza B/Phuket after a poor match in the Northern Hemisphere led to spikes in deaths; the new shot also covers A(H1N1), is expected to be a strong match to circulating strains, and will be the same used in the next Northern winter. High‑risk groups—the very young, the very old, and most Indigenous Australians—can access free, government‑funded vaccinations from April 20. Experts, including Dr Alan Hampson, say the delay is worth it and urge everyone to book vaccinations now to protect themselves and those around high‑risk individuals.

As Illinois marks the 150th anniversary of Abraham Lincoln’s assassination, caretakers of his Springfield tomb are defending the site against a harsh National Geographic critique and looming budget cuts that could reshape its management. Amid a state financial crisis, Gov. Bruce Rauner proposes eliminating the State Historic Preservation Agency that oversees the tomb, folding it into another department; a prior $1.1 million cut already reduced hours and staffing, leading some visitors to find it closed, though officials say correct hours are posted online. Historian Adam Goodheart derided the interior as a disappointing, incongruous Art Deco space with “all the historical character of an office lobby,” a view supporters call unfair and unrepresentative. The agency counters the tomb is in excellent condition after more than $2.5 million in recent repairs, including interior renovations and $730,000 in lighting upgrades, with a $390,000 waterproofing and vault repair project underway. Designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated by Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, the monument—reconstructed in 1899 and 1930—features marble-and-bronze interiors leading to the family burial chamber inscribed “Now he belongs to the ages,” and some visitors still find it “absolutely gorgeous.”

Nineties style is back (chokers, berry-coloured lips, round sunglasses, Calvin Klein logo tees), but news of JNCO’s return—rave jeans with leg openings nearing 50 inches—prompts Femail to round up retro trends it says should stay in the past: bucket hats (from fishermen to 90s pop, revived by Rihanna); camouflage print (Destiny’s Child-era staple now worn by Jourdan Dunn); maximalist looks like designer prints and double denim (from Victoria Beckham, Britney Spears, and Justin Timberlake to Kylie Jenner); Ugg boots (Paris Hilton to Kristen Bell, cozy but ungainly); Daisy Dukes (repopularized by Jessica Simpson, still ultra-short on Miley Cyrus though longer styles are now preferred); Juicy Couture velour tracksuits (Nicole Richie/Paris/Britney to Nicki Minaj); coloured sunglasses (NSYNC/Britney to Cara Delevingne and Kylie Jenner, now with mirrored sheen); corsets as outerwear (from Posh Spice to Selena Gomez’s corset-based gowns); and harem trousers (once Kim Kardashian’s, now on Elle Macpherson), all cited as nostalgic yet impractical or unflattering revivals.

A roundup of trending stories included a rare quadruple rainbow over New York photographed by Amanda Curtis; China’s crackdown on the growing practice of hiring exotic dancers for funerals; Robert Downey Jr. getting agitated during a UK Channel 4 interview; the #kyliejennerchallenge lip-plumping trend using a jar; 102-year-old Alice Barker revisiting the past with help from filmmakers; a bomb-referencing prom-posal rejected by a school, with the student alleging racism; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp appearing nearly unrecognizable in the Black Mass trailer; a pregnancy announcement referencing The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air; and a military dad photobombing his son.

At the Miami Open, celebrations turned cake-filled as world No 1 Serena Williams marked her 700th career win—following Andy Murray’s 500th—by defeating Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 to reach the semifinals at her near-hometown event in Florida, gaining a measure of revenge for her 2013 Wimbledon loss to Lisicki; hopes of a sister showdown ended when Venus Williams lost to Spain’s Carla Suarez Navarro, and Serena will instead face third seed Simona Halep, who beat Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Karachi-based activist and founder of the Second Floor (T2F) café known for promoting technology, human rights, and free speech, was shot dead by two gunmen at point-blank range after closing her café late Friday; she died of five bullet wounds, and her mother, also shot, is expected to be released from the hospital in time for the funeral. No one has claimed responsibility and police have not identified a motive, but Mahmud had just hosted a discussion on enforced disappearances in Balochistan—a topic authorities and mainstream institutions have suppressed, including a similar event shut down at LUMS—which she moved to T2F despite prior death threats. Widely regarded as a figurehead for humanism, love, tolerance, and courage, she drew young Pakistanis seeking open discourse, and tributes poured in after her killing, with friend and BBC journalist Ziad Zafar praising her bravery and impact.

Nearly 70 years after Partition, about 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (around 18,000 overwhelmingly Hindu families) living mainly in Jammu—people like 82-year-old healer Mangu Ram—remain denied state-subject rights in Jammu and Kashmir: they cannot own land, vote in state elections, hold state government jobs, or enroll in state training colleges (though they can take federal jobs), trapping three generations in slum poverty despite Kashmir being one of India’s more prosperous states and most refugees having been born in India. This exclusion stems from a pre-independence law restricting state citizenship to those from the old undivided kingdom of Kashmir and from leaders’ fears of upsetting the demographic balance in India’s only Muslim-majority state, which enjoys special autonomy; by contrast, roughly 35,000 Hindus who fled Pakistan-controlled Kashmir have been granted citizenship. Activists such as Labha Ram Gandhi demand state-subject rights and threaten protests if hopes are dashed, while the Bharatiya Janata Party’s recent entry into the state’s ruling coalition and pledge to normalize WPR status has raised expectations, even as ongoing insurgency and recent militant attacks on police underscore the region’s continuing unrest.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is weighing a summer move to Premier League leaders Chelsea after club president Naoki Ogane said the Blues had made an offer of about £4m, with plans to loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season. The 22-year-old says he wants to join a team where he can play regularly and develop. Ranko Popovic, who gave him his FC Tokyo debut, praised Muto’s intelligence, speed, strength, confidence, and background, believing he could thrive at Stamford Bridge. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledged awareness of Muto but declined to discuss him, noting that while commercial factors—including a £200m Yokohama Rubber sponsorship—and Financial Fair Play influence decisions, the club only sign good players or prospects.

The passage praises Australia for scrapping its ban on selecting overseas‑based players and urges England to follow suit, arguing Stuart Lancaster should be free to choose the best squad regardless of club location, especially with a home World Cup. It cites Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell’s Toulon form putting them back in Wallabies contention, highlights Steffon Armitage’s game‑changing impact and Nick Abendanon’s improvement in France, and recalls Jonny Wilkinson becoming even better after moving there. The author contends such restrictions demean a tournament meant to showcase the world’s best, notes that South Africa and Wales select stars abroad like Bryan Habana and Leigh Halfpenny, warns of the risk if England face Australia with those players in top form, and insists the RFU or Premiership should not dictate availability since clubs benefit from a winning England and players and fans deserve a best XV picked on merit, not home addresses.

Open Garden’s FireChat enables off-grid messaging by using Apple’s iOS 7 Multipeer Connectivity Framework and similar Android Bluetooth/Wi‑Fi Direct features to form wireless mesh networks where each device is a node relaying data, allowing chat in “Nearby” (within about 30 feet/9 m) or “Everyone” rooms; messages can typically travel up to about 200 feet (61 m), are sent securely so intermediate nodes can’t read them, can be anonymous via usernames, and don’t use the internet, with over five million downloads and usefulness in places like planes or the underground. To strengthen these networks, Open Garden developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped beacon/booster that stores messages until another FireChat device comes within range, currently works only with FireChat at about 20 feet (6 m), holds up to 1,000 recent messages, and has a one-year battery life. The combination is intended to provide resilient communication for communities, hospitals, and crowded events such as festivals, protests, and football matches where connectivity is absent or overloaded, with Greenstone’s release timing dependent on manufacturing partnerships.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle of New Jersey uses her TED Talk to reclaim “fat” as an honest, non-insulting self-descriptor—just like “short” (she’s 5'3") and “wife” (she’s married)—arguing that “fat” need not mean “ugly.” Citing research, she notes size-based discrimination has risen 66% in 30 years and that girls aged 11–17 most often “wish” to be thinner, but exposure to body diversity increases acceptance and even preference for varied body types. At 240 lbs, she embraced burlesque in 2012 to present a glamorous, positive “fat” body onstage, echoing performer Beelzebabe’s view that burlesque’s body diversity challenges narrow beauty standards. Performing proved empowering—despite initial worries about “jiggly arms”—and she advises others to find a personal “courage reference” to counter insecurity. Although delivered in 2014, her talk was posted to YouTube three weeks ago, drawing nearly 38,000 views and largely positive responses, including messages from young viewers who reevaluated their body image, leading her to conclude that body-positivity is winning despite a few online trolls.

Regularly benched this season, 26-year-old Theo Walcott appears in a Lanvin photoshoot with Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Ozil, and model Olga Sherer; Lanvin, Paris’ oldest fashion house and Arsenal’s official tailor since 2013, will dress the first team for their May 30 FA Cup final trip to Wembley against Aston Villa. Walcott has been a substitute in 17 of Arsenal’s 33 league games, featured only for the last six minutes of the 0-0 draw with Chelsea, and is hoping to make his first start since the 3-0 win over West Ham on March 14 when Arsenal face Hull on Monday.

An auction of 417 original props and puppets from legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker’s Cinovation Studio will be held May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online at propstore.com, featuring a no-reserve sale estimated at $746,100 and spanning more than 50 productions. Highlights include items from Men in Black (Alien Edgar Bug valued at $40,000 and could sell for more, Mikey costume $30,000, Worm Guy $10,000), Batman Forever (Two-Face mask $1,500), How the Grinch Stole Christmas (Grinch costume $8,000), Gremlins 2 (Bat, Mohawk, and Daffy Gremlins at $6,000 to $8,000), Harry and the Hendersons (Harry suit $6,000), Batman & Robin (Frosty thug statue $4,000), Michael Jackson’s Moonwalker (robotic transformation face $3,000), and Mighty Joe Young (hero Joe head $6,000), with additional pieces tied to An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Hellboy, and the Thriller video; all items will be sold to the highest bidder, and some are expected to fetch more than $40,000.

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell from Talybont-on-Usk, Wales, died in a skiing accident in Flaine, French Alps, after becoming separated from his family on the last run of their holiday; when his sister lost a ski and his mother stopped to help, he pressed on, left the piste for dense woodland apparently heading toward the resort he could see, removed his skis to continue on foot, and fell 164ft, with police later tracing his footprints and sliding marks to his body, which is ready for repatriation. His family paid moving tribute to a daring, outgoing, determined and caring boy whose smile lit up rooms and who made life full of laughter; he was a very competent skier and snowboarder since age three who admired Bear Grylls. His mother searched desperately for him, and friends, his Brecon school, and the local community have expressed grief and support over the tragic accident.

Fifteen-year-old Laura Scurr from Whitley Bay describes a two-year battle with anorexia that began after bullying and pervasive “size zero” pressures led her from a “sensible diet” into extreme restriction, hiding food, lying about meals, and surviving on about 100 calories or a single piece of fruit a day (even using mashed potato to conceal uneaten food). Her health deteriorated—her heart rate slowed, she became dizzy and bedbound, then collapsed—and she spent a week on a heart monitor at North Tyneside General Hospital, underscoring the pressure she and other girls feel to be thin. After discharge she received support from eating disorder organizations, EDICT, and CAMHS, and is now healthier, reaching the Miss Teen GB semi-final, a contest promoting confidence over size-zero ideals. The passage adds NHS guidance: anorexia is a serious mental health condition, often starting in teenage girls, marked by severe restriction and behaviors like self-induced vomiting and laxative use; an estimated 725,000 people in the UK had eating disorders in 2015 (10% anorexia), and loved ones are urged to offer gentle support and seek help from charities such as Beat.

Liverpool unveiled their 2015/16 home kit at Anfield, the first from New Balance after a record £300m four-year deal replacing Warrior, with Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, Simon Mignolet and others modeling a gingham-style strip featuring all-white branding, a new collar, and the Hillsborough tribute flame and “96.” Amid the “Hold Nothing Back” launch, fans urged Sterling to stay after he rejected a £100,000-a-week contract and said Arsenal interest was flattering, and the club insist the 20-year-old with two years left will not leave this summer. Players praised the supporters and looked ahead to the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, while Steven Gerrard’s hope of bowing out in the May 31 FA Cup final remains alive.

A University of Manchester team led by Dr. Sarah Bridle has produced the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, the first in a series from the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES) that aims to create a 3D map across roughly one-eighth (12.5%) of the sky. Using early DES data from the 570‑megapixel Dark Energy Camera on the 4‑meter Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile, they measured tiny gravitational-lensing distortions in galaxy shapes—analyzing about 130 million images with supercomputers—to infer where dark matter lies. The initial map covers about 0.4% of the sky (around 3% of DES’s planned area), reveals large filaments and cosmic voids that align with the distribution of visible galaxies, and supports the idea that galaxies form where dark matter is densest. By mapping the clumpiness of dark matter over time, DES aims to test cosmological theories and probe the nature of dark energy, which is believed to be accelerating the universe’s expansion.

PSV Eindhoven confirmed Manchester United have made an official approach for 21-year-old Memphis Depay, with Louis van Gaal—who coached him at the 2014 World Cup—keen to make him a first summer signing; United appear to be in pole position despite competition from Paris Saint‑Germain and another major European club, and Tottenham’s rejected £15m bid last year means a higher fee is now expected. Depay is enjoying a prolific season with 20 goals in 26 Eredivisie games, including a free kick as PSV beat Heerenveen 4-1 to clinch their first league title in seven seasons and the club’s 22nd, and he is the league’s leading scorer. Born in 1994, he rose through VV Moordrecht and Sparta Rotterdam before joining PSV at 12, debuting in 2011, signing professional terms in 2012, and surpassing 100 first‑team appearances. A pacy left winger who dribbles, cuts inside and shoots powerfully from distance, he can still make occasional poor decisions; he is praised by Phillip Cocu and teammate Stijn Schaars, compared favorably to a young Cristiano Ronaldo by scout Ed van Steijn, and tipped to reach Arjen Robben’s level. Internationally, van Gaal first called him up in 2013; he scored at the World Cup against Australia and Chile and was shortlisted for Best Young Player.

Chelsea’s youngsters won 3-1 at Manchester City’s Academy Stadium to take a commanding lead back to West London in the Youth Cup final, with Tammy Abraham scoring two first-half volleys (his 35th and 36th of the season), Isaac Buckley-Ricketts briefly leveling, and Dominic Solanke adding a late third; Abraham later went off injured on 67 minutes. For City, Haug looked shaky under high balls but wasn’t at fault for the goals; captain Tosin Adarabioyo and Humphreys-Grant were strong at the back; Maffeo and Jose Angelino Tasende were limited going forward; Kean Bryan went off hurt then returned and missed a big chance; Nemane was lively but wasteful; Celina and Manu Garcia were largely ineffective; Buckley-Ricketts was mostly contained despite scoring; and Barker was dangerous but tried to do too much. Chelsea’s standouts included goalkeeper Bradley Collins, commanding center-backs Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, influential right-back Ola Aina, lively Jay Dasilva, midfield shield Ruben Sammut, captain Charlie Colkett who bossed midfield, and Isaiah Brown who threatened despite an early miss; Charly Musonda was quiet, and substitute Kasey Palmer showed pace but shot over.

Marco Rubio told CBS’s Face the Nation that while he isn’t against gay marriage personally, he believes marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman, that states—not courts—should decide marriage laws, and that same-sex marriage is not a constitutional right; he also said he believes most people are born with their sexual preference. He added that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer out of love and respect despite disagreeing, likening it to his Catholic belief that divorce is wrong but not a reason to stop loving someone. Rubio recently announced his presidential run, and donors say he has already secured monetary commitments exceeding the roughly $51 million he’s expected to need for a crowded Republican primary.

Spanish 27-year-old Pablo Mandado and Latvian 31-year-old Ilze Zebolde quit restaurant jobs in Manchester to pursue an open-ended, ultra-budget dream to “discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time.” In 356 days they’ve cycled nearly 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries, carrying about 130 kg of gear (including bicycles). Starting in London, they rode through France (west and south coasts after a Spain/Portugal loop), northern Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece and into Turkey (a symbolic exit from Europe), then along Turkey’s north coast to Georgia and Armenia; they plan to continue across Asia, the Pacific, and the Americas for years. Living on under €3 each per day (about €0.10/km), with food at €2.74, they eat staples, accept meals and free produce, forage, and dumpster-dive in Western countries; they avoid transport costs, mostly camp (161 of 256 nights), also use Couchsurfing (66) and Warmshowers (44), and sometimes rely on strangers, with showers only intermittently.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 allege that a photo booth from Premiere Photos printed “poor n ***** party” on their wedding snapshots, which they learned months later when the bride’s sister—who withheld it to avoid spoiling the day—told them. With attorney Cathy Hale, they are suing owner James Evans under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract, saying Evans refused to apologize and told them to “sue me.” Evans and his attorney Christine Kirchner deny the claims, citing lack of evidence tying the company to the caption at a 103-guest event and asserting the couple showed no mental anguish. The couple, whose reception was at the Bell Tower in northwest Houston, primarily want an apology; mediation is scheduled for tomorrow, with a July trial if no agreement is reached.

England full-back Mike Brown is taking a cautious, step-by-step return after a concussion, having withdrawn from Harlequins’ match against Saracens and remaining unsure of his comeback date. He felt unwell with headaches after England’s game against France, despite no single incident, and previously was knocked out versus Italy before pulling out of the Ireland match; he credits World Rugby online modules with helping him recognize symptoms, stresses honesty, and says it’s not worth pushing through, adding he would urge teammates not to play on. His stance is framed by high-profile cases such as Northampton’s George North—advised not to play again this season after multiple concussions, ruled out against Clermont and set to see a neurosurgeon—and Ireland’s Johnny Sexton, who was stood down for 12 weeks, with Brown keen to avoid a long layoff like Sexton or Geoff Parling. He spoke as a Land Rover ambassador at the launch of the “We deal in real” Rugby World Cup 2032 campaign highlighting grassroots clubs.

A leading expert suggests smartphone use and constant connectivity may be contributing to a decline in how often couples have sex, with research showing British sexual frequency has fallen since the internet’s emergence. Cambridge statistician Professor David Spiegelhalter reports in his book Sex by Numbers that a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, down from four in 2000 and five in 1990. He cites possible factors such as more people living alone but argues a more realistic cause is that technology has blurred boundaries between home and work, making lives busier and eroding “quiet” time, with constant email checking squeezing time with partners. Researcher Catherine Mercer adds that competing demands push sex down priorities and late-night work emails leave people too connected at bedtime to focus on their partner.

Tibetan mastiffs—loyal herding dogs that can weigh up to 80 kg—have crashed from status symbols fetching up to £1.2 million to being so unpopular in China that many are sent to slaughterhouses supplying hotpot meat to restaurants and their skins used for leather belts. The decline is blamed on an anti-corruption crackdown that halted gift-giving to officials (per Luo Yi of China’s largest mastiff puppy farm), bans on dogs over 50 kg in cities including Beijing, Zhengzhou, Shanghai and Tianjin, rapid urbanization revealing the breed’s poor suitability for city life (per photographer Chen Youjun), and profit-driven cross-breeding that degraded quality and created a glut of unsellable dogs. Animal-welfare workers recently rescued 20 mastiffs crammed in cages en route to an abattoir; a third were already dead, none had food or water for three days, and several had broken bones, amid fears hundreds face similar cruelty, with gangs stealing dogs and breeders offloading “imperfect” animals. The boom began in 2005; just 13 months ago a golden-haired one-year-old sold for £1.2 million to a property developer from breeder Zhang Gengyun in Zhejiang, while another red pup fetched nearly £600,017.

A poll of 600 women from the Paris area found that every female mass-transit user reported experiencing some form of gender harassment or sexual assault on public transport, with half first harassed before age 18, and some unaware due to normalization of low-level abuse. Harassment ranges from insults, insistent flirting, whistling, and comments on appearance to sexual attacks or rape. Six in ten women fear being attacked on public transport (vs three in ten men), and the often unreported abuse restricts women’s freedom by forcing changes to routes, transport modes, schedules, attitudes, and clothing, effectively excluding them from public space. The High Council for Gender Equality, which submitted the report to the French women’s rights ministry, called for a campaign to curb sexist and threatening behavior; its president Pascale Boisard expressed surprise at the scale, while Ernestine Ronai noted attackers feel impunity in crowds and stressed that touching someone’s backside is sexual assault punishable by a five-year prison term and a €75,005 fine, urging better education for women, aggressors, and witnesses.

Leeds-based Direct Line’s #everydayfix competition, run via a design makeathon with London’s Makerversity, surveyed 2,000 people to identify top everyday emergencies—led by not being able to sleep (46%), with others including losing keys, being late in traffic, lost documents, no parking, printer failures, dead phone batteries, no toilet roll, automated customer service, and forgetting bank cards. Three shortlisted prototypes are: Snooze by Instruments, an alarm clock that connects to a phone and mutes notifications to aid sleep; Forget Me Lock by onn studio, a key-mounted device that swivels green when a door is open and red when locked, letting users check status while away; and Nipper by Impulse, a tiny phone charger powered by any household battery via two terminals. Voting is on Twitter by retweeting posts with #everydayfix, and the most-retweeted entry by 46 April will proceed to a Kickstarter campaign and into development. Non-shortlisted ideas included Hat Nav (a bone-conduction navigation helmet for cyclists), Parking Pin (a device that alerts when a parking space is free), and Relay (an app to forward messages when a phone dies).

Northumbria Police and Crime Commissioner Vera Baird faces a Ministry of Justice investigation after allocating over £500,000 of public money to Victims First Northumbria, a victims’ charity she directs alongside Chief Constable Sue Sim, prompting accusations of a conflict of interest and criticism from Keith Vaz, who called the situation a “soap opera” and said such powers should not have been granted to PCCs. Baird said all MoJ procedures were followed, and Northumbria Police said the funding mirrors how the MoJ previously funded Victim Support; the MoJ confirmed it will investigate and can stop funding if a conflict is proven. The charity was set up after declining contact with its predecessor, but sources fear public reluctance due to Sim’s involvement and prior bullying allegations investigated by Baird; Sim has announced her June retirement, and Baird has praised their work together.

In Philadelphia, ringleader Corry “Corey” Campbell, 21, and accomplices Carl Halin, 18, and Sandra Ng, 19—dubbed the “tattoo terrorists”—pleaded guilty to attacking 53-year-old Greg Valecce in late March 2014, beating him, tying him to a chair for about 42 hours in a Mayfair basement, and tattooing offensive images and slurs after Campbell believed Valecce had injured his cat and stolen money and weed; Valecce suffered broken ribs, broken wrists, and facial fractures, escaped on April 1, and police found a tattoo gun, related paraphernalia, 155 grams of marijuana, prescription drugs, and his stolen debit card; Campbell and Halin were each sentenced to 20 years in state prison and Ng to 23 months, while another man, David Thomas, 28, awaits sentencing and Jennifer Pratt, 40, awaits trial; Valecce has had the tattoos removed but reports lasting trauma.

PSV Eindhoven confirm Manchester United have made an official approach for 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal—who coached him at the 2014 World Cup—keen to sign him; Tottenham’s £15m offer was rejected last summer, and his price has since risen amid interest from Paris Saint‑Germain and another major European club, according to PSV technical director Marcel Brands. Depay has 20 goals in 26 league games and scored a free kick as PSV beat Heerenveen 4-1 to win their first Eredivisie title in seven seasons and the club’s 22nd overall. Born in 1994, he progressed from VV Moordrecht and Sparta Rotterdam to PSV’s academy at 12, debuted in 2011, signed a pro deal in 2012, and has over 100 first-team appearances. A fast, powerful left winger who dribbles well, cuts inside onto a strong right foot, and shoots from distance, he can still make occasional poor decisions. He has been likened to Arjen Robben by coach Phillip Cocu, rated by ex-United scout Ed van Steijn as better than a young Cristiano Ronaldo, praised by teammate Stijn Schaars, and internationally scored against Australia and Chile at the World Cup before being shortlisted for Best Young Player (won by Paul Pogba).

Chelsea won 3-1 at Manchester City’s Academy Stadium in the Youth Cup final, taking a commanding lead back to west London. Tammy Abraham struck two first-half volleys (his 35th and 36th of the season) either side of Isaac Buckley-Ricketts’ equaliser, and Dominic Solanke sealed it late on. City’s Kjetil Haug was shaky under high balls but blameless for the goals; Pablo Maffeo improved after early struggles; captain Tosin Adarabioyo was commanding; Cameron Humphreys-Grant coped well; Jose Angelino was limited going forward; Kean Bryan went off injured then returned but missed a big chance; Aaron Nemane was lively but wasteful; Bersant Celina and Manu Garcia were largely ineffective; Buckley-Ricketts was pacy; Brandon Barker dangerous but tried too much. For Chelsea, Bradley Collins distributed well; Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter were strong at the back, with Ola Aina influential and Jay Dasilva solid if fortunate to avoid a caution; Ruben Sammut shielded superbly; captain Charlie Colkett controlled midfield; Solanke combined powerfully with Abraham; Charly Musonda was quiet; Isaiah Brown missed an early sitter but remained a threat; and sub Kasey Palmer showed pace but poor finishing.

Marco Rubio said on Face the Nation that while he isn’t against gay marriage and would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, he believes marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman, same-sex marriage is not a constitutional right, and courts should not decide the issue; instead, state legislatures should regulate it through political debate. He argued most people are born with their sexual preference and, as a Catholic who believes divorce is wrong, he would still love and respect those making choices he disagrees with. Rubio recently announced his presidential run, and donors say he has already received monetary commitments exceeding the roughly $47 million he is expected to need for a crowded Republican primary.

Spanish cyclist Pablo Mandado, 27, and Latvian Ilze Zebolde, 31, quit restaurant jobs in Manchester to pursue an open-ended, agenda-free dream to discover the world “a pedal at a time.” In 356 days they have ridden almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries, starting in London and traveling via France (after a Spain–Portugal loop), northern Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, along Turkey’s north coast, then Georgia and Armenia; they plan to continue across Asia, cross the Pacific, and cycle the length of the Americas. Living ultra-cheaply at about €0.10 per km and under €3 each per day, they minimize costs by cycling for transport and relying on free or hosted lodging—161 nights camping plus 66 via Couchsurfing and 44 via Warmshowers, with occasional help from strangers—while showers range from daily to weekly. Food is their only major expense, averaging €2.74 of their €2.99 daily outlay, sourced from staples, seasonal produce, invitations, foraged fruit, and dumpster diving in western countries. Carrying about 130 kg of gear, they travel unhurriedly, savoring moments like the symbolic crossing from Greece into Turkey and “into the unknown,” and intend to stay on the road for years.

England full-back Mike Brown is taking a cautious, stage-by-stage approach to recovering from concussion and is unsure of his return after withdrawing from Harlequins’ game against Saracens at Wembley; he reported post-France headaches without a single clear incident and plans to follow protocols (e.g., a 20-minute bike test) rather than rush back to avoid long lay-offs like Johnny Sexton or Geoff Parling. Knocked out against Italy in the Six Nations, he also pulled out before the Ireland match, crediting World Rugby’s online concussion modules for heightening his awareness of symptoms, stressing honesty, and saying he would urge teammates not to play on if symptomatic. His stance comes amid broader concerns: Northampton’s George North, after a fourth quick-fire concussion and being knocked out against Wasps, will miss the Clermont match, see a neurosurgeon, and has been advised not to play again this season, while Sexton was previously stood down for 12 weeks. Brown spoke as a Land Rover ambassador at the launch of its “We Deal In Real” Rugby World Cup 2028 campaign highlighting grassroots clubs.

A leading expert, Professor David Spiegelhalter of Cambridge, reports in his book Sex by Numbers that Britons’ sexual frequency has fallen since the internet’s emergence, with a typical heterosexual couple now having sex three times a month, down from four in 2000 and five in 1990. He suggests smartphone and internet use—especially constant email checking—has blurred boundaries between public and private life, made people busier, and squeezed time with partners; another possible factor is more people living alone. Researcher Catherine Mercer adds that competing demands push sex down priorities and late-night work emails leave people too connected at bedtime to focus on their partner.

In China, Tibetan mastiffs—once status symbols that boomed from 2005 and sold for up to £1.2 million as recently as 13 months ago—have crashed in popularity due to the government’s anti-corruption drive reducing gift-giving to officials, city bans on dogs over 50 kg (e.g., Beijing, Zhengzhou, Shanghai, Tianjin), rapid urbanization making them unsuitable for city life, and profit-driven cross-breeding that degraded quality and created a glut of poor specimens. As a result, many mastiffs (which can weigh up to 80 kg and were traditionally loyal herding dogs) are being sent to slaughterhouses supplying cheap hotpot meat and leather belts; animal-welfare workers recently found 20 crammed in cages en route, with a third already dead, no food or water for three days, and some with broken bones. Charities report dogs are being stolen by gangs and that unscrupulous breeders are offloading “imperfect” animals, marking a dramatic reversal from their heyday of record-breaking sales.

Leeds-based Direct Line’s #everydayfix competition, run through its Everyday Fix design makeathon with groups from London-based Makerversity, surveyed 2,000 people to identify top “everyday emergencies” (leading issue: not being able to sleep, 46%, with others including losing keys, being stuck in traffic, losing documents, parking problems, printer failures, phone battery dying, running out of toilet roll, machine-operated customer service, and forgetting a bank card). Three shortlisted prototypes were created: Snooze by Instruments, an alarm clock that connects to your phone to silence notifications for better sleep; the Forget Me Lock by onn studio, a key-mounted indicator that swivels green when a door is open and red when locked, letting you confirm lock status while away; and Nipper by Impulse, described as the world’s smallest phone charger, which uses any household battery via two terminals to give a phone a boost. People can vote on Twitter by retweeting posts about these products with the #everydayfix hashtag; the tweet with the most retweets by 40 April will proceed to a Kickstarter campaign and development. Other proposed fixes that didn’t make the shortlist included Hat Nav (a bone-conduction navigation helmet for cyclists), Parking Pin (a device left in a space to alert you when it becomes free), and Relay (an app to nominate contacts to receive your messages when your phone dies).
